description:
Very good Chinese food place in Japan Town.  The dry fired shrimp, awesome, and is a must.  High quality ingredients, experience Chinese chefs,  great customer service, nice location and authentic taste. 

Chinese in Japan Town , yes indeed!
author: Kevin O.

description:
I have been going to this spot since I was in middle. I'm. thinking 1999. We always had big family parties upstairs. I would also go here with my primary family to have dinner.

The # 1 thing we ordered is the deep fried squid Super smacking extra crispy if possible. Its an all time favorite and cravings Yadadaimean!!! All the other foods like honey walnut shrimp, fried rice, sizzling soup, salt n pepper spareribs etc... is all good as well!!!

Enjoy a Lunch or Dinner here!!!
author: Ryan M.

description:
So I have to admit in all my visits to J-Town over the years, I managed to avoid this restaurant even though I've tried almost every other place in the immediate vicinity. Was it an odd sense of culinary xenophobia that prevented me from entering? Yeah, probably because I was one of the old-school types who felt when in J-Town, you eat Japanese no matter how good or bad it may be. But I've broadened my horizons and tried both Korean and Thai food in the neighborhood, so why not try Chinese, in particular, Mandarin?

Other reviews mentioned Korean dishes as part of the cooking offering here, although I guess I didn't get that far in the menu to notice. I did take notice of the complimentary cup of kimchee that landed in front of me before I ordered. It was crunchy though a tad too sweetly mild for my taste (photo: http://bit.ly/2IsWTfc). I was in the mood for something basic, so I ordered the $12.50 Chicken with Black Mushrooms, which was pretty basic with shiitake caps and pea pods mixed to a shiny finish with the poultry (photo: http://bit.ly/2k3HdVa). The $1.45 Steamed Rice was necessary to sop up the requisite brown sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/2IoWsCh).

I was feeling indulgent and went for the $8.95 Steamed Potstickers, a half-dozen hefty ones that tasted even doughier than they looked in the metal steamer (photo: http://bit.ly/2IICkyH). The piping hot minced pork stuffing was hearty stuff though you need to let them cook a bit before ingesting. I actually came back a couple of weeks later to try the $10.95 Eggplant with Garlic Sauce and was pleasantly surprised to find it not submerged in brown sauce and actually festooned with shaved mushrooms. So maybe I have gotten over my xenophobia. OK, maybe not.

FOOD - 3 stars...pretty standard dishes, huge portions.
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...popular spot but nothing special 
SERVICE - 3 stars...'been there, done that' attitude
TOTAL - 3 stars... if a hankering for Chinese hits you in J-Town
author: Ed U.

description: It's ok. Next time, I'll drive a little further and get better food. Had snow peas/shrimp, fried rice, chow mein, Mongolian beef and dry fried chicken. The chicken was the best but average. Chicken was a little dry. Eat Japanese instead if in the area.
author: Frank F.

description:
We came here after a day in Japan Town and Fillmore Jazz and by dinner time we were hungry. The food was ok. Some dishes hit the mark better than others such as the fried chicken wings. I saw others eating fried whole fish and wished our group ordered that. The sizzling rice soup that our friend wanted didn't sizzle at all 
Service isn't the greatest as it takes a long time to get their attention. The place is large with plenty of tables but is starting to look dated.
author: Ry T.

description: We came to this restaurant so my family and I could eat black bean noodles jajangmyun. We order 2 between the 4 of us and got share bowls since the noodles were big and we were getting more dishes. We also got the tangsuyook which is crispy fried pork in a sweet sour sauce. I would skip the dumplings. They came out with the skins broken and the flavor was kinda off.
author: Vivian C.

description:
I decided to come here instead of San Tung because, deducing from Yelp reviews, it seems less busy. And, that, I was correct! We came here after SF Comic Con. Already tired and extremely hot, we were more than ready to chow down.

Straight to the point - I didn't enjoy the food at all.

Our eyes were bigger than our stomach; we ordered three dishes split between the two of us. I'll give San Wang an extra star for the large portions.

We ordered:
- pork spare ribs, Korean style
- black bean noodles
- dry fried chicken wings

Each dish came out to be around $12.

The server asked me if I wanted to have the pork spare ribs Korean style, and I didn't know what that entailed, but I don't ever second guess the server's choice. Meh, I was wrong. It was basically hard pork rinds in a clear sweet and sour sauce. The sauce was good, but the actual meat itself was not. Would not recommend.

The black bean noodles were on the sweet side. There was only so much I could eat.. and I love bbn! :(

The dry-fried chicken wings were LARGE in size, holy. However, it was only mediocre.

To be frank, I'd rather spend an hour or more waiting for San Tung than eat here. Portions are large and food was only okay. It wasn't bad, but I wouldn't come here again, unfortunately.
author: Nicole D.

description:
OK Korean-chinese place in jtown

The staff here are pretty friendly. The food comes quickly. We got the beef noodle soup, which had really soft beef, probably took them a while to boil the beef overnight. The black bean jajang noodles was also pretty good--came in a large flat plate. The taste was ok, not bad, a little on the bland side. The decor inside is average--it looks like the place has been around for a while.

Overall, an OK korean chinese place
author: Henry L.

description:
Growing up in the beautiful city by the bay I have been truly blessed to have experienced bountiful and plentiful scrumptious dining experiences.....
Cheerfully includes San Wang! My parents brought us here time and time again over the past 4 decades for family meals, take outs, celebrations and even my first of two marriage wedding ceremony was catered from San Wang back in 1992! All 3 of my Sisters and families choose to dine here when visiting San Francisco. Parking has never been difficult with the garage parking just across the street. 
MmmmmmMmmMMMmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm.......
********Spicy Shrimp***********Clearly on my Top Favorite List Any Day!!
There are days when I just Crave the flavor of this Gotta Have and Gotta Enjoy Explosion of Sheer Delightful Yumminess to the Extreme!! The taste is not spicy and more on the sweet side with the perfect combination of soft plump shrimp, green peas, carrots, green onions and sauce galore.....can and have enjoyed the left over sauce with just good ol rice and Kimchee!!!  
I do wish there could be a San Wang here in the South Bay so that we could enjoy more often instead of a few times per year. 
Jajang Myun is also a must try and favorite.... back in the day we used to be able to watch the chef come out to the open table area where he would make the noodles for us to see! Have not seen this happen in past years so I'm not sure if I'm just not going on the days it's done or if management decided to no longer present the master piece in action mode. The sauce once again is simply perfection at its finest. 
We noticed the service is not quite as used to be however the treasured memories with the scrumptious meal will continue to welcome us back here timeless days. 
May decide to take a drive there sooner than later to feast and treat my taste buds and all of my senses!
author: Yoh M.

description:
My favorite place since I was a little girl.Every time  I crave noodles and spicy clams, I would come out to San Wang in japantown. They are family owned and prices has not really increased last 20 years. Service is great and the hand pulled noodles, spicy clams, dry fried boneless chicken and water dumplings are my fav dishes. Spicy clams is one of their signature dishes and comes in a good portion size. 

This place is consistent every time I come. Across the street from the center and prices range 12-20 per dish. Park in the one lot, spend 1/2 day here and enjoy the shops and food.
author: Jade L.

description: Disgusting and disrespectful ownership.  Sat there for 3 minutes without a menu.  Place was entirely open for seating and server sat me in a spot I didn't want to sit in.  Do not come here if you want to feel respected.  Terrible.
author: Stanley T.

description:
*** Vegetarian Review ***

Who goes to Japantown to eat at a Chinese restaurant? Our family has been paying the Bay Bridge toll to get to the city for over 30 years and hopefully after reading this and browsing through the food pictures, you will too. 

This isn't like the Chinese restaurants in China Town. Let's put it this way. Some great friends that owned a Chinese restaurant said they don't even eat at the Chinese restaurants in China Town because of cleanliness issues. Now it's not eating-off-the-floor clean here either, but you won't think twice when you walk in.

Tips for first timers:

1. Parking. San Wang is located on the perimeter of Japantown. If you get a window seat, you can see the Peace Pagoda in Japantown's center. This being San Francisco and in a tourist area, don't mess around with street parking. You're going to stroll Japantown either before or after so use the parking garage across the street.

2. Order everything dry-fried! I have no idea about any other dishes because all I've ever eaten here are the veggie chow mein / chow fun and whatever they can dry fry. What is dry fry? Imagine a tempura with a very thin, extra crispy batter and then imagine rainbows and unicorns!

3. Don't see it on the menu, just ask. Unlike some of the China Town restaurants where communication can be difficult, this is as easy as ordering at Panda Express.

4. They provide a complimentary kimchi for the table before your main meals arrive. Like most kimchis, this is not vegetarian-friendly.

Dry fried Eggplant (Grade A+)

I first tried this dish in my early vegetarian days and was so happy, ordered another to go. It has all the making of an eggplant tempura, but unlike the Japanese style that usually has too much batter and is mushy, San Wang lightly batters and dry frys this dish to a golden brown. The edges are crispy like the last piece of a corndog -- the piece on the stick.

Then, they drench the crispy eggplant with a Sichuan style sauce. My rookie taste buds detect soy sauce, sugar, garlic and my eyes can see spring onions, red bell peppers, and chilis. You would think this would make the dish soggy and you would be wrong. However, I recommend moving the eggplant out of the swimming pool of sauce to help your cause. Oftentimes, after this dish moves around the Lazy Susan, you won't have to worry about it because it's all gone.

The portion size isn't always consistent, but for the most part, enough for 5.

Dry fried string beans (Grade A+)

Same sauce as above, but with mushrooms. Same cooking method as above. These are the best string beans you'll ever try. During non-peak hours, you can actually see employees stripping and cleaning the string beans so you know they're fresh. This is the vegetarian version of selecting your fish or lobster from the tank before it's cooked.

Portion size varies, but generally enough to feed a party of 5.

Dry fried tofu (Grade B+)

They have mapo tofu on the menu, but I've stopped ordering this for the last couple of years. I'm sure it's good, but it took me years to realize I just don't like mapo tofu. So on this visit, still wanting a protein to complete my meal, asked if they could make a dry fried tofu. They said they can make anything dry fried, but ask!

Same sauce as the string beans and the tofu is thick cut rectangles. It didn't arrive lightly battered like I expected, but it was still very good. Next time, I'll ask if they can prepare it similarly which would elevate this to an A+ dish.

The tofu is fresh. This isn't a small detail because some restaurants that offer a tofu dish, but don't have a lot of customers ordering it often serve the tofu beyond its use date as a cost saving attempt. I know when I order tofu here I will get a fresh item because when I look around, plenty of tables have tofu on their table. It's more likely they run out of tofu before they serve you spoiled tofu.

Overall food observations:

The server jokes, "everything dry fried." You may think it's a waste to order dishes with the same sauce profiles, but trust me, it's worth it. Thirty-plus years as a regular and there's never leftovers.

Overall restaurant observations:

1. Friendly staff. Communication is never a problem.  

2. Bathrooms are clean and have paper towels.

3. Like most authentic Chinese restaurants, tea is provided. If you want water, you have to ask and make sure you say how many or for the table. If one person just asks for water, it's not uncommon for just that one person to get water.

4. Don't want to wait? Try to get there when they open for lunch or if you can wait, go into full-tourist mode and visit the many sights and sounds of Japantown and return a little after the peak hours. Pretend you're on a dessert-recon. 

5. Groups. I actually don't know if they take reservations. We always make sure to show up when they open to make sure we get a table. They have 4 round large tables that can hold up to 7 comfortably and 8 uncomfortably.
author: Ron R.

description:
Accidentally stumbled upon this place one day and it was so great we kept coming back. Who knew a Korean Chinese place would be one of the highlights in Japan town. 

The portions are massive and the all the dishes we have tried are awesome. Highly recommend the fried chicken, the eggplant, and the spicy noodles! Those have been our go tos every time.
author: Kelly Z.

description:
-Big portion of food with reasonable price 
-Good place for family and friends meeting
author: Tiratiwan L.

description:
Been here twice and really pleased with the food each time. Some out of the ordinary items on the menu such as jellyfish but also interesting combinations of things. 

Today I went vegetarian with a dish combining bamboo shoots, pea sprouts, broccoli and shiitake mushrooms in a light brown sauce. It's delicious. 

As a lunch special for 9.95 it came with a big bowl of rice, a big bowl of Kimchi, tea and hot and sour soup.
author: Tim P.

description:
What do you eat when in Japantown?

Well, you'd think the normal response is, duh, Japanese food?!  
In my pre-20's, besides having countless bowls of udon in the mall, we actually dined at the original Korean House, up the stairs on Post near Laguna.  We also sometimes came here, a Chinese restaurant with a Korean influence... gee, sounds like a popular place on Irving Street.
They used to have a second restaurant on Clement near 25th Avenue.  

Back to this place, I've been shopping in the neighborhood a bit more often and, after parking, pass this restaurant seeing a decent amount of diners enjoying their meals. On a recent planned shopping trip, I called the restaurant and ordered my lunch.  When I tried to order it in Mandarin (knew that their cuisine was northern style), I was surprised to learn the lady who answered spoke took my order in English (I believe she is Korean).   Their two staple dishes are their fried chicken wings and Ja jiang mein (noodles in plum sauce).  Not wanting to be stuffed at work, I order the Dry fried chicken wings (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Tu2Fn5Rg3dU0WnPAYVsinw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) and the hot and sour soup (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=HlutbfCeg_GaD_eb7zlGDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).

Starting with the hot and sour soup, my first impression was that the flavors were subtle, not an in-your-face vinegar sour or pepper hot spicy.  Mainly I enjoyed that there was a variety of ingredients though one old time favorite was missing (Kum choy in Cantonese).  If you do not have a high tolerance to heavy flavors or spiciness, you'll enjoy this.

Now, the chicken wings are another story.  I noticed several reviewers compared this version to that Irving Street place and the best description is that they are different.  Where San Tung (and So, for that matter), it's all about the flavors in the batter, the star of San Wang's wings are the trimmings or condiments that accompany the chicken. The ingredients are garlic slices, Szechuan peppers (which I removed), scallions, and ginger in a tangy yet sweet sauce.  The wings are not heavily battered so they are lighter on the palate, yet still just as addictively good.  Let's just say that, after finishing the chicken, I spooned some rice to top with those ingredients.

Old time place that still works.  Be warned that prices have increased and, in studying the takeout menu, dining in for lunch is probably the best deal in enjoying their variety of dishes.  Yes, I will be back and you can bet the wings will be one of my dishes.
author: Mike C.

description:
I've been coming here since I was 7 years old. I believe this place still makes their own noodles for their ja jang myun.  My parents and I came here last night for their ja jang myun (noodles with black bean sauce) jam pong (sp???), some sweet n sour beef and their fried chicken wings. Everything was delicious, but their jam pong tasted very gingery to me, and that seemed to over power the seafood and everything else. We always get the clams, but this time we decided to skip on the clams as we had already ordered way too much food 

We were able to find street parking which seems rare in Japantown, as we normally have to park in the parking garage. I like that this place had different crowds of people eating there, and people of all ages seemed to enjoy the food.
author: Monica K.

description:
I came here on a weekday night, so the 4 of us got seated right away. We ordered some soup and dumplings first and they came super fast. The dumplings were only okay, the dumpling skin was a bit too hard. The soup was just a typical seafood soup, but it tasted good. 

We then ordered ja jhang mein and it was AMAZING! The portion was big enough for 4 people to share. Then lastly, we got their dry fried chicken wings AND IT WAS PROBABLY THE BEST IVE EVER HAD. The only competitor I've had was SO (I heard they have the same owner as San tung), but I definitely prefer the chicken here better. It was seriously AMAZING! It was quite crispy but also saucy. It was so good that I almost forgot to mention they forgot my order.

LOL. We waited over 30 mins for our order, we kept asking and she kept telling me it is coming. BUT ITS TOTALLY NOT. I asked the younger waitress and she finally went to check for me. They forgot my order but cooked it really fast. Because the chicken was so good I had really conflicted feelings. So I gotta take 1 star off for that now. Anyway, BE MINDFUL OF WHEN YOUR FOOD IS COMING OR WHEN IT IS NOT.

I wanted to split checks because of business expense reasons, but they didn't really wanna do it, so be prepared!
author: Jen K.

description: noodles with plum sauce. dry fry chicken wings. san wang noodle soup. get some veggies, maybe some dumplings. you'll be set. asian service, so dont expect too much. but it's cheap and the portions are huge!
author: Christina L.

description: Just had it for the first time. Avoid if you could help it. Food is bland and unexciting, typical tourist trap. Service was almost none existent, we had to wave down the waitress for napkins and tea refills. No one even bothered to check how we were doing.
author: Zhao C.

description:
This was a suggestion my mom made because she was craving Korean-Chinese fushion food. We ordered 4 dishes (jjajjangmyeon, jjampong, sweet & sour pork, combo fried rice) and shared it family style. 

Jjajjangmyeon: It was decent, but it did leave a salty after taste that didn't go away...&& the two pieces of shrimp was confusing. I never had shrimp in my jjajjangmyeon before lol. (Either they mistakenly put it there... or they're just being stingy with how many pieces they put on their dishes)

Jjampong: my dad enjoyed this & I agree. It wasn't too salty & had the perfect amount of spice.

Sweet & sour pork: They definitely got the sweet part, but left out the sour. The batter wasn't like a tempura like texture like I'm used to, more like fried chicken texture. (Something I'm not used to, so it was rather strange)

Combo fried rice: It was okay. Pretty bland..if only they added some seasoning or salt it would've been better

The most confusing part of this dining experience is when I ask for iced water. The waitress brought a jug of water, but no cups. When she brought the fried rice, we had no spoons. It was just kinda annoying asking for basic utensils that should've been there once we were seated. :/
author: Sarah C.

description: Today, I travelled the Japantown. I heard about my friends that the food of San Wang Restaurant is pretty good. Thus, I came to the restaurant to try some foods. I ordered the general's chicken. I liked it so much because the chicken tasted so fresh.  Also, the general's sauce tasted sweet and spicy. I loved it. It's really suitable for chinese people taste. In addition, the owners looked so nice and kindhearted. He provided good service to me, and he always asked me what I needed, if I needed another one which didn't show in the menu, he still could help me do it. This is the best restaurant which compared with before. I recommend guys to try the foods, and I will come to the restaurant agiain.
author: Josie H.

description: Been going to this place for about 25 years+. Amazing consistency with really great tasting food. Dry fried shrimp unbeatable. Szechuan beef unbeatable. Whole fish unbeatable. Try the fresh made noodles but in soup not chow fun style. One my all time favorites anywhere in the world.
author: Tyrion L.

description:
I've been coming here since I was a kid in the 90s. Amazing Chinese/Korean food - chajang myun, hot and sour soup, sweet and sour pork, and dry fried shrimp! That's all I've gotten here for 20 years and it's always awesome. 

That being said, it's a hole in the wall that's ran by the family. Don't let that scare you away from this hidden gem in the heart of Japan Town!
author: Brandon F.

description:
Review is for their plum sauce noodles, AKA black bean noodles, AKA jjang jjang myun. AKA get in my stomach.

I've been craving these noodles for a few months, yet I haven't been able to make it out to Yu Yu Zazang in Oakland for them. My friend told me about this place in the city. I came with my Korean American friend, and we both ordered dem noodles. She said they're legit. If it's good enough for her, it's good enough for me! For $9.50, my craving was satisfied!
author: Joanna L.

description: Do NOT order the sweet and sour pork. It's really disgusting... water down, chewy, greasy... all in one. Honestly... Don't think I've had any worse Chinese food before
author: min t.

description:
Very nice traditional Korean-Chinese dishes. 
Enjoyed Jja jang myun and shrimp Jan poong gi. 
Bring back old memory from Seoul.
author: Munho Y.

description: I only ordered the water dumplings, but they were fantastic! I wish I had more time to try other items. What I saw on the other tables also looked very good and fresh.
author: Carla S.

description:
My family of four came for dinner on a weekday and we were seated right away. Yes, we came all the way to Japantown for Korean-Chinese food because we are the epitome of culture. Jokes aside, we actually came here because we read really great reviews about it and thought we'd give it a try too. We were surprised when the waiter who was Chinese spoke and understood Korean, taking our orders down with ease.

We ordered jjajangmyun (black sauce noodles), jjampong (spicy noodles), ggangpoonggi (fried chicken with sauce), and tangsuyuk (fried pork in sweet sauce). Instead of all at once, it seemed like each plate/platter came out as soon as it was ready, one-by-one. I can honestly say everything was absolutely delicious, especially the fried chicken! My family managed to just barely finish everything - it honestly is a LOT of food.

Also huge plus for putting the Warriors game on with the only TV in the restaurant!
author: Lydia K.

description:
Been coming here since I was a little girl, and that comforting taste still exists! This is a Korean-Chinese fusion-esque restaurant, but dishes lean towards Chinese. 

I recommend their dry friend chicken (wings) and the deep fried flounder! Both are juicy, tender, and extremely flavorful. Pair the sauce with rice and you'll be scarfing your rice down as if you were drinking water! I do recommend ordering family style to share as portions are quite large. 

Street parking will be tough during peak dining hours. You're better off saving time and parking in the parking garage. Service is decently friendly; pretty standard Chinese restaurant quality. Come for the food but not necessarily for the service and you'll feel great!
author: Kristi T.

description:
Korean-Chinese food is a comfort food to me. Nothing's better than a hot bowl of spicy seafood soup () and black bean noodles (). Coming from LA and having lived in Korea I've been spoiled with really good Korean-Chinese food.

Things I like:
spicy seafood soup: really flavorful with a lot of seafood!
fried black bean noodles: classic korean dish super tasy
fried chicken (): crispy chicken wings with a garlicky sauce

Things that I wouldn't get again:
fried rice: nothing spectacular
fried pork (): the sauce is a little bit too overwhelmingly sweet and the battter overpowers the pork. 

Overall a place I would go to if i had a Korean-Chinese food craving. Wouldn't go out of my way to eat it though.
author: Ariana F.

description:
Items here are of great portions, and that's about it. 

Their meat seem precook. Lack of flavor and it feels so werid inside your mouth, yuck. 

Price isnt cheap. Expect around $15 for each item you order.
author: Beth G.

description: Excellent food!! Order the baby shrimp in hot pepper sauce, dry fried squid and the  fried flounder!  Their Szchewan beef is good too!  Food comes out fast too!!  Been coming here for over 30+ years!
author: deborah y.

description:
#33/2016

They did the right thing, I want to start with that.

We wandered past a nearly full restaurant at 2pm and said, "Let's have lunch." 

A laminated review in their window indicated they're known for their hand-pulled noodles.

Yet, I shouldn't have ignored the 4 foot tall cart piled high with dirty dishes wheeled past us to a full stop. The bus boy pushed the cart past us a moment later but it was a sign of things to come.

Won ton soup was good, the dumplings were excellent with thin wrappers and delicious pork filling. 

This is where everything went very, very awry: the bus boy began bringing our dishes, first the walnut shrimp and bowl of steamed rice (I picked off a small bit of soy-stained rice off the edge of the bowl and put it aside.)

I chose to ignore it, my mistake -again. 

I had two or three shrimp; they were very good but the thought of the bus boy clearing tables in between becoming our server, I began to stop eating.

The water dumplings came, again delivered by the bus boy. I was ok until I remembered he'd gone from clearing tables to the dumplings set on our table.

I stopped eating. I pushed away the Tsing Tao he'd also set down. I patiently waited to ask for the check.

And in those two minutes, I thought about cross-contamination, Hep A, Zika and I complained to the harried but sweet manager who apologized and said two people had called in sick and..

I stage whispered- though there was now only one table occupied,

"That's not my problem! This is unsanitary. Think of the contamination. I was going to take this home but I don't even want to eat it!"

She tried to explain he'd washed his hands and pointed to a sink a few feet away and I insisted,

"But he didn't! Not the first- or second or third time he brought our food in between clearing tables."

She sincerely apologized and said she'd talk to the owner in the kitchen. 

She came out quickly and said they wouldn't charge us.

Between our barely touching anything besides the soup, the decision was straightforward still, I appreciated they did the right thing. 

The restaurant was full at 2pm for a reason: The food would be very good under other circumstances. And I felt bad that a small family business would be crippled by two no-show employees. 

I thanked them, put a $10 tip on the table (likewise the right thing to do) and left.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
My favorite Chinese in Bay Area 
Eat here about once a month even tho I live down on the Peninsula 
Clean but stark surroundings 
TV always has the game on
Love beef and green beans
Always get Hot and Sour soup
author: John O.

description: Food is okay, nothing too special. Service is terrible. Wait is so long when there's no one in there but on other family. Definitely won't be back here again.
author: Leafar D.

description: Family from Korea was in town. Ended up eating here as they really wanted some Korean/Chinese food. Surprisingly better than expected. Still just okay Chinese/Korean. The sweet and sour pork needs some improvement. Jjajangmyun is probably the best choice here.
author: Charles K.

description: Chinese food made Korean style -- the portions are enormous and the lunch specials are such an amazing deal that it can start getting filled even on a random weekday. Decent quality food too. Might not be the best or tastiest Chinese/Korean place I've been to but it certainly gets the job done and so quickly. I love kimchi and especially in the cabbage form, so this place doesn't disappoint in that regard as well.
author: David Y.

description:
Review is only for take out chowmein. 
I ordered pork and vegetables even tho they are separate on the menu
It hit the spot and came out piping hot
The lady owner(I think) who took our order was very nice and hospitable.

I will be back!
author: Pin C.

description:
Periodically I've been coming to this place for last 20+ years.  Wow, things have degraded... Worst food I've had.  No more visit to this place; and, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.  Shrimp (In Wonton soup) and Wonton tasted just out of frozen bag at the last minute.  I should have gotten the clue that the last visit ordering peking duck came with flour totilla, but...Also, they automatically add minimum 15% to their bill, written-in policy change on the menu (Change from the previous visit).   Shouldn't tip be inspired by Services/Value you've received, not automatically added because you are with 4 other people (Yes, we were a party of 5)?  Only additional Services we've received were 2 glass of water and 2 forks for kids.  We had to hail the waiter to get the bill and get few empty take-out boxes (Yep, we couldn't finish because the food was bad).    Finally, isn't it a common thing to get fortune cookies or some after-meal sweet after Chinese food?  None! 

PS: Brandon F, I don't know if you went back after May or there's a change in Chef, but, it is not the same San Wang that  you and I came to count on over 20 years.
author: D K.

description: Black bean noodle (jja jang myun) and spicy seafood noodle soup were good. I like their complimentary Kimchee too. Unfortunately, beef Tang Su Yuk was just ok. I think this was over fried and meat was too thin. I tasted mostly fried batter not beef. Overall, I like this restaurant.
author: EunJoo C.

description:
First went here a couple years ago, when my aunt introduced me.  I would say the food here is pretty hit or miss.  But I learned and only order the same things every time -- the spicy shrimp and dry fried chicken wings.  So for those two alone, it's 4 stars lol.  

I live in the east bay, I wouldn't drive to sf just to come here, but if I'm ever in the Japantown area, these are two dishes I crave.  

Add hot chili sauce for more kick!

PS.  Sorry for the double pics, forgot I posted them already and can't remove the dupes.  Must have been really good for me to post those twice lol!
author: Rustin L.

description: This family owned restaurant has been in business for 40+ years! Was only able to try the sea cucumber and clams tonight and pair it with ginseng wine. Fresh ingredients. I usually don't like sea cucumber because of the slippery texture. The chef mentioned he soaked the sea cucumbers for approximately one week and changing out the water everyday. It turned out soft but yet slightly crunchy. Not bad! I might have a new found interest for sea cucumbers now. It's a must try.
author: Jen L.

description:
This is a Chinese restaurant that caters to Koreans. This is my GO TO restaurant when I want some good food! 

4 stars for their:

-cha zang myun (black bean paste noodles, very saucy and tasty even though it might not look so appealing) 

-jang pong (spicy pepper soup with seafood, noodles, and vegetables) 

-fried hot pepper shrimp (a MUST TRY dish at this restaurant! I ALWAYS order this dish every time I come here. So delicious!!) 

This a is golden spot in located in Japantown :)
author: Amanda R.

description:
I was on the mission to Japanese cherry blossom festival. I was looking up places to go eat nearby, the reason why i don't eat at the festival is because of the long lines, spending a fortune, and nothing new i want from the festival food vendors. 

When i walked in here, i was greeted and sat down to the table with the nearest outlet. When i sat down, i was automatically given a plate of pickled spicy cabbage, in other words kimchee. 

I have decided to order the dry fry chicken wings, and jan pon which is spicy korean seafood noodles soup. 

Dry fry chicken wings $13 for 15 pieces of wings. I kid not, it was like never ending wings, as much as i ate. I had about 10 wings and i was so satisfied! i had save the rest for a late night snack when i am buzzed. The presentation of the wings were outstanding, colorful and appetizing. The wings were dry with light orangey red sauce. It had tons of fine chopped up garlic, sautéed onions, and chives mixed in with it. The chicken wings consist of mostly middle part of the wings, versus the little drum stick on the wing. It was worth the buck for this dish. Next time I'm just sticking with this dish only, because i was filled with just this. 

I also gave jan pin a try too. The presentation was steaming wonderful hot. The first sip of the broth i was not impressed, i felt like it was kind of bland. i had to spice it up with the table red chili, which wasn't too good. The noodles were ok, reminds me of soba noodles, but different. It consists a lot of veggies, mushrooms, some shrimps, clams, and slices of pork. I wasn't impress with this dish, and i don't think i will order it again. It was a big portion though. 

Overall service was ok, when i flag them down for water, boxes, or ticket, they were quick with it. The food portions was huge. The restaurant was clean and looks like a Chinese restaurant. I do like the little upstairs they have and in my mind i was thinking perfect for a uye party. Overall try the dry fry chicken wings because it was amazing. Thanks for reading and keep it saucy!
author: Alex T.

description: My partner and I came here to get the $45 special for two people. The amount of food was huge and realistically could of fed 3-4 people. The food was very nice and I particularly enjoyed the wonton soup. The aesthetic was quite basic and service was speedy but otherwise average.
author: Eliza G.

description: I've been coming to this restaurant since I was fresh out the oven. Love the food, love the owners, love the restaurant. Get the Jjajangmyun, dry fried shrimp, Tangsooyook (sweet and sour beef or pork), and the clams. So bomb. One time the owners daughter found out it was my mom's birthday and she secretly ran out down the street to buy her a cake. So sweet!
author: Chris F.

description:
When my family and I go out to eat we have at least 5-6 people with us at all times. This weekend we walked into San Wang's with a group of 12 without a call ahead and they accommodated on the spot. 

We really appreciated the fast service of beverages and large serving styles of food. We even order a large soup and they prepoured our bowls for us.

Overall, happy with the food and service as it was a quick warm dine-in on a foggy San Franciscan Day.
author: Kenneth J.

description:
My favorite place in SF so far for both korean-style jjajangmyun (here they're called noodles with plum sauce) and jjampong (and these are called san wang soup noodles). I have tried other places that had good one or the other, but so far San Wang is the only place I've been where I've liked both AND never has a wait! I've never had to wait in line unlike other places that are also good, but have a 40 minute minimum wait *cough cough* San Tung lol

Everything else I've had here has also been good - like  various meat dishes I can't remember specifically with rice or noodles or something. but if you want to get a soup appetizer I highly recommend the won ton soup! the small is actually pretty large and there's a lot in the actual soup. 

They do take card but there is a $20 card minimum which is helpful to know if you're ordering delivery or picking up an order.
author: Terra C.

description: My wife introduced me to this place when we first met over 20 years ago.  Still the best around.
author: Ken F.

description:
Great tangsuyuk (sweet and sour pork or beef that's deep fried)! Ja jang (noodles with black bean sauce) is also good. 

Used to drive here from Davis to get Koreanized Chinese food. 

Restroom is a spacious one room deal. Very accessible. 

Seating area is mostly wheelchair accessible, depending on how crowded it is. Second floor seating is not. 

In Japantown. Across from Daiso.
author: Esther L.

description: Not as good as the reviews say. Jajangmyun (black bean sauce noodle) was delicious. Chicken wings are not even comparable to San Tung's - they use a completely different tasting sauce. The wings here were not crunchy or crispy. We also got the fried rock cod with ... Some sweet black sauce. WAAAY too sweet. Too expensive for what it was. Got the boiled dumplings. These were OK. But they seriously came out way after we finished our meal... We asked about them several times and I just don't understand why it took the longest to come out. Don't think I'll be back...
author: Susanna C.

description: We were a party of 8 and just wanted to sit down and have a nice time eating food, but we learned there was a minimum we had to order. It would have been fine, but the waitress told us in a very rude and aggressive tone. The waitress we had was very rude to us even though we were there for only 5 minutes.  Because of her aggressiveness towards us, we decided to pay for the tea we drank and just live, but apparently the tea was $10 for not even a cup of tea. The tea was not even good quality tea. The tea given was very watered down.
author: Allen S.

description: The best noodles in San Francisco. On cold days, our family also enjoys the soups. They have a wonderful selection of soups and dishes that really stand out to make an impression. My father has been bringing his friends from out of town to San Wang for years.
author: Thomas Chase Leo S.

description:
Highly priced for a decent joint.

Looking for some food around 10pm and not looking to go too far from where I was staying I found San Wang. I ordered General Gau's chicken & a side of Fried Rice which came to $27 and change. For the price paid there was very little value. The General's chicken was very tasty and this review may be a bit higher if that was all I ordered, but unfortunately they did not offer a combo dinner meal. The fried rice had little to no flavor and was far from appetizing. 

There are a ton of food places in this area, I would recommend checking out elsewhere if available.
author: Brendon R.

description:
Just revisited this place in Summer 2015. Must have eaten here when they first opened decades ago, plus their other Richmond restaurant (now closed). They were famous for their hand-crafted noodle demonstrations.

Favorites include anything "dry-fried", like chicken, beef, shellfish etc...They have a seemingly set salty sauce full of garlic, scallions, and dried red peppers.

So, the "dry-fried" dishes of food become monotonous, deep fried proteins tossed with brown sauce and picking out hot dried red chilies.
author: Dean L.

description:
Me and my family were walking.around japan town. My sister recommend this restaurant because her co worker rave about this place.
We walk in no one to greet us we sat down ourself. Everyone that came in before us  got to order their food before us ( mind that we came in first.) 
Hot sour soup= it had shrimp in it so i was surprise the soup.had flavor but didn't taste like sweet and sour soup.
Walnut shrimp= gross taste all.maynoise.
Combination fried rice= it was just okay.
Plum noodles= really good i think people came to order that dish i believe it's the popular dish.

Overall customer service sucks of course being a chinese restaurant what can you expect right.
author: Hoa T.

description: My Dad's favorite San Francisco restaurant. He's been going there since the day they opened their doors.  Their noodles are fresh.  The dry chicken wings are good with rice. The kimchi is flavorful with out the burn. The plum sauce noodles is a favorite of my Pop's.  The Owner has been always nice since day one that I can remember.  The staff is always polite and nice. My favorite restaurant in the world.  I call San Wang, home.  Enough said.  Just go with friends & family and enjoy one of Japantown's longest surviving restaurants. 4 decades of fantastic food.
author: Nelden D.

description: My brother-in-law was feeling nostalgic about this restaurant that my wife's family used to frequent in their younger years, and so had his parents buy some take-out to have at his place.  I was surprised by how bad it was - typical over-gravied, over-cooked Chinese food for non-Asian crowds.  The dry-fried chicken and clams were okay; the broccoli beef, green beans and black bean noodle dishes were soggy, mushy messes.  I realize that a dine-in experience may have been better (though we did eat the meal within a half-hour of when it was cooked), but as it was - meh.  I can't understand the comparisons to San Tung as San Tung is at least two rungs above in taste and quality.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Roommate wanted black bean sauce noodles so we stopped by San Wang on the way home. I had never heard of the place, but he used to come here with his family when he was little. Since all his parents eat when they go out is Korean Chinese food I thought this place must be good!

Dry fried chicken: Crispy, garlicky and spicy. It was missing a little of the sweet sauciness that San Tung's wings have, but I enjoyed these. Sooo much that I just kept eating them even though I was getting full!

San Wang soup noodles: Loads of seafood and meat! And the soup was nice and spicy.

Noodles with black bean sauce: I had a bite of this. I don't love black bean sauce, but the noodles had a nice chew to them. Roommate seemed to enjoy them!

So the roommate's parents are right again! When I'm too lazy to go to San Tung, this is a great place to get my Chicken wing and Soup noodle fix!
author: Elena N.

description:
Mmmm delicious Chinese food smack dab in the middle of Japantown.

Relatively empty on a Wednesday night, with fast service and friendly waiters.

GET:
San Wang noodle soup: This is pretty much a combination noodle soup, with seafood, beef, veggies, and all sorts of goodies. It's a little spicy and BIG. Next time I'd ask them to make it extra spicy ;)
San Wang clams: pricier dish ($17) but large portions and HUGE clams. Get the spicy option.
Dry fried chicken wing: sort of like the chicken wings you get at San Tung, but less saucy. However the chicken is juicy and succulent.

Minus one star - the dishes lacked a savory component that I was looking for. Also a little pricey for a Chinese restaurant.

Regardless, I'll probably come back for more clams!
author: Michelle L.

description: The food isn't as good as I remembered it to be back when I lived in SF but I still liked it, nothing tasted bad. We usually get the sweet and sour beef and this time it was a bit more battered which I prefer the light crispy better. Like I already wrote, the food is good.
author: Gina Z.

description: Great large portions I came in here by myself since I'm new to the Bay Area and was very well pleased with my portion size and flavorful taste. I ordered the large Won Ton soup for myself since usually large means average and was well surprised with the gigantic bowl filled near the rim of large shrimp, mushrooms, won tons, and other mixed veggies.
author: Marc G.

description: Have been coming to San Wang for years.  Even when I moved out of SF, I drive up from penninsula for the outstanding Chinese-Korean food.  THe ZhaZha mein and Jampong are fantastic.  Also the dishes are terrific - shrimp dumpling, clamw/ black bean sauce, seafood medlee, green beans with spicy sauce and so forth.  Never to miss!
author: John R.

description:
Stumbled upon this place by accident with a friend who lives nearby. We were headed elsewhere in Japantown for dinner but when passing the window there was a large party at the front table which was packed with some gorgeous looking dishes. Chinese food in Japantown? COUNT ME IN!
So far we've loved everything we've tried: the hot and sour soup (nicely peppery), Mongolian Beef (not the nice sauce I get at my other fave spot but pretty and tasty), Noodles in Plum Sauce (something that sounds so plain yet is packed with delicious bits of shrimp etc.), Dry Fried Chicken (nice and crispy flavorful wings), Lemon Chicken (since they didn't have Orange Chicken), Eggplant with garlic sauce...shall I go on? Walkable distance from my place so it's also where I've gotten my takeout the last 2 Christmases. Good portions, reasonable prices, beautiful presentation and yummy flavors! I'd bump it up to 4.5 stars if I could but since I save 5 stars for UNBELIEVABLE, 4 it is.
author: Bob S.

description: Not many Korean Chinese restaurants in the area, so this would be a good choice if you crave jajangmyeon (black bean sauce noodles) or shrimp with hot pepper sauce. My friends and I thought both of these dishes were really good, better than San Tung. However, the water dumplings we got tasted average. Don't order the walnut shrimp; I've definitely had better at several other restaurants. They give you a bit of kimchi when you first sit down, but you'll need to flag a waiter down if you need to add water to the teapot - typical Chinese restaurant service, which doesn't bother me as I care way more about the food.
author: Diana C.

description: Came from Redding to visit family in Cal Pacific hospital. This was a short walk away in Japan Town. Food was pretty good. There was a little bug floating around in the low sodium soy sauce.
author: Michael B.

description: Really really good food!! I would've never probably never tried this place if it wasn't for my friend. The restaurant is owned by Koreans but they serve more Chinese food than Korean.  My tip for you is to come during lunch because their lunch portions are very generous and a lot cheaper than ordering a la carte.  My friend and I ordered the shrimp in spicy sauce and the fried chicken lunch that came with kimchi, House soup, and a hefty serving of rice. Both dishes were amazing!!!! Their wings were so addicting, sweet with a little kick, and the wings do have a lot of meat on them! I almost prefer these to San tung. I would definitely come back again to try their plum sauce noodles that I saw everyone was ordering
author: Linz C.

description:
I tried their noodle soup and it was the most bland noodle soup that I have ever had in my life. They also took a while to prepare it. When I asked the waiter how long it took he said that it should be ready soon, but I had to wait another 10 minutes. The broth tasted like plain water and I don't think they added any seasoning. The kimchi wasn't too awful, however.

For the price (or even less), I could have gotten much better food at another place.
author: Jimmy W.

description: I only eat in places I really enjoy, except under group pressure. I've been eating at this place for about 40 years and now I remember why. Everything is delicious! No this is not San Juan, but a Korean style Chinese restaurant located in Japantown.  We devoured the water dumplings, seafood noodle soup and almost the accompanying scissors. Next came the spicy clams and then the eggplant with mushrooms. We all tried to remember the first visit here. Well, there were also great looking private dinners going on at the roundtables with special sushi and wine. Complimentary cantaloupe at the end was a great dessert. Why not five stars? Get out the wipes.
author: Fred  D.

description: food was alright. wings were good!!! until i saw a rat running across the floor if the restaurant!! seriously?
author: Monica L.

description:
I wouldn't recommend Jampong( San wang noodle).
It's tasteless and not authentic at all.
author: Adam C.

description:
I typically don't go to Japantown for Chinese food, but after trying San Wang, I just might have to do so more often! San Wang is a Chinese/Korean restaurant in the middle of J-Town that serves up some very tasty dishes. San Wang definitely surprised me tonight with a very satisfying dinner experience.

The idea to give San Wang a try actually came from my mom. Her friends recommended it to her and she wanted to try it. I was game, so we went ahead and went in. The dining room is definitely adequate and clean. We were seated right away amidst a decent amount of people for a quiet Monday night out for dinner.

Looking at the menu, you might think the cuisine is American Chinese food, but it certainly isn't - it's authentic. We ordered a few dishes, and when they came, we saw that they were unique and portioned generously. I say unique because I feel that San Wang has their own style of preparing 'standard' dishes in a way that isn't typical of other Chinese restaurants. It's a bit hard to describe, but I can say that the dishes at San Wang are both familiar and different enough to pique your pallet's interest.

Each dish was seasoned perfectly and piping hot. We had quite a bit leftover to take home and have for lunch or dinner the next day.

In terms of service, the staff was friendly and attentive. We got what we needed very quickly, and they helped us box our leftovers up. The bathroom facilities were clean too! A lot of times Chinese restaurants tend to have below cleanliness standards in the bathrooms... but San Wang was nice and tidy. I really appreciate that in a men's restroom!

San Wang is a solid restaurant if you're craving some Chinese food done well. It's quite a few notches above average, but isn't the best of the best. But that's not what I'm expecting here. San Wang is a restaurant I would choose to go to on any given night!
author: Luke C.

description:
For those reviewers who are writing negative reviews stating this is not authentic Chinese, you are correct! However, it is not supposed to be, it's a Korean restaurant that serves the Korean interpretation of Chinese. Don't come here to order kung pao chicken or Mongolian beef, it will not be as good as your fake neighborhood take out. 

You come here to eat the best jjajangmyun (black bean noodle), tangsooyook (sweet and sour beef) and champong (spicy soup) in the city!

The service was fine and the restaurant was not that crowded whilst eating a late Sunday lunch. The food was fine except the tangsooyook was a bit over-fried for my liking. Will definitely go back!
author: Richard L.

description:
I am amazed at the poor reviews this restaurant gets.

This has been my family's favorite restaurant for Sunday dinners for years. There are many specialty dishes here that I believe are sub par if ordered anywhere else. And just to clarify, this place is not a traditional Chinese or a traditional Korean restaurant. It's a unique and delicious blend of both, and is pretty much it's own genre of Asian cuisine.

A personal favorite is the chicken wings. This is really one of my favorite dishes ever and I enjoy these so much more than San Tung. They are smothered in sauce/green beans that is just to die for, yum. Other favorites are the fried shrimp, fried beef (tangsooyuk), green beans, clams in black bean sauce, and sizzling rice soup. It's best to eat here family style and order all of the above! 

A paragraph needs to be devoted to the jajangmyeon at this place. In all honesty, it is my favorite place to get jajangmyeon. There is so much flavor and the sauce is loaded with so many goodies like shrimp, onion, etc. When you finish all the noodles, you could mix this sauce with rice. Honestly, you could do this with ANY sauce at this restaurant.

My family enjoys everything at this restaurant down to the kimchi they serve beforehand (not typical Korean style, but so good!). The service is good, especially now that my family and I are regulars.

Seriously, this is a place that never disappoints me and my family. Perfect flavor, huge quantities, at a reasonable price. You should definitely give this place a visit if you're a fan of (overhyped) San Tung and their chicken wings.
author: Greg J.

description: As soon as me and my wife walked in,  we were greeted by the server and was seated immediately. This is not a traditional Chinese restaurant, it is a Korean-Chinese restaurant.  The place is not that big but it had about 20 tables and chairs.  The server came to us after few mins and we ordered beef tan soo yook , jjajangmyun and jampong. The beef tang soo yook is hot and crunchy. Jjajangmyun is cooked to perfection. The noodles is cooked well and the sauce is delicious. Jampong is spicy but not to spicy. This dish is delicious. Parking is not good.  You have to find street parking.
author: Albert K.

description:
Food portion was awesome! We ordered a little too much. We ordered the dry fried shrimp, twice cooked beef, a noodle dish, fried rice, and dried fried chicken wings. Our total was close to $80 but like I said, the portion was well worth it. It came with Kim chi and hot tea also!

The reason why I'm only giving 3 stars is for customer service. I felt like we were rushed to order. We didn't get a "welcome/how are you", all we got was "have a seat here because there's a big party coming in", and there wasn't. Never once did our server come see if we're doing OK, or even offered us water or any other drinks. The only time we saw her was when she noticed we were done eating, to bring us our check and packed our left overs for us. One of the other server had her eyes stuck on the tv also.
author: Dixie x.

description:
Wasn't too keen to eat at this place cause I thought it was Chinese food, but my dining partners wanted to eat here for lunch.  Opening the menu was a surprise, since there were Korean dishes.

We ordered the San Wang Soup Noodles for each of us, and what a big portion it was for the price.  I couldn't finish my bowl.  It had basically everything you wanted if you didn't know what you wanted to eat.  Noodles, seafood, meat, and vegetables.  And topping it off was 3 pieces of chili since I wanted mild spice.  Noodles were soft, soup was tasty, and the rest was so filling.  But the meat is nothing to rave about.

Service was quick and helpful, although there was one waitress in the beginning that wasn't too friendly since we wanted her to wipe down the table.
author: Karen L.

description:
This IS the go to place for me when I'm anywhere close to Japantown.  I remember coming here even when I was a little kid with my parents, and it's still here!  The second floor of the restaurant is usually now closed off unless you have a party of 15 or more, but generally it's never too overcrowded, especially on the weekdays.

If there are any dishes you MUST try, I would go with the fried chicken wings and the spicy clams.  I don't know what ingredients they put in the sauce, but give me a spoon and a bowl of rice and I am a happy camper!
author: Kevin C.

description:
One of the best Chinese restaurants in the city. I have been coming here since I was a kid (30+ years) and it looks almost exactly the same. Most people come to J-Town for Japanese food, but I come for this place. 

Things to order:

- Dried Fried Chicken (you can order tofu it's not on the menu)
- Combination Fried Rice
- Mongolian Beef or Chicken
- Hunan Beef 

What not to expect:
- fine dining
- parking sucks

Come to Japan Town and eat great Chinese food.
author: Nino P.

description: Really a 3.5 but I rounded up. Went here with my coworkers after work and ordered the chicken kanppunggi, jajjangmyun, jampong and tan su yook. Everything felt fatty and pretty decent, but not that amazing. I didn't realize the kanppunggi had bones and it's actually more of fried chicken than kanppunggi that I'm used to. I wish I had gotten the shrimp one instead.
author: Juliana P.

description:
Service is bad.
Ordered pork and mushroom .
Came out in 2 mins luke warm.
Chow mein is bland and taste the grease.
Chicken wings are good but that is what gave it one star.
Not Chinese not Korean ... Not sure what it is... North Korean ??? Border China ?? That is the only style I can think of. I haven't had bad Asian food in a long time and I really regret coming here. Of all places in japantown this is bad!!
Oh the prices are extremely high for Chinese Korean !!
author: Alison W.

description:
Even though I'm Chinese, unlike my parents who are obsessed with the "authenticity" aspect of Chinese food, I love venturing out to try different interpretations of Chinese cuisine. Indo-Chinese, Japanese-Chinese, Filipino-Chinese, Chinese-American (think your average "lemon chicken" takeout and Panda Express), and of course Korean-Chinese. I'd say out of all the renditions I've had so far (Chifa/Chinese-Peruvian you're next), Korean-Chinese is definitely my favorite and I crave JaJangMyun all the time! 

Nowadays, whenever the fiance and I go to Japantown we always pick this place over all the other over-priced "Japanese"places in the area. That being said, San Wang definitely has the best Jajangmyun in town (better than Zazang, Tong Soon and that Korean-Chinese place in Lawrence Plaza that is now closed). Portions are good for the price and the sauce is not watered down like some other places. The sauce itself has the perfect balance of sweet and savory and there's always an abundant amount of sauce with every bowl of noodles. Their tangsooyook (think sweet-n-sour pork without the horrid food coloring) is also solid. Big portions and none of that overly fried, dry-ass, fat and dough-filled dingleberries they call "meat" at some Chinese places. 

Definitely a thumbs up from me!
author: Mona H.

description:
Small wait on a Friday night. This was my first real meal for the start of my SF visit! We didn't expect to dine here until a friend's family was nice enough to invite us out to eat with them! Great family-style restaurant. I wish I took some pictures but I didn't want to be rude and interrupt our great table conversation. The most remembered dish of the night for me was the fried scallops! They looked like tatertots. The chefs are generous with the protein in all their dishes and keep a good balance between veggies and meat. 

My dad is a cook and specializes in Chinese food so I neverrrr crave Chinese food, but this has definitely re-awakened my tastebuds to chinese food! From what we have heard, this restaurant is on par with San Tung, which is also an SF Chinese food foodie attraction for their chicken wings!
author: Linda L.

description:
This is the most convenient place for me to get jjajangmyun.  This is the only thing that I order.  And the cabbage kimchi is not bad.  OK, who am I kidding, it really hits the spot for a kimchi-starved Korean like me.    

Service is not bad, and the food is consistently good.  Can't wait to go back... have another jjajangmyun hankering.   

Parking is very doable by street or garage.  Cross the street to get a dessert at Belly Good Crepes or Andersen Bakery.
author: Miran C.

description: Okay Chinese food. I ordered pork with garlic sauce. It was really bland. This plates were a bit dirty. $20 minimum for credit card, which they didn't mention anywhere. I don't think I'd come here again unless other restaurants in Japan town are closed.
author: H M.

description:
This Korean Chinese restaurant is probably considered decent for SF standards.  Just to clarify, this is NOT a traditional Chinese restaurant.  There's a separate category for these kinds of places and should be logged under Korean Chinese cuisine. That is why they serve Kimchi. Usually, it's not the usual Korean kimchi.  The twist is, that they don't use napa cabbage but the green one.

We had the jellyfish,  sweet and spicy beef (tangsooyook), clams in black bean sauce,  San Wang fried rice, sizzling rice soup and spicy shrimp (kkanpoong shrimp). 

All the dishes were underseasoned.  They could've used some salt. If they had,  the meal would've probably been much better.   At least it wasn't salty,  I suppose. 

The clams in black bean sauce tasted different than the usual ones you get at Chinese restaurants. maybe this is supposed to have a Korean twist? It tasted like some sauce with gochujang (red pepper paste) in it.
author: Heejin L.

description:
Pleasantly suprised at this restaurant that serves Korean food cooked by Chinese in Japantown! It's like all of Asia is coming together, right now, over me.

We came at 11:30 on a Wednesday, plenty of metered parking outside. I swear I've been to Japantown hundreds of times in my life and walked this area all the time and never realized this place existed. I came wanting to taste the chicken wings that were, according to various local circles, "better than San Tung"

We walked and were greeted right away, lots of empty tables when we got there but all were full when we left. Straight away I ordered the Fried Chicken Wings, jajengmyeon (noodles with black bean sauce), and rice. The food came out relatively fast and we were eating within 15 minutes of ordering

The Fried Chicken Wings come like 12 to an order and are tasty but not like what I imagined them to be. They aren't glazed like San Tung but are deep fried then bathed in a sauce of garlic and something that gave it some heat.

The Jajengmyeon were good, but this didn't blow me away.

Overall I thought that the food was good and the service was great but maybe because people hyped it up like it was a must eat, i was a little disappointed.

That being said, the I would come here again.

tl;dr Chicken isn't San Tang, but come here if you want some Korean food in Japantown
author: Ray R.

description:
Size of portion: 10 out of 10
Everything else: 1 out of 10 and that's being generous.

We ordered the twice cooked pork which was too sweet. The pork made up about 15-20% and the rest is vegetables. The Szechuan beef tasted like deep fried beef in some kind of honey sweet sauce. The beef is coated in flour and deep fried. What you think is beef, is actually bundles of just flour, deep fried. Yup. Can't tell how much beef there was in that dish. I'd say only about 10% beef and the rest is flour batter deep fried. And even those were tasteless. Epic fail.
author: L T.

description:
Skip this place. Flavors were bland, soup was gross. Inside the teapot was all loose tea floating around. It was so bad I wrote this review in the restaurant.

Server told us we were ordering too much food too and made our friend feel awkward for wanting two entrees
author: David A.

description: Whenever im craving chinese korea. I get the korean sweet and sour pork. JaJangmyun noodle, black bean clams. The chinese kimchi is good, I eat a ton of it.  I honestly like this place better than the famous one on sunset only because I grew up eating this type of chinese korean a lot and I enjoy it better. The chicken wings are alright. I wouldnt get it there.
author: Barry W.

description: Food is great and service is decent. I always come here when I visit SF. I recommend if you like Korean-Chinese food. The spicy shrimps not that spicy but still delicious
author: Phil C.

description:
It's one of the closest Chinese food joints to CPMC.  I was on a mission to satiate grandma for lunch.  They didn't have her favorite bitter melon dish.  So I settled for some chicken fried rice and chicken chow mein.

For lunch, the total for my take out came to about $20.  I was pleasantly surprised once grandma and I sat down to eat though.  I hate greasy Chinese dishes and her even more.  Both dishes were grandma approved!  I was happy since she's picky.  Our rice and chow mein was both loaded with large, juicy morsels of chicken and a nice variety of veggies.  They also took it easy on the soy sauce and salt- even better.  

This is good Chinese food, and they even have a decent sized dining room which is clean to eat in too!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Pros

Szechuan beef
Garlic chicken
Dry fried scallops
Dry fry green beans

Cons

Not as good as before
Raised prices.  Some dishes almost doubled
Lack of service

This place was better with old owners. Place is cleaner now with new furniture and carpets 
Still good place for Chinese Korean food.  Rare type fusion
author: John L.

description:
I've eaten here for many years and they have THE BEST noodle dishes anywhere! I now live in the south bay and try to drive up when possible since there is no place around that still makes hand pulled noodles or dishes that taste so authentic.

I hope they always will be around because truly, no substitute to be found!
author: Benjamin B.

description:
Getting Chinese chicken wings in JapanTown, whatcha expect?

The Chicken Wings 

Smell: 
WOO! The smell certainly hits you first. Probably the best part of the dish was the smell. A very spicy and tangy smell that lingers on in a good way. Definitely a great way to whet the appetite.

Taste:
The best part of the wings were the chillies, spices, and green onions that were generously smothered all over the wings. It enhanced the flavor ten-fold. But, the reason they were so awesome was because the chicken itself lacked flavor on its own. A little dry and crispy. Nothing special. To be fair, we only tried their wings...

tldr;
When in JapanTown, try Japanese food.
author: Matthew S.

description: Come travel to San Francisco, I visited here in seattle. Go and eat jajangmyeon champong. Especially recommended. It goes too delicious to eat well.
author: Garam P.

description:
San Wang is my favorite delicious down-to-earth restaurant where I go to for jagjangmyeon (black bean noodles), seafood noodle soup, dried fried chicken and San Wang Clams. If you are a foodie and love Asian food this is the place to go!  Love garlic!  It's here!!  Love noodles!  It's here!!  Love seafood!   It's here!

Daiso is across the street so shop and then have a delicious meal and relax at Sam Wang.... The new spa is couple doors up the hill so eat at Sam Wang first and then relax at the spa. 

San Wang has been a long-standing SF neighborhood business for 40+ years.... The owner is a wonderful gentleman who has put his heart n soul into creating a well-establish restaurant that is open 7 days a week!!!
author: C C.

description:
This place has very good food but I don't think it's worth the hype. 
The chicken is very good, and made well but its like a Korean chicken, and getting elsewhere has very little difference in terms of how good it taste.
author: Timothy C.

description: Great jjampong!  Great jajamyung!  Brings back memories of eating lunch with the family after church in LA.  Need to try the sweet and sour pork next.
author: L Y.

description: This restaurant deserves 0 stars. HORRIBLE. Our waitress was beyond awful; she would disappear for at least 25 minutes and we had to hunt her down for more water. When it came time to pay, she said that she couldn't split the check and she made all of us take turns and go across the street to get cash. Also- the food was average at best. DO NOT GO HERE.
author: Madeleine B.

description:
This is a Northern Chinese restaurant with Korean leanings, meaning that it's kind of a fusion, and the menu does have Chinese and Korean writing on it.  It reminds me of San Tung Restaurant on Irving.

The 3 of us ordered these items (which turned out to be a tad bit too much for us, so we had some leftover chicken):

# Fried Noodles with plum sauce = "zha jiang mian" = "za zang myun"
- These seem to be standard.  Not the best I've had.  (The honor for that goes to Shan Dong in Oakland which sets a very high standard: http://www.yelp.com/biz/shan-dong-restaurant-oakland#hrid:7USD0JPUUshsTpjCJdxh3A/ ).  But also not bad by any means.  Nicely chewy, and the sauce is good.  I'd definitely come back for these noodles.

# Dry Fried Chicken - I think this is what San Wang is known for.  These are no where near as good as the ones at San Tung.  Our pile was mostly drummettes, with just one flapper.  (Most people seem to prefer the drummettes, but I really enjoy the flappers, since the meat is more tender.)  The flavoring was good, mild garlic and soy sauce flavor, but not as sweet as the ones at San Tung.  The part I didn't like was the breading.  It was a bit too thick and dry.

# Bean Curd Family Style - This was some fried tofu pouches (which were kinda mushy) with an assortment of Chinese vegetables, and a very lightly flavored sauce.

Service was good.  The interior and customers inside felt authentic.  It's pretty roomy inside, and they've got large tables .... great for groups.  Also, it's possibly the only place to get Chinese food in Japantown.  I'll come back for the zha jiang mian, but I'm going to try other dishes.
author: Jeanne L.

description: The food was amazingly terrible and it can easily piss you off. The review at yelf was not reliable this time. I ordered four dishes and none of them was eadable. It was very greesy and not fresh at all. I was so glad that my kid did not eat at all.
author: Ji J.

description:
As much as I love my friend, the rest of us have agreed to never let him choose a dinner joint ever again. 

Don't get me wrong - San Wang wasn't horrible but when you're living in San Francisco & amazing Chinese food can easily be found at every other corner, San Wang doesn't quite satisfy those taste buds. 
Their food was rather bland, everything seemed to just taste the same, & the beef was unusually chewy/rubbery. 
I'm sure they get a lot of tourists from being right in the heart of Japantown, so I don't feel TOO bad about giving this review. 

Anyways, aside from all that, the service was still really nice & happy to accommodate our big group.
author: Sylvia N.

description: Very Bland jjampong noodle soup (San Wang Soup Noodles) no flavor no spicy very disappointing. Won't be going back.
author: Sarah O.

description: Mediocre Chinese food with a bit of overpriced.  I wonder that by doing this kind of job what's the secret recipe of staying this business for a long time.
author: Piano B.

description:
The definition of two stars is "Meh. I've experienced better." And that's exactly what defined my lunch at San Wang. I'd always wanted to check it out because it looked like a nice place but I always passed it up for other restaurants around it. I think I will continue to do that. 

I got the lunch special which came with hot and sour soup. Unfortunately this soup was not hot nor sour. Just kind of ... MSG-y. Next up was the beef and beans. It wasn't terrible, but it was definitely meh. I've experienced better (see what I did there?).

When it came time to pay, I was told there was a $20 minimum for credit card. That's a little bit high, especially when lunch special items are about $8 each. So you're telling me that if two people come in and order a lunch special, they still don't have enough to pay with credit card? 

As far as I know, this is the only Chinese restaurant in JapanTown. Kind of unfortunate that they squander such potential.
author: Philip W.

description:
So I came here because my friends said that they had delicious food and so we came. This place is a bit of a fusion with Korean and Chinese but the taste is on point. We got there and ordered the chicken wings, jampong, jajangmyun, and clams. They were all very delicious and I would definitely come here again. 

Definitely get the chicken wings! If you are a friend of garlic this is for you. I love the sauce with it and the toss it around with some minced garlic and onions and it is just heaven. Be warned however that you will have bad breath by the end of this.

I loved the noodles for the jajangmyun because it had the right chewy texture. The sauce is okay it is a bit too sweet for me here but I would still order it again.

The jampong and clams were both good and very standard as well. At the end we were given pieces of watermelon as dessert as well. The service was great and the servers were very kind and approachable.
author: Angela S.

description:
Chinese Korean Food. 
Yes, that's right, this is a place where you will find Chinese food made by Koreans. The hybrid produced by this kind of alchemy gives you an awesomely good tasting Jajangmyeon. I've tried my friend's mom's Jajangmyeon, japagetti, and even the jajangmyeon place in Temescal where the price is right but San Wang's Jajang sauce takes the cake. The dry-fried chicken wings actually rivals San Tung's--yes I said it. 
Not a believer? Go ahead and try it for yourself! Better yet, don't because I don't want to wait in line and let's keep this place a better kept secret than San Tung.
author: Taffany H.

description:
DISCLAIMER: This review only applies to the Jja Jang Myun, which is the ONLY dish I order from here.

It comes in a large portion, served in a shallow bowl (which is different from the traditional large, deep bowl).  The noodles are always cooked perfectly chewy and the sauce is thick with both beef and shrimp pieces.  I have ordered it both take out and dine-in, and have been happy each time.

Although a Chinese dish, you can find it in restaurants that are Chinese/Korean, a specific type of restaurant that local Koreans and Chinese will appreciate.  I learned that the owner of the restaurant lives about 2 blocks away from me in the Richmond District, so of course I had to give it a try.  Fortunately, it was so good, I can't stop coming back and bringing friends with me to spread the word and the love.

Once I get the courage to try something else on the menu, I will re-post a diff review.

*There is also a super random "banquet room" area upstairs.  The stair case is in the back end of the restaurant behind the cash register... hmm...curious....  I went up there to check it out.. meh. Dark and looked more like a storage area.

San Wang will get crowded on the weekends, so if you can, try to come on a week day.
author: Elisha Y.

description:
Decided to give this place a try, though being in Japantown, why we didn't opt for a better-rated Japanese place is beyond me (I blame my brother who insisted on jja jang myun...)

Though we were early for the dinner "rush," the restaurant was completely empty and just old-fashioned in its decor. The 'fish tank' in the front was half filled with water and more like a seaweed/algae tank. That should have been enough to re-think the decision.

We went with the staples of jja jang myun (black bean noodles), tang soo yook, and kkan poong gi. The jja jang myun was very average.  The tang soo yook was too crispy in my opinion, lacking in the gooey sweet and sour sauce to soften it up. The kkang poong gi was just a bad choice altogether - it came out as regular wings with no sauce.  The seasoning on it was decent but the wings themselves were so dry.

Nothing was impressive except the old waitress who spoke Korean, Chinese, and English.
author: Lannie L.

description: Great food it's been over twenty years since  my last visit and it's still outstanding!  The dry chicken is still outstanding! And the service is outstanding!
author: Danny M.

description: Most ridiculous services! They pushed that dirty dish cart and bumped into me three time without even say a word; when asked to stop the guy pretended he is deaf. The plates are so dirty and the services are nonexistent. The price is very high for the crap they serve. Never again.
author: Woopie D.

description:
San Wang has been at this Post St. location in Japantown for many years.  I've been here for lunch and haven't had the opportunity to try their dinner fare.

Today we had:
Ja Jiang Mein (Noodles with Plum Sauce) - one of the better Ja Jiang Mein that I've had.  Noodles have a nice texture and the bean sauce was very flavorful.   

Chicken Chow Mein - a good portion order and that was quite tasty.  

Service is friendly and prompt.  Overall, San Wang is a good alternative to Japanese food in Japantown.
author: Al L.

description: The food comes so fast after you order it! Everything we ordered was very good. We got the san wang chow mein, garlic eggplant, Mongolian beef, and dry fried chicken wings. One of my favorites was the Mongolian beef which was stir fried with mushrooms and leeks! The best dish though was the dry fried chicken wings!!! Definitely order this chicken! It is so flavorful and good! Since it is Korean Chinese, kimchi is also served and it was yummy as well, and not too spicy. It was a great first dinner in SF after our long road trip! :)
author: Joy Y.

description:
This Korean/Chinese restaurant is tucked away in Japantown and I swear this place is always got good business every time I walk past it.  That's important because good business means lots of traffic means quick turnover of food (inventory) means the food has got to be fresh!  That's why seeing a sushi restaurant with bad business..... is most likely a bad idea.

Side story, this doesn't have anything to do with San Wang but when I was in Yan Tai visiting my wife's parents, I ate sushi at their Korean/Chinese restaurant.  The sushi was lightly frozen and sitting on top of ice.  Supposedly, that's how Koreans like their sushi which just made no sense at all to me.  Transition.... Jackie Chan meme....

Point of the story, good thing San Wang has no sushi.  I probably would not enjoy Korean styled sushi.

Honestly, I could ramble on and on about all the great dishes at San Wang and what large portions they provide for all their dishes.  But nobody would care to read such a long ass review.  Everything is cooked with the right amount of flavour and not smothered with salt/spices/flavours that seemingly a lot of the teenies really like nowadays.  Taste the food..... not the flavour.  They'll understand as they grow up.

Been there a bunch of times but some of things I gotta have are the sweet pork, jajangmun, spicy fried chicken, and the clams are delicious.  If I lived in the city, I would be there twice a month.  But I'll have to settle with Bonchon for now, for my Korean fried chicken.
author: William C.

description: Great Chinese restaurant. Friendly staff and good food. Stopped in randomly and was very impressed. I would recommend the eggplant to anyone. Best eggplant sautéed in garlic and mushroom sauce ever
author: Rusty T.
