description: Their dried chicken wings are the best in the city! Nobody comes close ( sorry San Tung). Their chickens are crispy on the outside, soft and tender on the outside. It's got just the right amount of pepper, salt and jalapeños. Sooo, sooo addicting!
author: Hoang T.

description:
Surprriiiiiiiise! This Chinese restaurant's menu has Korean subtitles. It also has some Korean dishes. It also had two tables of Koreans among whom I sat when I went. I don't know what Korean stew the person across from me got, but a person beside me got jjajangmyeon, and it was good. It had a few shrimp sitting in it too, as a bonus.

I myself got jellyfish because it sounded cool and because someone at my table endorsed it. When they said something about it being served with mustard, I didn't realize they meant the Chinese hot mustard. Those bites of mesoglea went straight to the back of my nose like wasabi. The texture and underlying flavor, if you'd call it flavor, were pretty mellow - simply something to try then say you've tried it.

What I didn't get around to trying from our table's Lazy Susan were chicken wings, some other preparation of chicken, dumplings, and maybe one other dish. Everyone at the table(s) seemed to like their meals. But after the stinging, breath destroying appetizer of coarsely chopped onions with black bean(?) sauce, all the entrees seemed demagnified in a way.

I heard there's sea cucumber, but I must've overlooked it on the menu. I'll have to get it and any other sea beasts on a future visit.
author: Dan B.

description: Must order the black bean noodle / jajangmyeon here. It's the best I've had in the city. Also, there's never a wait here, so you can come and get your jajangmyeon fix fast! They give you a lot, it comes out fast, and it's delicious. What more could you want
author: Derrick W.

description: hands down best dry-friend chicken in SF, and my favorite  chicken nit named churches. Dry-Fried, 2 orders every time! Fried crispy dressed with a sauce and minced garlic eww wee, not a place for a first date.
author: Kilo B.

description:
It feels to me like San Wang is a Korean Restaurant posing as a Chinese restaurant.  A lot of the food seems to be inspired by Korean dishes.  I mean they give you complimentary kimchi and raw onions with black bean paste.  What we ordered was also very Korean.  We got the jiajiagmyun and the dried fried chicken wings.  Both were good, but not outstanding.  The jiajiagmyun had good texture and the noodles were nicely done.  However, the sauce, although very good in concsstency and abundant,  lacked a little bit of flavor, just by a little though.  Same thing with the wings, although fried well and were good, they lacked that extra punch.  I don't know, maybe my taste buds are all screwy from all the spicy food I've been eating, but until proven differently I have to give it 3.5 stars.  

The Chinese food actually looked really good.  A table next to us ordered honey walnut prawns, and I had buyer's remorse!  I will have to come back here and try the Chinese food!  Sometimes you are better at what you intend to be than what you actually are.
author: Veasna H.

description:
San Wang has koreanized chinese food such as jja jang myun, jjam bbong, etc.  I walked into the restaurant not expecting anything special bc they have plenty of these restaurants in Chicago but I was blown away by how amazing everything I tasted was. A lot of reviews have mentioned that things taste different than they used to but this is my first time reviewing so I have nothing to compare it to.  THe following are the foods we ordered:

-jjam bbong
-eggplant with garlic sauce
-sweet and sour beef

All of them were seasoned so perfectly I coudln't stop eating even after my stomach was about to explode.  They definitely  don't make it this way in Chicago.
author: Karen K.

description: Perfectly adequate, and reasonably priced. I remember the food being much better at their now-closed satellite restaurant on Clement.
author: Jethro B.

description:
Unless you like jajangmyun (aka black bean noodles a la Korean style), this place is okay.  Having had fried chicken wings and garlic pork at San Tung or So, it's hard for this place to compete except that they are in J-town.  

Service is friendly, but it can take awhile to get water and/or noticed.  Parking is ample in the lots across the street at the garages.
author: Jenny L.

description:
The food here is horrible! All the familiar Chinese dishes did not taste the way they were supposed to. Everything was bland and all the dishes tasted the same. How do you make broccoli chicken taste the same as mongolian beef? I am perplexed. 

Never will I come here again nor will I ever recommend this place to any family or friend.
author: Gary C.

description:
If you think the dried fried chicken at San Tung's is good, then you must try the ones here! :D

What I love about this place is that it reminds me of the Chinese food I had when I  lived in Korea. The food here isn't your typical Chinese food, but more towards Shangdong or Schechuan flavors. If you know about the history of when the Shangdongese (Chinese) people immigrated to Korea during the war times, then you would really appreciate this place. This is exactly how the Chinese food in Korea taste like! 

My favorite dishes here are: Dry fried chicken, clams, sweet & sour pork, jajangmyun (black bean sauce noodle), and their salt & pepper ribs. The list can go on and on, but these are the ones I'd recommend!
author: Lily H.

description:
I really don't understand how anyone could like San Tung's jjajangmyun over the one here at San Wang...maybe its because I lived in Korea recently...but either Americans have a really weird sens of what is good jjajangmyun (bland noodles, watery sauce) or they have weird food allergies and still insist on going to  restaurants that serve cuisine that is rife with it and then complain...yes that idiot down there 

(in fact really he should avoid going to Japantown entirely...I mean an egg allergy and he GOES TO ASIAN RESTAURANTS???? he's just asking for it).

The jjampong here is the best in the city...which considerably isn't saying much because there aren't many places that serve jjampong but still...its more than satisfying.

But of course you'll get someone who will probably dispute this because they confuse another dish for the dish I am talking about....(sigh..very common with Korean cuisine in the bay area)

Honestly...when it comes to Korean cuisine in the bay area..I have ended up doing the opposite of what is on Yelp. Avoid any place with more than a thousand reviews with high ratings. especially if 60% of the reviewers are um....caucasian. or black. or malaysian. If they're Hawaiian...you can more or less trust it.
author: John K.

description:
I have been eating at San Wang for as long as I can remember.  This was my favorite restaurant growing up, and even as an adult, I compare all the chicken wings I eat to their dry fried chicken.  I have been told San-Tung has good/better chicken wings, but I have never tried it.  From my understanding, it is cooked differently.

The dry-fried chicken is just perfection.  Crispy outside, moist inside.  They then smother it with a garlic, green onion and soy based sauce that is a match made in heaven.  The wings are not greasy, surprisingly.  I can eat a whoel order all to myself!

They pretty much dry fry everything, but IMO the chicken is the best.  I also really love the sweet and sour whole rock cod.  Its so crispy outside, again moist and juicy inside.  It si pricey though, so I save that for special occassions. 

I have also tried their noodle dishes, and they are yummy.  They make their noodles in house.  The jajangmyun is pretty good, and so is the San Wang Noodle soup.  Has a nice spicy kick to it.  I also love their sauteed pea sprouts.

When I get a craving of dry-fried chicken, I make the trek from newark to Japantown.

It's amazingly funny when I take people to my favorite chinese/korean restaurant, we end up in Japantown.

The only thing holdng me back from 5 stars is the decor and ambience.  Seems like it has been the same way all these years.  Time to freshen up!  They have upgraded their restroom the last couple of years, so they are trying!
author: Raymund S.

description: Really good Chinese food. If you're near Japantown and want great Chinese food, come here. Also, the staff seems very friendly.
author: Beau B.

description: Great spot in Japantown. Recommend the Szechuan dishes and the Dried Fried Chicken. I'll have to try more when I come back around.
author: Andy G.

description:
The worst Chinese/Korean restaurant in the city.... yes, its pretty bad.

* the free kim chee appetizer was underwhelming.  I've had better kim chee from a jar... seriously!
* the chowmein, packaged noodles and with a bunch of random ingredients tossed together.. horrible
* Mongolian beef - the WORST Mongolian Beef I've ever had.  No seasoning on the beef and way too much green onions.
* Sauteed string beans- you would think this would be a can't go wrong dish, but naw.. they messed this up to with whatever sauce they added to the dish
*hot and sour soup.. tasted like packaged soup and they just added water
*Walnut shrimp.. the shrimp was good with good glaze and crunch, but the candied walnuts were separated on the side and ruined the dish.

Lastly service... nonexistent!
author: Emmett B.

description: Moving up from ktown LA couple monthes ago I crave these koreanized chinese restaurants, and their Jjajangmyun(black bean noodle) was pretty solid the couple times I went there.  Stick with the korean style, jajangmyun and tangsooyook(sweet and sour pork/beef).  It's like a fat korean kid's hamburger
author: James L.

description:
First time have Korean food, feeling good and having a lot fun here.........!
I order the two delicacy cold platter; walnut shrimp and noodles with plum sauce... Those were very good!!!!
author: Wenhao J.

description: The only restaurant I've found on the west coast to have sesame chicken the way I love it!
author: Larissa S.

description:
3.5 STARS. So I came to San Wang drunk. Very drunk. Yes I was able to question why there was a Chinese restaurant located in Japantown, but my friend told me they have great Jia Jiang Mein (I had no idea what that was but I was wasted so it sounded good to me)! We walked in and a friendly lady sat is down. I ordered the cashew chicken and rice, and my friend ordered the Jia Jiang Mein. 

I thought this was a Chinese restaurant, so when the lady brought us kimchi as a free starter, I was very confused. But my friend explained it was owned by Koreans? Okay. The kimchi was nothing like other kimchi I have had in the past. It was not spicy and didn't taste as fermented. I honestly didn't like that very much. When the Jia Jiang Mein and Cashew Chicken came, I was excited. Jia Jiang Mein is not on San Wangs menu, but it is noodles in plum sauce and onions?  I tried a bite of the Jia Jiang Mein and I loved it! Tried a bite of my cashew chicken and didn't like it. 

I'd come back here because the food is cheap, but next time I'll order the Jia Jiang Mein instead.
author: Emmanuella Z.

description:
Came to San Wang last Saturday to celebrate a special one year old birthday.

Many goodies were served at this luncheon such as deep fried chicken wings, steamed fish, rice, and a bunch of other dishes I don't remember because I didn't order.

LOVE LOVE LOVED the chicken wings! Will probably be back for a more intimate dinner.
author: Mabel Y.

description: Dry fried everything!!! Dry fried green beans, dry fried calamari, dry fried chicken, dry fried shrimp. San wang clams!!! Been coming here for 20+ years literally and they never disappoint!
author: Briana H.

description:
I have a bad egg allergy and made this very clear to the hostess and waiter before ordering. The waiter helped me order something that he said would not have egg in it. He even confirmed this 3 or 4 times! When my food arrived, it was contaminated with egg and I had a severe allergic reaction. Management did not accommodate my allergy at all and as a result, I became super sick!

Avoid!
author: Michael D.

description:
Their jjam bbong tasted like.... salt water. The large bowl came out piping hot, with all the right ingredients, smell and color. 

However, took one sip of the broth... and I thought, "wut?"

It didn't have any depth in flavor whatsoever. No msg? But even so... come ON. what's going on here?

I was sorely disappointed, and my spoon tasted and smelled like dishwashing detergent.

I tried to pay with my debit card, and they said I couldn't use it unless my bill was over $20. I said I can go get some cash from an ATM. 

The lady said indignantly, "I'll take it this one time, but make sure you have cash next time."

Ah yEEee Lady, there won't be nO NEXT TIME Okay. 

Again, another miss on Korean Chinese food in San Francisco.... smh
author: Alexis P.

description: One more dish I like is noodle with plum sauce.... I hear that was traditional Korea food, good and health for all age of Americans and Asians.....
author: Jacky X.

description: This place used to be a solid OK but I'm downgrading to MEH. We found hair in the fried rice tonight and they didn't even say oops. Just "Cancel? Or you want another one?"
author: Cheri S.

description:
Cannot really say that I had ever tried Chinese Korean food before, so I was looking forward to this meal. MAN ALIVE - be absolutely sure you come with an appetite!

Walking in, San Wang resembles a usual Chinese restaurant. Florescent lighting, white walls, cooks clanging pots in the back, and waiters bustling all over the place. I was the first of my party for 9 that had arrived and luckily we called ahead for reservations, because the restaurant was quite crowded. Another group of 10 dropped into the restaurant without reservations at the same time I showed up. The waiter gave my table away because my other dinner mates had not showed up yet. Understandably, my group was placed a very cramped table. I think I sat at a 45 degree angle from the table to be exact. But seriously, I was ready to eat standing up if I had too!

Once everyone arrived we took some time and ordered 7 dishes. We were not told how big these dishes were, but just by looking around, I could tell these were massive portions. Someone at first thought that it would not be enough, but we were spot on with the order size. We started out with a large bowl of Hong Kong style Sizzling chicken broth soup. Then the food started coming out immediately. Ma Po tofu dish, sauteed pea sprouts (dau mu), dry fried green beans with chicken,  Jai Jiang Mein (a korean noodle dish), walnut shrimp, their deep fried chicken, AND a whole Hot Braised Fish (rock cod). The two highlight dishes here for me were the fried chicken and the dau mu. I have not had fried chicken that good since my days of living in Beacon Hill in Boston, Primo's restaurant. Not sure that these were actually Pea Pod stems per se, but they were really well done.

The service here is awesome. There was one younger waiter who was just buzzing around so quickly and on top of everything. For a group of 9, we were all completely full and each of us ended up paying only $15 dollars. Incredibly good value for the amount of food we ordered.
author: Michael C.

description: The best Chinese Korean restaurant in San Francisco Japan town The food was great surveys was a very good
author: Al H.

description:
Dried fried chicken wings, clams, chicken with string beans, beef with string beans, egg plant, cashew chicken, szechuan shrimp, and soup.

Went here with my coworkers today, it was a lot better than I had expected. My favorites were the wings and clams even though the clams were a bit too saucy for me and I love sauce. The soup was something that seemed like they threw in everything but the kitchen sink, not impressed. I am a bit sad that I didn't get jiajiangmyun, I saw a lot of people with that.
author: Kylie L.

description: Excellent bowl of noodle soup Jam Pong style, savory and spicy broth with sea food chicken and perhaps pork.  Very reasonable price.
author: Glenn H.

description:
Came back recently, and noticed how their food is still similar, not much has changed except their prices. Aiya! 

Anyways, good place in the heart of Japantown for Chinese food, go figure. :)
author: Bai Z.

description:
Such a bummer.  We used to love this place - this was our go to restaurant for clams, soup noodles...etc.  So excited to return and with very high expectation, only to be disappointed.  Nothing was up to par.

What we had:
hot braised chicken 
pot stickers 
san wang soup noodles
author: Gloria H.

description: I recently experienced this restaurant and drove the food back to Oakland, CA. It was pretty good actually. I had some commercial dishes like the dry fried chicken and the chicken  chow mien.  They were very tasty! I will probably go again
author: Nate C.

description:
Horrible Chinese food, I decide to give this place a try and I apologized to my friend. 

My san wang noodles's chicken has some white cream stuff on it and already my stomach started hurting....... Their dry fried chicken was ok but it was mostly bones. Their Chinese broccoli had way too much oils.

Never going back!
author: jasmin t.

description:
I've been going to this restaurant for the pat 15 years. 

My parents were coming here ever since they were in their 30s. 

Its been around for a long time, food is always good. 

They speak korean, chinese, english, its basically best of three worlds. 

jjajangmyun, by far the best in the city. 

every other dish that i've tried, i never was disappointed
author: Christine K.

description: I I had The Dry Fried Shrimp and it was a excellent choice for lunch my description is savory, crunchy, and delicious.
author: Sharon L.

description: I would give this 0 stars but there's no option. When we arrived the waiter told us to seat ourselves and gave us side dishes that consisted of onions, black bean paste, and kimchee. The kimchee was bland and didn't taste fermented at all. We waited for 15 minutes for a menu at one point I thought we were supposed to get it ourselves. Several waiters passed us multiple times and did not even say anything. The store was not full with customers or busy so there shouldn't have been an excuse. We raised our hands and I saw a waiter in the back doing nothing but standing there and looking at clean dishes. We finally got menus and had to wait another 20 minutes to order when everyone already had food and eating amongst themselves. We were about to get up and leave but they already set the side dishes there. He finally got our order, it was an order of black bean noodles (didn't even have it on the menu) and curry chicken. He also did not tell us that it didn't come with rice (curry chicken) which aren't the waiters supposed to tell us? The wait for the food was not long, it came about 10 minutes after we ordered. The chicken was bland and did not taste good, would rate it 1/10. The black bean noodle has shrimp in it which was a big surprise because it usually doesn't. The menu said there was a noodle with plum sauce and shrimp, maybe they mislabeled it? When we were finally done it took forever to get the bill. The wait times for things were ridiculous. When one of the waiters came back to get the black bean noodles boxed, he touched the inside of my bowl with his bare fingers touching sauce ect. That's so unhygienic is gross, will definitely NEVER come back here when I visit San Francisco again.
author: Nancy A.

description:
After my friend announced that this is his favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco, I had to try it.  I ordered the General Chicken, rice, and egg rolls.  I was going to order another dish, but did not have time to decide on a second item before the food arrived.  Thank goodness I waited to order a second entree!  The General Chicken was huge.  Enough for 2-3 gourmands.  The chicken was very good, with the crispest, lightest batter I've ever had, but the portion size was just obscenely excessive.   The lunch menu is not available Saturdays, so I had to order from the dinner menu which has an additional charge for rice.  A complimentary bowl of kim chee was served, so I should have skipped the egg rolls which were quite greasy and tasteless.  
I would come back for the fried chicken and kim chee, but not for the egg rolls.  I added a star for the very clean and spacious bathroom.
author: Emma Q.

description: Their food is so bland . don't waste your time. My bfs family decided to come here and we always do family style and we always order their main dishes. Everything was so bland except for the salt and pepper pork chops... I'd rather go somewhere else for pork chops.
author: Lyra C.

description: This is one of my very favorite Chinese restaurants in S.F. Been coming here for years. I love how they start you off with kim chee. It really complements the Chinese dishes. My favorites are the Dry Fried Chicken and the San Wang Claims. Talk about value, not only is the food delicious, the portions are large! This place is the bomb!
author: Athena S.

description: Everyone orders the Dry fried chicken.   Soup noodles are good too.
author: Shirley N.

description: The tangsooyuk and jajangmyung are pretty good here.
author: Julia P.

description:
Maybe because it's a Chinese Korean place, but this has to be my most favorite Chinese restaurant. I've been eating here since I was like 3 years old. Our church always comes here for large gatherings and since my dad is on the board I always tag along too. I'm sure if you're chinese this place aint gunna be that great. I mean I love Panda express, so that says something about my taste in Chinese food. I'm not into authentic Chinese flavors. This place is basically Chinese food you'll find in Korea like zzazzangmyun, zampong, tangsuyoot, etc. 

We ALWAYS order the same shit. Sachun beef, meh-woon seh woo, shrimp fried rice, and black and peppar shrimp. Omg I'm drooling as we speak. First off, you can feed an army with these entrees. It's pretty big. I say one entree is for about two people. 

Sachun beef and meh-woon seh-woo (shrimp) are both battered and deep-fried and smothered in sweet tang-su-yook type sauce. They both have chili peppers but they're both more sweet than even considered spicy. OMG seriously, unhealthy but sooo good. You mix the sauce with the shrimp fried rice and that shiet is heaven. 

Shrimp fried rice can't go wrong so I won't say much, but it's super light and not greasy, it's just perfection. Honestly I don't really like zzazzangmyun, but honestly it's not bad, but I don't like it in general so I can't say much for that either.

My mom is obsessed with black pepper shrimp. It's deep fried king shrimp covered in fresh garlic and black pepper and jalapenos. I don't eat it because it's literally the entire shrimp deep fried with eyes, legs, etc. But my mom and everyone LOVES it.

Anyhow, idk about quality or authenticity of the restaurant in terms of Chinese food, but for Chinese Korean Food I think San Wang is what's up. Everyone at my church loves it. I love it. My fam loves it.
author: Joyce L.

description:
So my first trip to San Wang was great.  This trip not so much,
We arrive, told to wait (even though there were empty tables but I understand that sometimes you just don't have enough servers). 

So even though we were first in line, after 20 minutes another couple was seated before us.  Okay, not going to freak out.  So we are seated and then several other parties are seated after us.  We are served menus, tea, and that kimichi like substance.  Then we sit and wait.  Everyone in the restaurant was served and orders taken.  We sat and sat.  We left.  I am not sure why they chose to ignore us, but I suggest you find another restaurant.  Don't eat here.
author: sean d.

description: The jjajangmyun is really good here. One of the best I've had in sf. However, the portion is EXTREMELY small. It is literally Peanuts. A snack. Cute. Especially for the price. I was able to finish it in two bites. And was not even half full.
author: Martin C.

description: I've been there several times and the food was amazing all the time! It has the best hot & sour soup I ever had!
author: A Cream Puff With Apricots D.

description: Every time we go to SF we eat at your place on Post. Last time we left SFO airport and went straight to your restaurant to order the Won Ton Soup. Like no other soup in the world. Plus we can eat well and walk for exercise around Japantown right after
author: Thomas C.

description: Been coming here since the early 80s. I totally love their dry fried (Chicken, Shrimp, Beef, Green Beans). Good selections and prices are very affordable. This is my go to spot when I am in J town.
author: Hideki M.

description:
Chinese/Korean food in disguise. I had to take a close look at the menu just to be sure it even had Chinese/Korean food. I guess the Korean writing gives it away. 

I'd heard that this place had some good jiajiang mein (black bean sauce noodles). After looking over the menu, I couldn't find it. Turns out that it's listed as plum sauce noodles here. Hur? Luckily, when the noodles came out, they were actually very good. Probably one of the best versions in the city. Noodles were soft but not mushy, and the sauce was sweet but mixed in with a good onion and pork(?) flavors. I was pleasantly surprised, although I did think it was a bit weird that there are 2 or 3 boiled shrimp in there. The kimchee they serve here is also very tasty. 

Sadly, that's where the enjoyment in the meal ended. We also ordered the fried shrimp and the cashew nut chicken. Both were pretty bad. The shrimp were overcooked and tough. It was covered in a mish-mosh mixture of green onion, chili peppers, and garlic. The cashew nut chicken was even worse. The chicken was thinly sliced but had absolutely no flavor. The dish is stir-fried with green bell peppers and onions. At least the cashews tasted good. 

The service was ok, although they forgot to bring us a few things, and pretty much just stopped by to drop off the food. 

Meh. I would have given the place 2 stars if not for the jiajiang mein.
author: Saunders C.

description: My favorite Chinese restaurant anywhere. The chicken wings, noodles and broccoli beef is to die for. I come here at least once a week. The owners are VERY nice and gracious. I can't say enough good things about this place!
author: Shawn F.

description:
Quite disappointed in San Wang considering the restaurant is always busy. The food is subpar compared to other places that service the similar cuisine. We ordered the noodles with plum sauce, dried fried green beans, and fried chicken wings. 

The green beans were everything but dry. they were topped with gravy with mushroom. 

The noodles were extremely heavy and lacked in seasoning. The shrimp wasn't great quality and left me not wanting to eat anymore.

The chicken was fried pretty well and tossed with A LOT of garlic and ginger. Easily the best dish of the day!

Unfortunately, I don't think I'd ever come back unless I'm in the neighborhood and had the need to eat garlicky, gingery chicken.
author: Derrick H.

description: I normally love this restaurant and have regularly ordered the same items. I just received beef fried rice and chicken chow mein and they are terrible. Barely edible and some very cold bites throughout the rice and the beef tastes bad. Maybe there's a new chef or just a bad day but I'll be hesitant to order from this restaurant again when it had previously been my go-to.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Three things I like at this restaurant are the pot stickers, water dumplings (shrimp), and San Wang chow mein.

Two things I think can be further enhanced at this restaurant are better service to keep our tea filled when we ran out and fresher fortune cookies.

Overall, I think this restaurant is a good value considering how affordable it is to eat here.
author: joe w.

description:
It's a Korean-owned Chinese restaurant in Japantown. Yeah, I don't know.

We came here with enough people to fill two tables, so that's what they gave us. We had two adjacent tables near the corner of the restaurant closest to the door. Since we weren't all sitting together, we thought it'd be best to just order separately for each table because there were some items which one table liked but the other didn't, and vice versa.

I sat at the table which ordered second. Within a few minutes, plate after plate starting coming out of the kitchen for my table. The table which ordered first sat back and waited. Eventually every single plate we ordered came out, and the first table still didn't get anything except white rice. We felt kinda bad for them, since we ordered around just enough food for just our table so it wasn't exactly feasible to share our food with them. The waiter kept insisting that their food was coming.

By the time most of my table was done eating, the other table just started getting food. It's just ridiculous that the waiters would completely neglect one table of a two-table group.

As for the food, it was decent but not memorable. I heard the dried fried chicken wings were supposed to be good but they weren't even half as good as the ones you can get at San Tung.
author: Allen C.

description:
No matter how popular this place may be for some, all the memory I was able to take home was that it was the WORST customer service I've ever had experienced in SF for an Asian restaurant. 

I didn't mind the 30min wait in the beginning, but the fact that the servers were not attentive and won't even notice you was a terrible experience! They were so swift in placing the food on the tables, and swift to leave also before you even think of what to ask. They seriously will try not to notice you as they are determined to give out all the orders ASAP like a robot. It took a while to get a server's attention for water. It makes you feel like you don't exist. 

I certainly won't be returning here.
author: Erika K.

description:
Best Chinese food I've had in many years.  I'm definitely looking forward to my next visit!  

We were at the Kabuki for an SFFF show and asked a friend who works there if there's a good Chinese restaurant in walking distance.  She sent us here, b/c it's just 2 blocks up Post from the theater.  It was uncrowded & everyone else there was Chinese families.  

We ordered Garlic Scallops, which turned out to be deep fried but YUMMY, and sauteed chinese greens, which were beautifully cooked On Choy (Chinese brocolli).  Both dishes were different than your run-of-the-mill Chinese: the ingredients were super-fresh & high quality, they were perfectly cooked, and the seasonings were both more interesting & more subtle than usual.  

I would recommend both of the dishes we had, and look forward to trying new ones.
author: Jessica R.

description:
LOVE San Wang. 

I've come here a couple of times and have always been super pleased with the dishes. 

Last time I came here with a friend and we ordered the chicken wings (good, but a teensy better at San Tung) and Noodle Soup and dry fry green beans. 

THE GREEN BEANS WERE AMAAAZING. They were the best I've ever had. GET THEM AND YOU WON'T REGRET IT! 

The only gripe, well not gripe, but it's a little far to go and San Tung is closer. :/ Such is life.
author: Alison N.

description:
The review is for the Hot & Sour soup only. 

Almost all the ingredients are either canned or frozen, and while some might appreciate the lightness of this soup, I would have to say it's more tasteless than light. Hot & Sour soup is supposed to have a distinct tangy, intense flavor to it, and this was a very sad imitation of that. Also, have the owners changed? I remember coming here a couple of years ago and the management staff was different.
author: Jennifer W.

description: One day we were roaming the streets of San Francisco which we decided to give this place a try we ordered noodles with plum sauce and a order of dried fried chicken. Overall the chicken came out ok it wasn't what we expected as for more sauce. I also feel like the portion of the noodles were okay there wasn't as much flavor in the sauce.
author: Caitlin M.

description:
O-oo-o
Oppan gang-namseutayil
Kang-namseutayil
O-oo-O
Eh- sexy lady
O-oo-O
Oppan gang-namseutayil

Yes, it's Korean.
So, Pseudo Chinese?
There is nothing wrong for Korean to have Chinese restaurant in Japo-town.
There was something going on at the Japantown, I don't know what the heck was it but many people were walking around and most places were full house but here. That was the reason why we went in.
The food was OK.
Nothing bad but I have to say that "Meh, I've experienced better."
Because, I totally lost my appetite when a pigeon flew in the store.
3 time in a row. That was really fxxxed up.
It was disgusting.
I hate pigeon more than anything.
Pigeons are badasses! Always.

But, I know that it is not really fair for the place getting 2 star review because pigeon.
I understand the point, but 3 times? 
To me, that was it. I lost my appetite anyhow.

Every time a pigeon got in the store, fly around in there, the manager guy follow the pigeon out. But, one time, there was a lady who was a customer seating a table, when the pigeon flew right over her, she just smack the pigeon with a menu-book she was reading, the pigeon flew out of the store.

I like northern Asian food, That is how Northern China and Korean food are crossing over. 

But, so far, San Wang, I lost my appetite.
I have a right to tell you why I lost my appetite because the FXXXin' Pigeons!
Get rid of pigeons!
author: Nobu K.

description: Not going back. Food was priced ok. Not cheap, and not too pricey. Don't do the seafood spicy noodle soup. There was no flavor to it at all. Customer service is like any other hole in the wall Asian place... there is none to really expect. Lacked in flavor. Not a place I would return to or recommend.
author: Marlene T.

description:
Had dry fried Szechuan beef, had that a number of times in Szechuan restaurants in Beijing and Guangdong and was really looking forward to it. A huge disappointment when the dish was served: large clumps of relatively tasteless fried meat (instead of carefully sliced tiny pieces). The beef was not dry fried but covered with fried coating making it even less interesting. 

The spiciness was non existent, no wonder, the "chilies" were just thrown in the whole thing and not carefully cut to small pieces. The bill was higher than what was written on the menu, and there were lame comments by the waitress about that.

Maybe I picked the wrong day, after that I'd have a hard time to come back or to recommend this place. I gave the second star because they accept credit cards ;)
author: Zipo B.

description: I came here to try for the first time because I saw all the good reviews. I ordered chicken wings and black bean noodles. The chicken wings were pretty dry and the black bean noodles tasted really burnt. I didn't really like it. The service is really bad. I heard the worker complaining that my family and I ordered too little!! I'm never going back here
author: Rachel W.

description:
Great noodles, i always get the plum sauce noodles and san wang clams for groups and the san wang spicy noodles.

Recently they've been very expensive with their prices, or that's just cheap me who has been at san wang since their early days when a bowl of noodles was 6 instead of 8$. 

Also, 3$ for adding extra noodles, NOT WORTH IT but their noodles are so good. I believe they are hand-pulled. Just get another order! 

Will be sure to try the Dry Fried Chicken wings in the future. Been a regular since I was born.
author: michelle w.

description: I know San Wang is a classic Chinese restaurant that has been around for years, BUT I personally don't think their food is the best and their service was kind of ruff and not very polite.The amount of food they give you is So little and doesn't seem very fresh. the chair had something stick on it  between the cracks when i was trying to push my. I mean i know bits the cracks of the chair but its still gross when you touch it and you have all this weird sticky stuff on your hands. I don't think I would go back.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Great Chinese Food Here! Not too Oily & makes food fast & service is great!
author: Lisa S.

description:
What an interesting place. A Chinese place that serves kimchi, OB beer, and black bean noodles. I've lived in California--south and north--for 15+ years and haven't come upon this combination. And I'm Chinese and had a Korean girlfriend for a really long time..

Anyways, the food here is pretty competent with a taste that might surprise you. We had the hot & sour soup, salt & pepper fried calamari, a huge fried flounder, and some chicken + veggies. Everything except for the last one (and the kimchi appetizer) was gone by the end of the meal, which is always a good sign. I wouldn't call the food refined or revolutionary, but I'd go again. Plus it's so close to Japan plaza that it's a cool neighborhood...

service is okay.
author: Ralph L.

description: I love this place! Ive been coming here since I was a kid and whenever my parents want to go to lunch this is where I ask to go. My favorite is the dry fried chicken. So tasty and juicy. Their mongolian beef and dried fried string beans are the other two staples I always order. Service can be slow sometimes because of a full dining room but otherwise service is pretty decent.
author: Maria M.

description: Quick stop for a beer and quick bite. Free Kim chi was up first, hit the spot.  This was followed by some of the best  water dumplings I've found on earth. I want to return for dinner, I highly suggest a visit here.
author: Jeff K.

description: jumbo shrimp in hot pepper sauce--not really too spicy but oh so delicioso!!!!!
author: Neil V.

description:
Spicy fish is my favorite ! Deep fried with lots of garlic sauce.. even better soju :)
Too much food for one or two people but when we go with my family, we always get this..mmm
Not cheap either but worth it
author: Mike C.

description: San Wang totally brings back the childhood memories of hanging out in J-Town back in the days. This restaurant must have been here for at least 20 years (proud X-gener!)  This place is known for their Chinese Korean cuisine, the jajangmyun (zazang noodle) is still the best I can find in the entire CA, even better then some in Korea. I would love to suggest they serve "takuan" (yellow radish), that will totally make me feel like I'm in Korea doing home delivered take-outs! Their "gu-lao-rou" (sweet fried pork) is also 20+ years of authentic flavor(it's like a Chinese-Korean sweet-&-sour pork but with white sauce and lots of veggie). The portion has slightly gone down & prices have slightly gone up through the decades, but as long as their jajangmyun & "gu-lao-rou" stays the same, it's all worth it!
author: Leticia W.

description:
This place really sucks.  I ordered a Za Zang with beef because I had a really good one at Yuyu ZaZang.  Well, EXCUSE me! The waitress says sure we will make it, then I could hear her arguing in the kitchen with the cook.  

(all spoken in Chinese)
Waitress:  Beef, Beef, add the beef.
Cook: hum....
Waitress: Beef in the Za Zang! Beef, beef.
Cook: what?! beef?
Waitress: Yes, Beef.  You add it.
Cook: GRAAF, EWOW...

15 minutes elapse...

When my ZaZang with beef came, guess what? NO BEEF, LOTS and LOTS of onions and cucumber , not a bit of beef! The waitress apologizes and then comes back 5 minutes later with basically the same thing with maybe 5 tiny bits of beef.  During eating I get crackling pork skins and bits of mystery fat.  I also get charge $2 Extra for the beef! I am never coming back to this crappy restaurant ever again.

WARNING: DO NOT EAT Za Zang in the city, only in Oakland.
author: Jim J.

description: The service was fast but the food was OK. There was nothing too spectacular and that made me think "I wanna come back here to eat that again!" I agree with most of the reviews that the food was bland with not much flavor.
author: Michelle R.

description: Awesome place for jjajang myun!! If you order it, get the regular type over the stir fried (gan jjajang), it's way more flavorful! The champong is seriously delicious too.
author: Terry K.

description:
My #1 favorite Chinese-Korean restaurant in all of Northern California.

Cheap/Reasonable prices, huge portions, excellent quality of food & customer service. I don't know what more you could ask for. 

I'll just say that their Jja Jang Myun tastes better than many of the ones I've had in Korea or Southern California.  (FYI, I've lived in Korea)

Here's a brief list of some of my top fav's and I'd HIGHLY recommend them to anyone trying out this place for the first time

-Jja Jang Myun (get the "plate" kind..which is the upgraded versionn has larger portion with an extra veggie topping)
-San Wang Fried Rice (aka their House combination fried rice)
-Szechuan Beef
-Kkan Poong Shrimp

Rather than eating at other over-priced, not-so-authentic Japanese restaurants nearby in J-town, how bout giving this place a try? :)
author: Rob P.

description:
Definitely a disappointment.
Their signature dish is the dry-fried chicken wings. DRY? Definitely an understatement. Their chicken wings and drumsticks were pathetic. No meat whatsoever and there was more bone exposed than meat. The minimal meat that was there was more over-fried skin than meat, so it tasted tough and dry. It tasted like (over)fried chicken wings tossed in a soy sauce on a bed on diced onions and vegetables. 

Surprisingly their Sauteed Strings beans and their Shrimp In Black Pepper Sauce were quite good.
However, the shrimp in black pepper sauce was not what I was expecting. The shrimp was fried in a tempura style and had this spicy sour sauce that was reminiscent of a sweet and sour sauce. Don't get me wrong, it was good, but not what I was expecting from the description in the menu.

Would I come back again? I'll pass.
author: Jenna H.

description:
Wow this place is over hyped.  I was excited trying this place out after seeing so many 5-star reviews, but alas, yelp fails with this place.

I was struggling between either 2-stars or 3-stars, and decided 2-stars since I feel a 3-star restaurant should denote at least somewhat good, even if average food.  Everything at San Wang however was at best bland.

We went with the dry fried chicken, the zha jiang mien, and the steamed dumplings.

Dry fried chicken was dry (ok, I know dry is in the name of the dish, but it should be tender meat, crispy dry battered skin with a complimenting sauce).  The meat was just average, the battered skin was not as crunchy or tasty as expected, and the sauce was bland and minimal.  If you want real dry fried chicken, go to San Tung.

Ja jiang mien was also bland.  I'll give good marks for the noodle itself, but the sauce was overly greasy, and again very bland.  Maybe I'm basing too much off the Taiwanese version of zha jiang mien, but there was just no depth of flavor at all with this dish.

Steamed dumplings were forgettable.  The skin was too thick and dry, and was already breaking when it was served.  Again, it was bland, dry and flavorless. 

Cannot see how this place has so many high marks.  Only good thing was there was no wait here.

Maybe for good reason...
author: Tadd L.

description:
Service: horrible waited 15 mins for a table without any acknowledgment. There were plenty of tables. 
 Soup noodles where a lttle bland. Clams had a lots of shells without meat in it. But sauce was good. Noodle in plum sauce was delicious. The noodles were prepared perfectly. Will probably only return for that dish as a take out.
author: Jess H.

description:
I was in this area today because I was waiting in the LOOOOOOONNNGG line at the Chinese Consulate waiting to get my visa process going for a trip to China next month. 

Anyway, the Consulate actually closes from 12-1pm and they kick you out of the building, so not wanting to go far I just searched around Post St. for something that looked decent and fast.

Even though I was really craving Japanese since I was in Japantown after all,  I was short on time and looked in and saw a lot of Chinese people eating there and was sold. :)

The service wasn't rude, but they were definitely busy and rushed. We had to ask a couple of times for water but the food was excellent and portions were huge!

A lunch special of Beef and Broccoli, chow main noodles, and sweet and sour soup feed 4 adults and one kid. It was supposed to be just 2 adults and one kid but my in laws swung by and wound up staying with us. It seriously would have been too much food for just us 2 adults and a kid.

The food was fresh. They used real fresh mushrooms in the soup and I know that some places used the canned mushrooms.

Good value and good food.
author: Alexis M.

description:
For the record, the prices listed here are COMPLETELY INACCURATE! I was craving just broccoli with garlic sauce but wanted to try the San Wang Clams too, to see what all the hype was about them, especially since they were so cheap and the serving looked really hefty.

The clams are NOT $10.50  as listed on here but $14.95...big difference. And the shrimp and broccoli is also not $10.50... But $14.95 also! Guess that was my fault for not calling in to verify prices but I shouldn't have to if they are already advertised online. So a meal that should've been about 20 something bucks after tax ended up being $32.52 after tax! No tip because it was takeout. That was ridiculous for a meal that was just for me.

As pictured, the serving of clams was really generous and tasted pretty good. Pretty spicy because there were green bell peppers and jalapeños mixed in and it was hard to tell the difference between the two because they were cut the same. The broccoli and shrimp was edible... I say that because the shrimp was gross and over cooked... Way too chewy and it had a weird filmy taste on it... The broccoli was great (maybe because I just love broccoli lol) I may order the clams again but definitely not the shrimp. So 3 stars only because the clams were pretty good and the serving size was generous.
author: Nia N.

description:
This restaurant is a traditional favorite for many local families but on my recent return, I discovered their food quality and taste has plummeted to very low levels. 
We were a large group, and order several different dishes. 
Everything tasted so off the normal Chinese restaurant taste, I felt embarrassed for our friend/host who was trying to make the best of the situation  to help us have a good experience here. The food was just bad. People all around the table started looking to the left and right of each other to see the reactions of others as they ate their food. It wasn't just them- everyone's faces appeared like they couldn't eat anymore of what was in front of them.
The noodles were bland, the fried foods were like cardboard, and the sauces did a poor job of helping to flesh out any interesting tastes to the dishes.
I would not recommend this to anyone looking for good Chinese food emblematic of what San Francisco has to offer.
author: Bryan S.

description:
Only been here once but I liked their food a lot.

I was craving black bean sauce noodles and I was told by a friend that this place makes good noodles. So I went, and I came out very satisfied. Definitely try this place if you like Korean style jajangmyeon.
author: Steven L.

description:
great little spot in japantown for food.  never really have to wait, which is a bonus.  it's one of those restaurants where the waiter will come up within five minutes of you having sat down and said "what do you want? .... (fill in blank)... ok". then you'll have your food in like ten minutes.

try the dry spicy chicken.  fried very well and coated with a yummy soy, garlic sauce.  although this time, when we went, there was way too much garlic.  usually not an issue though, because they're big enough that you can pick it right off.  it's a fairly large platter and enough to share for four people.

follow up with the jajang noodles.  the noodles are really a highlight here because you can tell they are fresh and chewy.  the jajang sauce (black bean with seafood or pork) is splashed on.  just stir it around and eat up.

last thing, if you like potstickers, they make them fresh here.  the filling is pork and chive, slightly different from what i'm normally used to.  takes about 10-15 minutes to cook, but totally worth it.
author: Tina L.

description:
a group of friends lured me into going to SF for chinese food. coming from the south bay, this is 9 times out of 10 a bad idea. 
there just isn't much good chinese in SF, with a few exceptions in richmond and R&G and new sun hong kong (although i dont think i've ever eaten there sober). 
san wang is one of those utterly forgettable places. I was expecting maybe chinese fare with a tinge of korean influence, but instead all i got was Americanized Chinese food. the best dish we got was beef broccoli, which says something. 
everything was dripping with oil, the family style tofu, a chinese staple, didn't even closely resemble what it should be. the tofu was overly mushy, and the sauce didn't have any flavor and definitely did not taste like the very flavorful dish should. 
the only positive note was that they served tsingdao, and their service was relatively responsive (this is also usually a warning sign that the restaurant is not good).
author: Xander C.

description:
I have been here with my fam fam many times! It's a Chinese restaurant owned by Koreans in Japantown. Pretty funny. 

Seafood food here is yummy! Order seafood and you won't be disappointed!

Things you must try are: 

Calamari (deep fried squid) 

A whole fish with their delicious sauce

Service here is decent. Prices range depending from what you order, but it's nothing crazy. On average, I would say each dish is around 10 dollars. If you are ever in the area and wanna try Chinese food instead of Japanese food, come here!
author: Jeannie L.

description:
It's a Chirean restaurant.  Okay, Chinese/Korean. I went there.

I was hyped for the JJM here but a tad let down. It was a bit on the sweet side?? I've never had sweet tasting jja jang myun?? It was still acceptable in my book, just not what I have grown accustomed to. 
Dry Fried Chicken Wings are so so, I thought they needed a tad bit more sauce. 
I really liked the cold jellyfish because it had plentiful w/ slivers of cucumber. It made for great texture, crunch, and had that cooling effect. 
The spicy clams in black bean sauce weren't spicy at all, but the sauce is still good to mix with rice. I opted to just have noodles though.

It's good for groups because it turns out to be dirt cheap but don't expect the best service... EVEN IF YOU ARE KOREAN. The table of Koreans next to me were ignored for a good long time and they were pretty pissed.
author: Susy C.

description:
My favorite all time Chinese Restaurant......

San Wang Clams..
Dried Fried Calamari..
Mongolian Beef.....

Are the best I've ever had......

i'm with Rob P.

"Cheap/Reasonable prices, huge portions, excellent quality of food & customer service. I don't know what more you could ask for."

I can eat here every other day....
author: Dan M.

description:
A no-frill big-hole-inthewall in a tourist spot.

It's one of those places that you'd expect to find in Chinatown, mostly frequented by locals.
The menu is standard Chinese food with a Korean section.
Since a friend recommended them, we had both the Jajangmyun and the SanWang noodles..
soooooooooo yummy!
the Jaja was mixed in and had just the right amount of sweet and savory,
while the SanWang was spicy, but the kind of heat that fades quickly (making you want to take another bite asap).

Service was great, and the complimentary kimchi was actually pretty good.
Can't wait to come back and try some of the Chinese food because it looked amazing at our surrounding tables...
author: Jade T.

description: First came here over 30 years ago.  Food is still about the same.  Expect terrible service.  Dirty tables.  Food quality doesn't override the other two.  Their best dish is probably Mongolian Beef.
author: James B.

description:
San Wang and my family go way back.  Growing up, it was a near biweekly ritual for us.  Not because it was where my dad would talk politics in Korean with one of the "ajussi" owners or  the only place at that time serving the Korean-Chinese love child of a dish, jajangmyun and jambong but because celebration of life in our new home in the US was that much sweeter over a plate of sea cucumber or jellyfish, taste of the old country.  No birthday, graduation, promotion, pregnancy, birth, etc. would be complete without a visit to San Wang.

So here I am at the familiar round table with my brothers and mom.  No spouses, no kids, just mom and us.  We order our usual: dry fried squid with its juicy garlicky coat, shrimp in tomato sauce deceptively pedestrian but its tangy ketchup like sauce with bright peas thrown in is always scrumptious then there is also San Wang clams in black beans sauce.  And of course double order of jajangmyun polished off with house kimchi doused in vinegar.

We eat in silence then it hits me, this is the first time we have eaten together like this just the four of us since my dad's funeral nearly ten years ago.
author: Emily L.

description:
San Wang sits in a strange juxtaposition as a Chinese restaurant in Japantown owned by a Korean family. It is the strangest, but most delicious combination of food ever. San Wang is known for their dry-fried style of cooking. Their secret dry-fried recipe comes in various forms such as dry-fried chicken, shrimp, beef, scallops, squid, green beans, and eggplant. The chicken is especially popular as they are essentially large delicious fried chicken wings of magic. I recommend trying the dry-fried chicken and shrimp or the beans if you are a vegetarian. 

San Wang also offers family-style meals that serve up to 10 people. The fanciest being the Peking Dinner for $159.99 that has an assortment of dishes as well as the much desired Peking Duck dish. 

The appetizers aren't anything to write home about. The potstickers take an average of 15 minutes, which is well after all your entrees arrive at this quick turn-over establishment. Plus they taste as if they are previously frozen (the potstickers at Trader Joe's are better). The soups are good especially the Hot and Sour Soup. 

Come hungry and leave in a food-coma as San Wang serves up some of the best Chinese food outside of Chinatown. An average meal for two is $30-40.
author: Alice S.

description:
San Wang's Dried Fried Chicken totally blows San Tung's Dried Fried Chicken out of the waters! Hands down. Without the artificial-tasting sugariness and high salt content that usually accompanies the dishes at San Tung's, San Wang does an impeccable job of balancing its seasoning without compromising the taste. 

Just some preliminary words of advice: if you're coming in for lunch (the only time I've ever been) on the weekends it's best to come before the rush hour. Come in by 11:30-11:45am and you're guaranteed a table. This place is rated 5-stars not for the ambience, but for the quality of its food (with ambience ratings added on, my comprehensive score would be a 4). 

When you're seated, you are offered a small dish of kimchi. Just FYI, this restaurant is Korean-Chinese. And just in case you aren't too familiar with Chinese restaurants, there are various types of cuisines each with their specialties. For instance, you would only order your usual chicken chow mein or beef chow fun at a Cantonese restaurant, as you would only order kung pao chicken or other chili dishes at a Szechuan restaurant.

For starters we had the sizzling rice soup. Now, if you frequent many Chinese restaurants as I have, you may notice that many, if not most, restaurants have cut down on costs with the wok-crisped rice cakes. Most restaurants use pre-packaged rice cakes purchased at wholesalers and markets, leaving you mostly with a soup that is....sizzle-less. But here at San Wang, they make their own wok-crisped rice cakes and it really does make a significant difference in terms of the soup's savory taste, its aromatic qualities and a bit of a crunch to indulge with its spoonful of fresh, best-quality seafood and vegetable chunky medley. 

We then proceeded with the restaurant's Dried Fried Chicken, a bowl of Zha jiang mian (it's basically a Hand-Pulled Noodle with a black sauce of Zucchini, Potatoes and Pork dish -- if you want this dish to be as authentic-tasting, the first sign for this dish would be the color of its sauce. BLACK ONLY. NOT BROWN), the San Wang Noodle Soup, and a Beef and Green Onion Stir-fry (LOVE IT). 

This place offers a scrumptious, more health-conscious alternative to your typical greasy, sodium-overload Chinese take-out place. The service is quick! The portions are plentiful! And if you order these dishes suggested, I promise you and your tummy will only smile with delight!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Occasion: Dinner with family 

What I Had: 
Jajangmyun
Sweet and sour pork 
Jambong 
Dumplings 
Fried rice 

Food Review: Their Jambong was alright, nothing special. Sweet and sour pork was mostly breading and very little meat, but their Jajangmyun was fine. I really enjoyed all the food because it was freezing cold outside and we were all pretty hungry, but it wasn't anything better than other places I've been. 

Service Review: Food came out quickly, and they didn't disturb us while eating (typical at many Asian restaurants, so not a surprise). 

Venue Review: Lots of indoor seating that could fit even larger families or groups. Parking can be found down the street in an underground parking lot, or if you're lucky there is also some street parking. 

Overall Impression: Perfect place to go for some solid Asian comfort food or for large groups. Nothing really special, but good Chinese food on cold days.
author: Rachael K.

description:
Hands down best Chinese food in the Bay Area. We travel from Cupertino for any excuse to eat piping hot, fresh, non-greasy Chinese food loaded with fresh mixed vegetables. The quality is always consistent, service pleasant and food craveable.

Best restaurant in JapanTown and having lived in lower pac heights for sometime and tried the majority of restaurants in the area, this is the place that's worth your appetite, money and calories :)

The staff are always pleasant and very prompt. Accidentally left a credit card here at lunch and they were kind enough to have it waiting for me in the evening and checked ID on pickup!
author: Sarah M.

description: Pretty decent chinese food in Japan town / Fillmore area of San Francisco. They were not very busy because we went at around 4:30 pm on a Saturday. We had: steamed dumpling, seafood noodle soup, eggplant in garlic sauce and sizzling rice soup. Most of the dishes were good except the noodle was too soft. We liked sizzling rice soup  the best.
author: Raman S.

description:
I've been going to San Wang for years. Used to be my favorite chinese place in the city. While they still have some gems, some of it has been lost to me. Maybe i'm biased because they got rid of my favorite menu item. Yeah, maybe i'm just hurt. 

So they have amazing hand-pulled noodles. We always order chow mein when we are here. They also have some bomb shrimp fried rice. One of my faves in the city. My mom loves their dry fried green beans (yum). My brother loves their sweet and sour shrimp (yum). My dad loves their salt and pepper spare ribs (yum). I loved their chicken in peking sauce. It had tender chicken in a tangy peking sauce with a nice kick of red pepper. They took it off their menu and broke my heart. *sniff sniff*

It's great for large groups and they even have an upstairs for private parties. Their food is good and decently priced. There's never too long of a wait and their wait staff is attentive and quick. 

I would give it 3.5 stars because they took away my fave dish but i bumped them up to 4 since i've been going there so long and have always had good dining experiences with them.
author: Tab C.

description: The food was pretty flavorless, there was a $20 minimum for paying with a credit card, and the service could have been better.
author: Nicole S.

description:
LOVE!

they serve real mandarin food authentic and delicious! love love love. combination chinese and korean food that just makes you taste buds come to live! menu has lots of variety and food is good price. if you love flavorful and spicy foods come here !!!
author: Ali L.

description:
A Korean owned Chinese restaurant that incorporates both Korean and Chinese food. I guess an Asian fusion restaurant? The bf and I visited a few friends and they recommended this spot for crispy chicken wings. Thinking that it would be Korean style chicken wings, we went and to our dismay it was quite the opposite. First off, the chicken wings were tiny and the sauce was way too salty and the chicken was oily. We also ordered a Chinese vegetable stir fry medley with bok choy, mushrooms, onions, garlic, and other veggies and honestly, I enjoyed the vegetable dish more than the meat. 

The kimchi here isn't the greatest and San Wang does not have Korean yellow daikon which is real rare for a Korean/Chinese restaurant. Overall, a cheap place that's open late to grub at, but taste-wise not the greatest.
author: Hannah L.

description:
The fired string bean is my favor, very good
Ma-po Tofu --- not good, the appearance of this dish is very poor, i didn't eat it at all when i saw it 
Good service
author: Aichi L.

description: Came in  today trying something new in the area, we ordered chicken chowmein. Salt and pepper ribs. Vegetable fried rice and the lemon chicken. . I enjoyed everything.  The waitress was horrible. But the food was worth the wait. It not the best I have ever had. But it's pretty good.
author: Hershey R.

description:
I've been coming here since high school, so over a decade... 

So Koreans come here for Korean Chinese food, which consist mainly of 3 things:
Jjah jahng myun: black bean noodles (With pork and shrimp)
Jjahm Pong: seafood/pork spicy soup noodles (note, jahm pohng has now become slang for everything but the kitchen sink in Korean...)
Tahng Soo yuk: sweet n sour beef  (not the pink sauce, but the clear one with pineapples and sea things).  You can get this with pork, but seriously, most Koreans I know eat it with beef.

Those 3 things are delicious here, but sometimes the Jjahm pohng is hit or miss, sometimes amazing, sometimes meh. 

If you follow Korean chinese food at all, the jjahm pohng is better at San Tung, the jjah jahng myun better at San Wang.  Just my opinion though.

Also, the fried potstickers are really good here too.

And if you're with a big group, they're known for their clams... my dad loves getting these when there's more than 4 of us.
author: YJ P.

description: Amazing dry fried chicken, hand pulled noodles. Been coming here for a long long time.  Service has always been inconsistent, but the food is just too darn good to not go.  San Tung on Irving is their only legit rival. Garlic Rules!!!
author: Chad R.

description:
BLACK NOODLEEEEE!

Yes, that is pretty much all I order here. And I love it! I use to only eat the black noodle at Playground, but my boyfriend stopped taking me there (don't know why) and we came here instead. Initially, I was sad, because I love the black noodle at Playground. But as time progress, I started to adapt to the black noodle here, and now I love it. 

The gan pong chicken is another thing that I order here. But it is very inconsistent. Sometimes they give a lot of sauce (which is what I like) and sometimes, it is very very very dry. The Tangsuyuk here is really good though, lots of sauce all the time.
author: Alicia W.

description: Can't say much for any other dish, but the jja jiang myun is tops. The noodles are chewy and stretchy, and the black bean sauce is well flavored. Only suggestion is that it could probably use a little less oil, but if you're trying to keep your waistline this is probably not the way to go either way.
author: Judy L.

description:
Went here fore dinner on a Sunday night. My friend took me here and paid, yay free meal! So my review is only for the taste because I don't remember the prices. 

I remember having the 
1. Mu Shu Pork 
2. A cold dish with a lot of seafood in Chinese mustard,
3. San Wang Noodle Soup
4. Salt and Pepper Beef

My favorite was the Mu Shu Pork, it was delicious! Aside from that, everything was decent but not amazing. The Salt and pepper chicken is supposed to be pretty good and famous, but we had the salt and pepper beef instead. The beef was a disappointing, but I still have hopes for chicken.
author: Anna T.

description:
Been here twice, the first being seven months ago and just last month.

They start you off with complimentary kimchee, which is pretty tasty and a bit different.

I've haven't looked at the menu once yet since the rest of our family is ordering.  

Highlights: 

*String Beans - Really freakin' good!  They have that double-fried thing going on perfectly - crispy on the outside and still with a crunch in the inside.  Just good stuff.  I'd eat a whole plate of that myself if I could.

My family likes ordering their clams, not sure why.  It's good, but not great.  Last time we found a big old rock on our plate.  We showed it to the manager just so he knew and he was pretty indifferent about it.  Oh well was his reaction.

The first time we ordered some beef dish that tasted pretty blah.  I can't remember what it was because it wasn't very good.

What I do remember from the first experience and our most recent was the service.  Nothing to rave about at all.  The first time it was bad - they were not good about clearing dirty dishes at all, especially when it came to cutting the cake.  Despite having reservations, the table wasn't ready for our large family and grandparent in a wheelchair.  Yeah, we don't like waiting when we're hungry and when we expect them to be ready for us.  Most recently, service was not that great either and they were not good about refilling the tea.  They would come around and look, but not take the tea pot with them for a refill.  

We'll probably end up here again because they have a large table to accommodate our large family, which is probably why we came here in the first place.  And the parking is a lot easier here than on Geary or Clement.  Maybe we'll have to order their more Korean type foods instead to have a better experience.
author: Teri C.

description:
UPDATE - This place is even more of a godawful garbage dump. Stay away! You've been warned. San Tung is light years ahead of this place. Go there instead.

The place is still dingy and dirty.

Amazingly, the awful service has somehow gotten even **worse**. It now ranges from nonexistent, to surly, to purposely ignoring you despite making direct eye contact and conversation.

As you're probably familiar with Chinese restaurants, you'd know to expect dirty tables and horrendous service if the food were good. But the food here is anything but good.

Years ago, the food was mediocre at best on a good day. It, like the service, has also somehow gotten even **worse**. 

The food used to at least come out quickly. Now it takes forever. Perhaps to balance things out, it's also significantly more expensive, too.

There's literally no reason for a restaurant like this to exist anymore in San Francisco. Maybe when Chinese food was still a novelty, back in the 1950s (or whenever), and crappy, overpriced Chinese restaurants with terrible service like these were something you would do once for the experience. 

I don't think there are any tourists left on the planet naive enough to find this dumpster fire of a restaurant to be anything other than a horrific experience. It really is that bad.

Nothing about this place is worth your time, effort or hard-earned money.

STAY AWAY. 




OLD REVIEW - Sad to say, San Wang has completely gone to hell.

The service has become incredibly inattentive and the servers are no longer interested in taking your order, refilling your rice/tea, or actually seating your party properly or in a timely manner. They'll take your order (eventually), bring out your food (which still comes out quickly), and hand you the check (eventually). Beyond that, as a customer here, you may as well be invisible.

The food has taken an absolute nosedive. The dry-fried squid is an absolute, soggy, floppy, flavorless-mouthful-of-batter disaster. The dry-fried chicken wings now come out over-fried, shriveled, and smelly. I've never been to San Tung in my life (I'll rectify this soon), but I can guarantee their wings, which I've never actually eaten, are better than this place's. That's how bad it's gotten.

Before, this place looked like your typical, terrible, family-style Chinese restaurant and was such a treat because of how pleasant a surprise it would turn out to be.

Now, this place is, in fact, your typical, terrible, family-style Chinese restaurant, with horrible service and awful food.

If you're in San Francisco and craving Chinese food, you can do much, much, much better than San Wang. Avoid at all costs.
author: A P.

description:
We've been coming here forever and we visited their other locations as well (now closed).  The menu still seems the same after the recent remodeling (they were closed for a couple of months) and they still give you some complimentary yummy kim chee to start (the owner is Chinese but lived in Korea, I believe).  Some of the dishes were better before the remodel, some were better afterwards.  It seems even more popular now than it did before the remodel (consider making reservations).  Post-remodel, more items seem to be battered and fried than pre-remodel.  The place still looks rather plain despite the remodel.  The dishes have plenty of sauce, probably too much sauce, but the sauces are good and plenty flavorful.  There have been fights over who would take home the leftover sauce.

It's really a three star restaurant but two five star dishes, reasonable prices, generous portions, and the status as an old family favorite earn San Wang an extra star.  Get the clams in their special sauce with jalapenos and dry fried chicken (my father's favorite, it's loaded with ample garlic and chili peppers, crispy outside, tender inside, explosive flavor).  It seems like you get far less chicken than you used to though.  

The dry fried string beans were a family favorite too, but they're coated in some type of batter now and they weren't before.  Some of the green beans were stuck together and they didn't use the Chinese long beans.  They do have a great, garlicky flavor though.  The spicy seafood noodle soup with hand-pulled noodles had lots of seafood, including clams, sea cucumber, etc.  The broth is decent but not amazing.  I could do without ordering it.   I think we had hot pepper shrimp - it was deep fried and goopy, definitely a disappointment.  The mabo tofu is okay but not special.  I used to like this dish better before the remodel.

Portions are generous, the food comes out in a blink of an eye even when they're busy, and the prices are reasonable enough to even please my father.  It's better to come here with a large group (make reservations).

They don't give you oranges or fortune cookies at the end of the meal.  Too bad.  Much as I like authentic Chinese food, I still enjoy fortune cookies.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Came here a few times now...when I first came here I wasn't a fan of this place. But overtime I've really grown to like it. Seating here is easier than San Tung..I've never had to wait! there's always a table whenever I get here. This is like a korean/chinese fusion place. They automatically serve you kim-chee and onions with this black bean sauce when you sit down.
Dishes I've tried:

-Dry Fried Chicken wings- this was OK. Not the same as San Tung's at all. This had much more Garlic and did not have the sweetness to it. 
-Dry Fried Beef - I really like this dish. This too has a lot of garlic, but its also stir fried with onions and chives and it has a really good flavor to it
- Black bean sauce noodles - I'm just not a fan of these noodles, but this was OK.
-Jap-Chae-  I really liked this too, this had great flavor and isn't as dry as regular korean jap-chae's.
-Spicy Seafood noodle soup - This is too spicy for me..so I did not enjoy it as much. But my bf really likes it...but he can handle spicy.
-Hot Braised Tofu - This was pretty good. A little on the saucy side..but good with rice.
-Pot Stickers - I didn't like the pot stickers here at all. 

Overall, service is okay...food comes out quickly and the portions are really big! Parking can be a little difficult because its around japantown, but nothing too bad.
author: Betty S.

description: The jajangmyeon is okay here. Their chicken wings (dry) were pretty awesome tasting. The lone pigeon walking inside was a bummer (the door was left open that afternoon). Shoo.
author: Derek N.

description: Al H.'s Review is fake. Just look at the photos. They were taken from inside the kitchen. You can tell because the table is metal and from the anti slip carpet on the floor. How sad is this place?
author: Eric E.

description: Horrible.....being Korean and have lived in so cal....avoid avoid....salty, poor quality food
author: Diana S.

description:
I wasn't able to locate this resturant on Yelp's! "check-in. It's actually been years since I last ate here.  Coworkers had a farewell luncheon here this past week. $16pp.  Great deal.  However three of us had unsettled stomachs for the rest of the afternoon from overly sauced dishes.  

I believe this is the only Chinese food restaurant in Japantown.  Quote from my non Asian co-worker: " Well isn't that odd.  Korean kimchi is being served at a Chinese restaurant in the middle of Japantown.  Hmmmm.".  It was kind of entertaining we had to translate fungus to mushroom & squid to calamari for them so they'd recognize what they were eating. 

-(*)Vegetable soup
-Spicy pork
-Spicy peppered beef
-Fried squid
-Fried Shrimp
-Eggplant w/ fungus

(*) = Favorite
author: Stacey L.

description: Prices kinda hi.  I cant eat onions but the cant make food w/o onions so i didnt eat.  My wife seemed to like it.
author: Mike B.

description: I like this type of food. Got a clam dish, dry chicken wings and a fish. Love the first two but the fish was aight. Pretty yummy Chinese food joint in Japan town.
author: Karina H.

description:
Came here with a friend on Saturday evening. When we arrived the restaurant was quite packed so none of the staff was able to greet us. That was fine. We just picked a table and sat down then notified the wait staff. Now the restaurant was quite packed at this time so it took awhile for the waiter to take our orders. The wait staff was very friendly but again it was very busy so they weren't able to promptly attend to our needs but they did their part. 

We didn't feel like eating too much so we ordered two noodle dishes, Roasted bean noodle(Ja Jang Myun) and San Wang special noodle dish. Both were priced very reasonable at only $7.25. Even though the wait staff had their hands full I don't remember having to wait long for our food to arrive. When the food arrived it was warm and the best part, PLENTY. They really give large portions. Well worth the price of the dish. 

The combined portion of both noodle dishes was more then enough to feed us both. We were only able to devour the Sam Wang noodle dish and the 2nd dish we took to go. I heard from one of my korean friends that this restaurant makes decent Ja Jang Myun in SF. He wasn't lying. This was my second time eating the dish and I was really pleased unlike my first time which was overpriced and bland. Without name calling on yelp I'll just say the other restaurant is located on Geary near Japan town and across from a hospital. 0_0 

My first time eating here and I can't wait to come back again.
author: Jude N.

description:
I'm spoiled by LA Korean Chinese food. This place was meh. Jjambong was watered down and bland. Jajangmyun was poorly executed. Tangsooyook was all fried stuff and no meat. Jellyfish was bland.

However, I will say that our waiter was very attentive and legitimately tried to make our dining experience pleasant. Everyone else that worked there didn't really seem to care whether or not we liked the food, or got our food.
author: So H.

description:
Since I think Chinese food in San Diego is mostly crap, one of the first things I like to do in other cities is try their Chinese.
This place was pretty bad; my General's Chicken tasted like it had been cooked 3 days earlier and reheated. My girlfriend's shrimp with tomato sauce was definitely made with ketchup. The hot and sour soup was neither.
Service was friendly.
author: Sean W.

description:
Mediocre food, horrible, horrible service. The waiters had major attitude, I never got the water I asked for, the table that sat down after me got their food before me (we ordered the same thing), and it took nearly 20 minutes to get our check after we finished eating. It wasnt even that busy!

THAT said, the mongolian beef was almost inedible. No flavor and it had mushrooms?! Ive never had mongolion beef with mushrooms... Gave it two stars instead of one because of the jja jang myun. One of the better jja jang myuns around. 

The jja jang myun is good, but it doesn't make up for the horrible service. Not planning on returning.
author: E S.

description: It's kind of sad reading all the negative reviews about this place. It reinforces the American stereotypes (yes Asian Americans too) of ignorance and smothering there food with salt/sweets. The food here is Korean-Chinese food and the dishes are very good. If your looking for American-Chinese food or Traditional Chinese, go somewhere else.
author: Jon M.

description:
Went back here to try the jam pong.  When I got the dish, it had large slabs of pork in it.  WTF!  Jam pong is a seafood based soup.  I told the waiter that I don't eat pork and nowhere on the menu did it say it had pork in it.  The waiter just shrugged and said it has pork.

OOoookaaay.  Whatever, so I just picked out the pork and then tasted the broth.  I almost spit it back out.  It was RANCID!!  It tasted like rancid pork.  It WAS abnormally hot that day in SF so I think maybe the pork went bad or something so I tried to send it back.  THe owner came out and said that he still had to charge me for the dish.  WHAT?!!!  It's fuckin RANCID!!

Then my friend started arguing with the owner that the jampong wasn't even supposed to have pork in it in which the owner then tried to bullshit and insisted that that's how jampong is made.  WE have had jampong in Korea, NYC, LA, even at other restaurants in SF...you ask any Korean person and they'll tell you Jampong is seafood based.  

By now, I'm started to get a shady feeling about him and what goes on in the kitchen.  I mean it's $10. Whatever, I'll pay it.  But for him to argue about it...I mean is he that desperate for money?  Cuz then it makes me think that in order to cut costs, he's using expired stuff...maybe he reuses the kimchi banchan too from other tables.
