I'm actually thinking of calling the health dept to check out this restaurant to make sure because that jampong was truly off.  I've had ramen at Japanese places that has a pork broth and no way does it taste like spoiled meat.

YUCK!  Not to mention, my friend ordered Peking Duck and it looked and tasted like it was sitting out in the sahara desert for a week.  Hardly any meat and dry like twigs.  And they tried to charge us for rice that they never wound up giving us.

Anyhow, I don't recommend going here even though in the past I thought the jajangmyun was ok.  Because of the way the owner handled the situation, it makes me think there are some dirty practices going on in the kitchen.
author: C A.

description:
HUGE PORTIONS!!!! I really don't understand why there is a Chinese restaurant right in Japantown, but then again...why was I eating at a Chinese restaurant when I was in Japantown?! And why did they serve kimchi with the foood...(answer: the owners are Korean). 

I came in and they were SUPER busy and a tad understaffed. However, whenever we had to ask for more napkins or more rice, they were quick and prompt and apologized profusely for not noticing it first. I ordered the San Wang clams, which were super fresh but a tad oversauced (HUGE portions, most Chinese restaurants would give you 2/3 or less of that for one order), the scallops (surprisingly, they were fried but still very good), the garlic eggplant (yum) and the chicken with black mushrooms (forgettable). Even though the lunch rush was barely ending, our waitress was gracious and boxed our leftovers for us instead of throwing us a few take-out boxes and making us do it ourselves. 

Would come back again.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Noodles with plum sauce. That's all I can say. Only because that's pretty much the only dish I've ever ordered here. 
Sooooo delicious!! It would not be the first thing I'd eat after being stranded on an island..but it definitely does satisfy me as a good meal. 
  The dish consists of their noodles of perfect consistency with the plum sauce on top. This sauce-brown and goopy- is not too aesthetically pleasing in my opinion..but it compliments the noodles perfectly!! The sauce contains bits of onion, zucchini, meat(I want to say pork?), and some shrimp...TRY IT!!! the only thing is, the sauce is pretty oily, and so a lot of the time I'll get super full after half the bowl...which leaves enough to take home for a second meal! :)

I also LOVE the kimchi they give you here after you order. When I ate here recently, we asked for a second helping of the kimchi..and devoured it. The waitress came buy our table, said,"oh, you like it!" and returned to our table with a bowl twice as big as the two previous ones, filled with kimchi. Look at her go, gaining customer service points :)
author: Z A.

description: I was there with family that across the hotel recommend (San wAng rest) I believe, but it was horrible, I do not recommend this place!!!!!  Worker smoking and belligerent drunk  looks like worker  or boss drinking with cig in hand , ( thought it was against law ) smoking in rest and bar prohib!!!!! Fight broke out , we left without paying , This guy was yelling and screaming and throwing punches at coworkers ( fight on YouTube)  caught on my friends phone!!!! Stay away!!!!
author: Nancy T.

description:
I'm not a super big fan of the hand-pulled noodles with plum sauce, but that's the highlight here.  Therefore, that's what I ordered when I came in recently, mainly because I was walking by and they had World Series Game 6 showing on their TV.

I can at least appreciate the quality of the noodle and the effort they put into it.  The noodles do taste fresh.  In past years, when I came with a friend, I've even witnessed them pounding dough in the kitchen making the noodles from scratch.

Similar to San Tung Restaurant, they give you kimchi when they sit you down.  The nice thing here is that when I finished it and the food hadn't come yet, they automatically gave me a second serving.  This is something I never experienced at San Tung.
author: H K.

description: I pass by this place a lot and always see it filled with people, so tonight, when my son begged me for fried rice, we gave it a try. We ordered combination fried rice and Mongolian chicken. They basically tasted the same. No flavor whatsoever. The portions are huge, but I'd rather have flavor. Now I have a fridge full of bland leftovers and an MSG headache.
author: Jen L.

description:
pretty decent place if you're in the mood for Korean-style Chinese food.  Jjajangmyun (black noodles) was decent, maybe a little on the blander side.  JJampong (spicy seafood noodles) was done pretty well.  Ggampongi chicken (spicy fried chicken) was definitely the best dish of the night, seasoned just right.

portions were large, service was quick.  dining room has decent amount of seating.  not a bad choice if you're already in the area.
author: JL G.

description: I am big fan of this place. It is weird going to a Chinese place right in the middle of Japantown but you won't regret it. Try the soups!
author: Sahba A.

description: To be honest - I think I've only had the jajang-myun here but I love it. It's got that slippery-gooey texture that jajang-myun should have and it's flavorful! If you love jajang-myun I suggest checking this place out.
author: Gee H.

description:
I came here yesterday for a semi-good meal I always order the won-ton soup, its one of the best in the city, they give you lots of won tons and veggies in the soup.
And of course I ordered the dry fried chicken wings they are good but not as good as san tung .
But I also ordered the salt and pepper ribs its off the hook, its so good and so crunchy.
author: Corey W.

description: Jja Jang Myun (Noodles in Plum sauce) is good. The sauce is not starchy, as it is in other places that serve the same dish.  They serve kimchi alongside your order.  Not too crowded at lunchtime.
author: Dan C.

description: I use to be a regular many years ago. I haven't been here in years and was hoping it was the same. I was disappointed by the wings, they were tasty but the quality of how they put the chopped garlic/green onions & peppers over the top was big and really couldn't eat raw by my standards. The moo shu vegetarian dish was good, but they used flour tortillas! I couldn't believe it! It was too thick for this dish and just warm, not thin and steamy soft which meant it cracked trying to wrap it. They use to use thin wrappers you can buy frozen. The dry fried green beans weren't dry fried, they were thick beans and deep fried w/ a light batter. Don't think I would go back unless it was w/a group that wanted to go for convenience. I was very disappointed in the quality sadly to say about an old favorite.
author: Kim F.

description:
This us my favorite Chinese restaurant in the city so far.

I love the Korean waitress who anyways takes care of our table.  People who work here are really nice.  This place is always busy so their food is FRESH!!!

Our favorite dishes: San Wang noodles, sweet and sour beef, Mongolian beef, black noodles, San Wang clam to name a few.

***Very hard to find a parking space unless you park near by garage.***
author: Maki M.

description:
If you are looking for ambiance, forget it. That is unless ambiance is a nearly industrial chinese restaurant where you are nearly the only non-chinese present.So why the 5 stars? Its the food! Of all the stereo types of the chinese, buying cheap and eating well are two that seem to valid. This place is both. We were just looking for a quick reasonable inexpensive meal. It would have been faster if they brought out all the dishes in the A menu but then we would not have had enough room on the table for the large proportions! Granted we ordered Chinese-American staples, but they were done really well. We sure didn't get hungry after an hour from this meal!
Cost? $30 for food plus about $6 for some ok chard. That was $30 for 4 courses, for TWO people!!!
This is my first time here and won't be the last....(If I didn't live 50 miles from the City I would be there tonight)
author: Barry F.

description:
I've been coming here with my family since I was a kid.  

Family friendly restaurant, they have a banquet area upstairs...prices are cheap, service is quick.

A few awesome dishes:
Black Bean noodles - fresh pulled noodles, black bean sauce, shrimp, pork, veggies...so yummy, they have the flavor right

Dry Fried Chicken wings - SUPER crispy and delicious.  My only complaints is that not all the pieces look like chicken wings.  They seem to cut the wings in half and I even got a huge drumstick this last time...weird pieces, but they all tasted good 

Walnut Prawns - mayo and honey on prawns???  why yes please...haha

House fried rice - I love their fried rice, but it's a hit and miss...sometimes the rice is a day old...i love it like that...sometimes the rice is mooshier than desired...but it's still good.

Portions are good, food is served quickly and HOT, prices are good, and you can usually be seated right away!

I'll definitely be coming back...as always!
author: Janet L.

description:
This place is super! Delicious, fresh, Szechuan good, made by Koreans, in Japantown. What else can you ask for?

My favorites so far- wonton soup- fresh dumplings (you might see them being made in the dining room), crispy fresh vegetables, shrimp!, big mushroom slices. And super tasty broth. 

Dry fried chicken- not sure how them do this one, but it's great!

Fresh egg rolls! 

Sweet and sour whole fish, complete with maraschino cherries. 

Basic service, and typically no-frills decor, but go for the food. Oh, and kimchi on the table as soon as you sit down.
author: j-mo h.

description: This place has great chinese food.  I always order the sweet and sour beef, garlic eggplant, and general's chicken.  They use really good quality chicken meat.  Also, the portion sizes are very big.
author: Sunny K.

description:
In this restaurant, yougotta order "Korean" style chinese dishes! I have been coming to this restaurant for many church occasions and I actually was not a fan of this restaurant until last year when they changed owner or cook or something... Taste of dishes definitely changed. 

Hand-made noodle is great~ Jjajangmyun (Korean Style chow-mein), Tangsooyook (Korean style sweet and sour pork), Sizzling rice soup, Yangjangpee, Shrimp Kkanpoongi are my favorite dishes... More people you go with, better here~ Their dishes are huge and staff are nice. If you ask for Kimchee~ you will get that as well!!
author: Sunny K.

description:
If you see my novel on why RG Lounge sucks, you can see what I think is good asian food in the city...

Service is as usual for these places... nothing to write home about but I dont care.  I'm here for the food.  Hey peeps, stop giving low ratings for service in a real chinese restaurant.   

Let me say two words here:
DRY FRY.

Yes. Yes Yes... They make this preparation with just about any meat or vegetable.  They are all  great.  If you like whats inside you will like it.  

They coat the base meat/veggie in light batter.  Flash fry it up then toss with minced garlic, scallion, mushrooms, red chilli peppers and a very small amount of liquid so its not really a sauce but moist.  
OMG.  This dish rocks.  The dry fry shrimp is my favorite.  But the beef is awesome .  Shit they all are. And this is not just me.  My family all craves it and we hit this place everytime we visit SF.   And my best friend who lives in SF craves it and eats there all the time.  So I know I'm not off base on this one. 

Everything else here I've had is quite good and flavorful to my taste buds and not greasy. The vegetable mooshoo is very fresh and tasty.  Won ton soup is really fresh and loaded with EVERYTHING.  It's like 5 bucks for a "Small" size that easily feeds 4 or 5 people.  I dont know how they do it so cheap and make it so good!

And the portions are huge and the prices low.  13 bucks for the dry fry shrimp  and you get a lot of them !  They have been around for over 40 years so that should tell you something right there.  

RG Lounge.... this is what "flavor" is all about !
author: Bruce M.

description: We've been coming here for decades whenever we're around the area.  Forget Chinatown restaurants since this place is convenient and dishes out a superb fare.  I thought I'd give them their deserved rating.  Service can be slow when busy but relax and enjoy the comp kimchee meanwhile.  Save yourself the aggravation of seeking street parking and proceed to the garage across the street and weave yourself through the hotel main entrance then cross the street to San Wang.
author: Jesus L.

description:
I wanted to like this place. I wanted to have another decent food option near the Japantown garage where parking is so easy. Instead it was very meh. If it was only bad because they put mushrooms in almost everything we ordered without me expecting it I would have given it a higher rating. But the sweet and sour pork was also pretty subpar. Then at the end it took about 5 minutes to get the waiter's attention in order to get the check.

They are pretty nice and the portions are relatively large... but it didn't have much else going for it.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Awesome Chinese food in Japantown.  It was the smell that brought me in.  Service was pretty good...seemed like it was better if you were Asian.  Just an observation.  I would go back for more!

Hot tea and some kind of cabbage dish that looked like Kimchi was complimentary with your meal (at least for dinner).
author: John B.

description: crispy rice soup, salt n pepper crab, chicken, and clams was absolutely delicious! i cant get enough! cant wait to come back for more lol
author: Linda A.

description: Really kind of funny, it's a Chinese restaurant inside Japantown mostly filled with large Korean groups. Like others have commented, San Wang serves more Korean-Chinese, I wonder if that is why each dish is very saucy or if that is the more Americanized part of it. Not your most authentic place for Asian food in the neighborhood, but it seems pretty clean, and it' s basically the only Chinese food place in Japantown, and prices okay for the food.
author: Christina H.

description:
wow...so much has changed with the cooking.. me so sad :(
it's been many years since our last visit..i'm sure they have a different cook.
we ordered the dried fried chicken, squid, garlic eggplant
our usual favorites...didn't taste the same
so disappointed..
on to san tung when it reopens from remodeling the restaurant
author: Kei ..

description: The food here is great! We ordered Korean dishes and were VERY happy. But I didn't give it 5 starts because the service was terrible. Lucky for the them, the food makes up for it. Just maybe bring your own bottle of water, you won't get a refill.
author: Joon K.

description:
I'm a pretty light eater so I was very surprised to find that everything I ordered tasted bland. Here's what was ordered: 

Dry fry string beans - Ordered this based on recommendation of other yelpers. Visually correct, but it tasted like the chef forgot the salt. 

Salt and pepper pork chops - Came out much less oily than expected which was a plus. Again, it seemed like the chef only remembered the "pepper" part and not the salt. 

Soup noodles - Other than the hand-pulled noodles, it was pretty forgettable. Too much/many canned vegetables. 

Stir-fry noodles - The hand-pulled noodles really stood out in its texture. The stir-fry version had more flavor than the soup version and used more fresh veggies. 

I think this would be a pretty good place for someone watching their diet---all the dishes I ordered, no matter how guilty it sounded, came out "healthily" prepared. For anyone looking for a more indulgent or authentic flavor, San Wang may not satisfy.
author: A. L.

description: Since I consider myself too busy (or too lazy) to cook, I always go here to buy food. I haven't tried so many things yet but my favorite so far is Kung Pao Chicken. The staff are nice especially the tall male one who's always by the counter when I pick up to-go food in the afternoon. I would really give them 5 stars but I went here one time for lunch when they were sooo busy and too understaffed that I didn't get acknowledged at once.
author: The Silent Spectator X.

description:
When I was in Berkeley, I used to drive to SF for this restaurant. I love their Sizzing Rice soup. I don't know what it is.. but I JUST lOVE IT.. 

The food here is pretty okay and they serve really fast.  I usually go here during lunch time now, since I work near here, and the food is READY by the time I get there.. Ususally 10 - 15 minutes.  For having an hour lunch break, this works out perfect!

Only thing is that parking sucks......
author: Esther N.

description:
I only come here for one thing: hand pulled spicy seafood noodle soup.  It's very good.  

Every now and then, I'll order dry fried pork, shrimp or beef or chicken that's not bad, but I usually can't finish it because the portion's too large.

For an appetizer, I also occasionally order pot stickers.  Nothing spectacular, but not bad either.

All and all, it's one of my favorite soup noodle places in all of SF.
author: Tony U.

description:
Placed an order to go.  Had 2 reviewer favorites- the jjajangmyeon AKA Noodles with Plum Sauce, and the dry-fried chicken, as well as eggplant with garlic sauce.  The jjajangmyeon and dry-fried chicken both lived up to their high expectations.  The eggplant with garlic sauce was ok- had a nice sauce but nothing in the dish inspired a feeling of "wow!" to me like the other 2 dishes did.  I'd definitely like to go here again next time I'm in the mood for Chinese food.

Prices:
Noodles with Plum Sauce: $6.50
Eggplant with Garlic Sauce: $6.50
Dry Fried Chicken wings: $8.50
author: Karen W.

description:
CHINESE RESTAURANT IN THE HEART OF JAPANTOWN

It was late in the evening and my friend introduced me to a Chinese spot away from Chinatown and in Japantown. I really didnt know what to think but to just think of it as some affordable Chinese restaurant. We entered the restaurant and I was suprised to the place half-way packed with other random people eating. We were quickly seated and as I browsed the menu my first thoughts exactly were right "affordable Chinese food". 

My friend has been here before so I went along with what she ordered for us: 
- Soup: Hot and Sour Soup ($8.95)
- Vegtables: Mushroom, Bamboo shoots with Pea pods, and fresh broccoli ($5.95)
- Beef with Bak choy ($7.50)
- rice

The food was pretty good. Usually I'm picky with my Chinese food but I was very pleased and would return to this spot for another "affordable Chinese food" fix. The portions are well enough to pack up and take home for leftovers too!
author: Jane A.

description:
chinese with korean fusion, but doing wrong...mediocre at best....black sauce noodles acceptable...dry fried chicken near tasteless...the rest?...typical monotonous edible chinese fare with ongoing blunders...incompetence?...san wang noodles recommended....the rest...not...

sub-par pot stickers $six.fifty....equally sub-par steamed pot stickers $six.fifty....horrible dry-fried chicken $eight.ninety-five...mediocre dry-fried green beans $six-ninety-five...average beef soup noodle $seven-thirty-five....average san wang clam $eleven.ninety-five...little pricey beer $seven.fifty (each)...
author: Hen A.

description: Really really good northeast Asia type Chinese food. As the majority of the patrons are usually Korean at any given time, you can immediately know that they also have really good Korean type of Chinese food. You can know these dishes by the Korean writing on the menu next to the Chinese and English. Famous traditional staples like: TzaTza myon (black bean noodles) champong (spicy seafood noodle soup,)  bolum bap (Korean type fried rice) yang nyom chicken (spicy hot sauce fried chicken) tang su yuk (Korean type sweet and sour pork etc. all well done, just like back home, so the full Korean tables. Our go to place whenever we have a hankering for the Korean type of Chinese food that I was used to eating in Korea. Bittersweet memories, but that's a story for when we eat together, until then, just know that the food here is authentic, delicious and reasonable and reminds me of Sunday Chinese lunch with the fam in Han Gook (the big K, Ko-rea. Hee hee.
author: George F.

description:
The hand-pulled noodles with Hoisan, onions, cucumber, and shrimp were really tasty.  The noodles were almost el dente, not overcooked.  The sweet and sour beef was mostly sweet, and the vegetables were not overcooked.  

However, the fried meatball dish lacked flavor and was expensive ($17); the texture seemed cooked but the insides tasted uncooked.  

The service was pretty fast even though it was nearly noon on a Friday.
author: Julie Y.

description: My Auntie brought me here and so far, this is the B-E-S-T Chinese-Korean restaurant!
author: Zett M.

description:
OK what the hell is wrong with all you chinese people! (BTW I am also chinese)

Was craving korean and have passed this place several times and figuring the line is always out the door with chinese folks like theyre giving out free gold or something it MUST be good. 

got there around 630ish and it was packed, with a family of 11 ahead of us. Of course more families crowded in and with no sign in sheet it kinda got chaotic. Chinese people just don;t like to wait in line, neither do they obey lines and really don't care if you got there first, they just try to cram in as they can. This old man and his family tried to get to the front of the group and as soon as a table free'd up, the waiter in the back looked at us and said who is next and before anyone even had time to respond, he shimmied his way on back there. OH HELL NO!

I raised my voice and said "HELLO WE WERE HERE FIRST!".Luckily there was another table right behind them that they gave us otherwise you know I would have raised hell. The staff were apologetic that they didnt recognize we had been standing there for like 15 minutes...so we proceeded to our table....
Not being a huge fan of san tung's chicken wings nor their green beans I was skeptical about this place...

we got:
highly coveted dried fried chicken wings
braised green beans with assorted mushrooms
san wong noodle soup
pan fried shrimp

over all BLEH. MEH. UGH. What is all the fuss about? 
while we were waiting in line this old lady and thi sother couple was saying they came all the way from south city, and were dying to try this place. THey said hte noodles are hand cut and are really really good. The famous and suposedly good noodles dish was just OK. I The noodles were chewy and had a nice consistency to it, but the broth was just so so. Had bits of pork, shrimp, cucumber, cabbage and mushroom and black mushroom fungus in it. MEH. Forgettable.

The pan seared shrimp were OK, just fried shrimp sauteed in a gang of garlic, peppers, mushrooms, green onion. at $11.50 a huge portion as was the noodles.

Dried fried chicken wings. KFC chicken wings taste better than this! They were virtually tasteless fried chicken drumettes sauteed in...YES THE SAME ITEMS AS THE SHRIMP!: garlic, peppers, onions and mushrooms! 

Last was the braised green beans. Nice green beans sauteed with YES THE SAME INGREDIANTS!: Mushrooms, black mushroom fungus, button mushrooms. 

EVERTHING TASTED THE SAME. Every dish had the same ingrediants which was bothersome.

Overall food was forgettable and i left really unsatisfied, so unsatisfied that I had to go to J town to get a crepe. Also what was so annoying was yes the restaurant is busy and yes there is a line, but why do the waiters have to rush SO BAD and execute their service like they were running for their lives? I have never seen servers so rushed, so abrupt, and looked like they were so in a hurry with everythng that htey wre about to die. It was just not pleasant and not very enjoyable to have a dinner when every wait staff is literally running past you so fast that your hair whiffs in the air. they had 5 servers in there so it was plenty and I didnt see any customers complaining about slowneess of items or food delivery, so I am not sure why they were so hurried. In experienced perhaps?

One review said "THIS IS THE BEST CHINESE RESTAURANT IN SF". I'm sorry, but you should perhaps stick to eating hot dogs and hamburgers cus you obviously have no clue what REAL CHINESE FOOD IS and dont say things that are far from the truth.

Will never go back and you shouldnt either unless you want bland forgettable food.

$38.95 without tip. Ugh, should went to eat shabu at kufuya.
Also Nobu K who always has good reviews on asian places gave this a 2 star. F*** should have known betterrrrrrr!!!!!!!!

The only thing good about this freaking places is portions ar ehuge which is probably why most chinese families like this place. I prefer quality quanitty so this is not for me.
author: Petri Y.

description: Dry friend EVERYTHING!!! It is their staple. Been coming here since I was little and don't plan on stopping anytime soon. Love this place!
author: Janelle H.

description:
There are certain places that will forever remain with you, and San Wang, is definitely one of them.

When I was younger (back when I was wee little thing) my family would come out here to have Sunday lunches, and if we ever came out to SF, we'd stop in here for a meal.

It had been years since I came here last, but this past Sunday, my mother and sister popped into the city for a bit and we headed over. Oddly, I woke up with a severe craving for one of their dishes so I guess it was just a matter of time.

Little do people know that Korean Chinese food is a wonderful type of fusion, and if you ever want to indulge yourself in this great treat, come here.

There are plenty of great dishes, and the portions here allow you to get your money's worth, but the one you Must try: The Spicy Fried Shrimp. ( meh oon seh woo) 

I don't know what it is about this dish, it's almost like the biscuits and gravy of the east, but it's a dish that I could eat pounds of. Deep fried shrimp that are crispy and large, drenched in a sweet and sour sauce that will leave you in a drunken Homer Simpson state.

I usually pour the sauce over my rice to continue the gluttonous flavor feast. It's a dish you have to try, and will leave you waking up 2-3 years from now and still craving it. Much like I did.

And you can not leave until you wolf down another house special, their dry fried chicken (gampongi )

You will have a boneyard within a blink. 

San Wang is a down home place. I will be the first to admit that the decor is lackluster, the service is.... 

But what you will see here are big families coming together, eating big dishes with Big Flavor. Enjoy it, I know you will.
author: Mike K.

description:
I'm not sure why this place doesn't receive higher reviews.  I come here for the food and not for the ambiance.  I love the Dry Fried Pork, Sam Wang noodles, Sam Wang Clams, and Baby Shrimp.  The fried rice and chow mein are as good as it gets from any other decent Chinese restaurant.

The place gets busy and packed so plan to wait a while before being seated during the busy rush hours.  There is metered parking on the streets just outside the restaurant and you can also pay to park in the garage underneath the Japan Town mall across the street.
author: Ritche C.

description:
My four stars are for the fun time I had and the deliciousness of the food.  The service was kind of sporadic and hesitant.  

10 of us order a family meal which, with tip, came to $170.  It was delicious however.  And they were very nice to accomodate our large group since it's not a huge place (even though we made reservations in advance and I recommend doing that if you are seating 5 or more).  The spinning table top made the evening all the more fun!
author: Levi B.

description:
I can't say enough yummy things about this restaurant.  We are eating on the cheap these days and this place was always full so we thought it would be a good bet.  Love, love the fresh veggies and monster huge portions.  The water dumplings were so fresh, stuffed with shrimp and chives, lip smacking!  

Word of caution the portion sizes are HUGE so don't go overboard on ordering.  Appetizers and two entrees is more than enough for three people.  The broccoli beef was tasty as was the mo sho pork.  I can't wait to go back and order their crab special now that it's in season. This is a yummy and economical dinner choice!  

*Also located near Kabuki Theatre so hit it up before or after a show.
author: Claire C.

description: Meh indeed.  The black bean(ish) clams were large, juicy, and nicely flavored with the sauce, but it went downhill from there.  The pot stickers' skin was spot-on, but the meat and veggies inside were very bland and tasted exactly like the frozen variety.  The ja jyang myun was also essentially flavorless...and very greasy.
author: Eric F.

description:
Good Korean-Chinese food. Black bean noodle is delicious.  

Btw, the disposable chopsticks they give you are awful. Either they are just really cheap and cutting corners or they just want the non-chopstick users to suffer. The chopsticks are bent AND bend as you use. Very annoying. FYI.
author: Bayarea K.

description:
I've passed by SW restaurant a gazillion times and never even thought to give it a try b/c who eats at a Chinese restaurant in J-town? So, apparently I've been missing out in all the 27 years of my life. 

Came here on a Friday at around 9:30PM after HH at Izakaya Lounge. 

FOOD: 
*Starter: Kimchee (Free) - Not like the typical Korean kimchee. SW's version is less acidic and less spicy, probably because it isn't fermented as long. It was good though. 
*Dry Chicken Wings (2x): MmMmMm. Hot, crunchy, moist, spicy, sweet, garlicky = Enough said. Just as good as San Tung's! 
*Dry Fried Squid (2x): HOLY MOLY! I've never had chinese calamari done this way. On the bottom of the platter was a sauce made with soy sauce, vinegar, ginger, garlic, and jalapeno. Then, they topple it with calamari that's light, crisp, and tender. This way the sauce doesn't make the calamari soggy....so simple, but genius. 
*Clams in Black Bean Sauce (2x): The clams were a good decent size and were super tender. Normally, black bean sauce can be very salty, but in this dish it wasn't; you can actually "taste" the clams. 
*Noodles in Black Bean Sauce: The home-made noodles were done al-dente. Not a huge fan of black bean sauce in general, so this dish was just ok for me. 
*Seafood Noodle Soup: Didn't try this dish, but there was huge amounts of seafood (shrimp, scallop, calamari, etc). 
*Peashoots w/ Garlic (2x): Peashoots were super fresh and wasn't overcooked, so it was still crisp. There was just enough garlic to add the garlic flavor w/o it being to overpowering. 
*Dry Fried Green Beans (2x): MmMmM...another good dish. But, then again all anything fried is good though right? The green beans were lightly fried and then tossed with sauce soy sauce vinegar concoction which balanced out the oiliness of the beans. 

SERVICE (-1 Star): Sub par. We arrived at 9:30 and the restaurant closes at 10 PM. When we were ordering the waitress was very impatient, kept rolling her eyes, and pointed to her watch several times. No surprises here, I'm use to having rude service in chinese restaurant unless you're in PF Chang's which of course is NOT considered a chinese restaurant. So, you go there for the good food and not the service. 

As you know, San Tung can get very crowded, so SW is a great alternative to go to. 

BTW, the food here is dirt CHEAP. We had 2 orders of everything except for the soup and it came out to $11/person including tip for 10 people. WOOT! 

I'll be back... :)
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I visited here about 9 years ago and remembered that their plum sauce noodles (jajangmyun - or some places call it black bean sauce noodles) was pretty good.  I wasn't a huge fan of this kind of noodles before, but my husband loves it and noodle texture is extremely important to him.  We would frequent Chef Wang in South San Francisco for their  jajangmyun which my husband thought was the best in the city, so I thought I'd take him here to compare as San Wang makes their own noodles from scratch.  

He was truly a happy camper and thought these noodles were the best in SF so far (haven't tried that many yet, hah).

Along with sharing the jajangmyun, we ordered a small hot and sour soup, and potstickers, all for approximately $22 + tip.  They give you a free bowl of kimchee to start with.

4.5 stars - jajangmyun

3.5 stars - The hot and sour soup, it was decently good.  It had a good spice to it and right amount of vinegar, but had too much of the shrimp, black mushrooms, and bamboo shoots in it.  Some people would love the value of having the extra amount of ingredients in it, but I like the soup and had to keep picking off the items and putting them aside because I had too much of it already.

2 stars - The potstickers - We were hoping to get the best tasting pot stickers ever, but as we were picking them off the plate, they would fall apart because there were small cracks in the dough.  Small detail, but aside from that too, the dough texture was a little pasty.  It tasted okay, but I would most likely skip on ordering the pot stickers there next time around. 

Thank you san wang for having the noodles taste the same as it did 9 years ago.  I can still hold my head up high without another "I told you things you've had years ago won't taste good anymore" and can trust at least some of my recommendations from the past.
author: W. L.

description:
My Favorite Korean Chinese Restaurant.
 
This past Sunday, I dined here for dinner with a group of friends.  We ordered typical Korean Chinese dishes like Jajang Myun and Tang Soo Yuk (sweet & sour pork), and a host of vegetarian dishes.  I've had better Korean Chinese in Seoul, but San Wang's food is better than I've had at any Korean Chinese restaurant in NYC and NJ.
 
The Jyajang Myun had shrimp and ground pork in it.  The Tang Soo Yuk wasn't drenched in sweet and sour sauce, which is good.  I liked their breaded and lightly fried string beans.
author: Hideki K.

description:
love this place, food and service are great.

best dishes (so far) mongolian beef, chinese broccoli w/plum sauce, moo shu pork and sweet & sour soup.

you must try it!
author: Luis Alberto R.

description:
Came here for dinner with some people from school because my professor told us that this was the BEST chinese food in the city. I'm chinese, but my standards for chinese food are pretty low (i.e. I think Mr. Chau's is pretty damn good), so I knew I'd like it no matter what.  But really....this place is GOOD!  I don't know about the BEST chinese food in SF, but overall every dish we ordered was a HUGE serving and reallllly yummy.  The best dish was the san wang clams.  If you like clams you'll LOVE this dish.  

I would definitely come back here again!
author: Cindy K.

description: i'm in Japantown, and what do i go to as my default place? a Chinese restaurant! over the past few years, it's getting more and more crowded, so be prepared. of course, parking is pretty bad, but i know i'm just stating the obvious. the decor is definitely a lot more attractive since they remodeled, but the bathrooms still work; just somehow wish they were able to expand just on the bathrooms alone. food-wise, by far the best Chinese restaurant in the area...at least within a half-mile. recommendations: fried beans (!), eggplant, general's chicken, fried chicken wings, hand-made noodles, fried flounder...despite the parking/decor problems, i seriously forgot how good this place is.
author: Mike C.

description: They no longer carry chow fun, the mongolian beef was flavorless yet seemed to have more MSG than it used to, and the final straw was the pot stickers - those used to be fairly decent, but I spat out my first bite.  It was free so I can't complain too much, but I think next time I'll pass.
author: Sus... B.

description: My favorite Chinese Restaurant ever!!!! Interestingly enough it is Korean owned and has some Korean dishes...also interesting is the fact it's located in Japantown. Hmmm Either way they have great food and I've been going there since I was a little kid!!! They family or shall I say group of Brother's that own it are very nice and have been with the establishment since the 70's. They have awesome Mongolian Beef, Chow Fun, House Fried Rice and Hot & Sour Soup!!!!!
author: Eddie G.

description:
Dry fried chicken, San Wang soup noodles, Chow mein, are some of the staples that I always order from this place.  The secret sauce that they use for the chicken is also used in their fish, scallops,and squid.  The sauce is made with Honey, garlic, peppers, sometimes frozen carrots and peas,  In either case, it is a very good base for eating copious amounts of rice or noodles.  Some people may not appreciate this Korean/Chinese fusion as much as San Tung in the sunset district but I do have cravings for their saucy chicken wings and flavorful noodles.  

Pros:  Huge portions!, Big Screen T.V., upstairs has room for large groups.
Cons:  Parking is almost as bad as Chinatown!
author: Curtis L.

description:
I am giving this place 4 stars because of the size of their dishes and their staff.  The dishes are pretty big.  And whom I think is the owner, is super nice.  The food prep was also super fast.  They carried out our dishes and I was like... wait thats ours??  I couldnt have been more than 5 minutes.  

The food, though, was OK.  I think the bread that cake with the Peking duck was just tortillas... hahhahahha.  I cant really think of anything that I ate there as especially good.  But I will definitely come back and try their noodles and other dishes.
author: Janet S.

description:
What I most like about San Wang is that you can't really find too many Korean-Chinese style restaurants.  I ate there last weekend and ordered the following dishes: 

*Noodles with black bean sauce
*San Wang noodle soup
*Garlic chicken 
*Spicy shrimp in orange sauce

The food was excellent and I highly recommend these dishes. Great place to go with friends and family.  I think it's been around for over 20 years and they are known for their hand-made noodles.  

In sum, two thumbs up!
author: Di W.

description: If I could give this place zero stars I could. Don't even try to go here unless you are Asian. Well I take that back, if they aren't busy they will take your money. Went there today, there were plenty of empty tables, placed a simple order and began waiting..and waiting. In the meantime at least 4 tables came in ordered and were served food. We were there 40 minutes and the rude waiter did not even bring my drink.Needless to say we are going somewhere else for lunch! It's a shame..we are good tippers!
author: Suebee B.

description:
I remember when they had a restaurant on Clement St 17 years ago.  This restaurant has been opened for close to 30 years and I remembered it to be very good.  Please do not even compare this restaurant to San Tung or mentioned this restaurant in the same sentence.  If I had to choose between the 5.99 dim sum place in Chinatown or this place, I would really have to choose the 5.99 dim sum place.

Ino sushi was closed today so we ended up going here.  This is by far one of the worst Chinese restaurant that I have ever been to.  Dom, my friend sitting to my left on my profile pic chose this restaurant.  I should have known better.  I don't think he can pick a good restaurant if it hit him on the head.  What a mistake that was.  Brian P. said this is one of his favorite restaurants in the city.  Maybe in the city of Tulsa, Oklahoma.  I swear I am going to start doing random drug tests in my office.   I am about to fire him for even recommending this restaurant.  Brian P.  I am going to test you for drugs and then fire you.  hahhaahhah

TERRIBLE...........here's why.

Hot and sour soup.  Saw a couple of flies in the soup so we had to return it.  I don't mind bugs in the food.  I am not that picky.  If your food is good..........I can overlook it.  Things like this happens in all restaurants. We changed it and got the seafood soup.  It was tasteless.

Potstickers........tasted like frozen potstickers

Mushu Pork........Should have been called mushy pork.  The pork, egg, cabbage was very mushy and slimy.  The skin was hard.  It needed to be steamed.

Dry fried chicken..................exactly as it sounds.  Dry, Fried, Chicken.  It was tasteless.

Dry fried shrimp..................tasted ok but it wasn't something I would ever crave again in this life time.

Braised string beans.........it was fresh but the mushrooms were extremely salty but the beans weren't?  

Total price was 59.00

My friend Dom treated.  I don't know whether to thank him or kill him.
author: jason g.

description:
Comparing San Wang (SW) to San Tung (ST) is the question of the day!  I'd have to say it's interesting to see how the Yelpers in SF view San Wang vs. San Tung, given the copious number of reviews on these two hwagyo heavyweights in our City.  Having been to San Tung many times, I thought it'd be helpful to also look at how San Wang would measure up in the hwagyo department.  I've also heard that the Korean Consulate of San Francisco in Pacific Heights is partial to San Wang, so I thought that this endorsement would bode pretty well for San Wang.  Hmmm..meh.  I've experienced better!

1.  SW KIMCHI BETTER THAN ST:  there was no waiting crowds in front of San Wang, so I thought that would be indicative of the popularity and quality of the place.  However being an open diner, I came in anyways and was promptly seated.  They bring kimchi, but no onions.  That's ok, considering that San Wang is in the middle of Jtown.  Actually, their kimchi tastes slightly more right, crunchy in the right notes..just about right in terms of doneness.  ST's always tastes a little more underdone.  Either way though, both places' kimchi tastes shelf-ready and not homemade.

2.  JAJANGMYUN (SW NOT AS GOOD AS ST) following my JJM standard:

*  Ratio of sauce to noodles:  SW's is a little less, and there is no garnish of cucumbers here.  I don't taste much onions here.

*  Vegetables, meat plentiful:  there isn't much in the way of identifiable vegetables, and the server said they only had it in pork.  Couldn't they make it just as easily with beef or shrimp?  

*  Texture, taste and color of sauce:  was slightly lumpy, and had a slight sheen of oil on the top.  Extremely bland, and the color is off-putting.  The pork flavor doesn't add much to the sauce.

*  Noodle quality and bite:  tastes slightly off, overcooked and surprisingly gummy.

*  Balance of sauce to noodles:  ST leans towards being more generous in noodles.  

3.  JAMPONG (SW  UNDERPERFORMS COMPARED TO ST):  the jampong at SW has a harsh ginger aftertaste, leaning towards heavy and flavoring everything including the soup.  It also is watery at times, although certainly not as oily as I expected.  The noodles again do not taste as fresh.  I had to add some hot chili sauce and kimchi to kick up the flavor, and that is a negative.

4.  GAMPONGGI (SW  NOT AS GOOD AS ST):  the gamponggi is not as glazed in the rich garlic sauce and peppers, nor does it glisten in color.  The color of the crunchy outside is rich though, and it on appearance seems appealing.  However, the garlic scallion sauce on top doesn't add much to the flavor, although every bite is certainly crunchy.  It is dry, and often at times you'd have to add kimchi with your chicken to add moisture.  Dipping it in chili sauce may save it from the not too intense garlic sauce, which isn't particularly generous either.

5.  IN SUMMARY WHY SW IS NOT A MUST VISIT:  overall, SW doesn't perform as well as I thought it would in the hwagyo trinity.  =P  I'm extremely underwhelmed despite the hype, and I'd definitely would not recommend SW to anyone looking for hwagyo food with flavor.  However, I did see some Chinese Chinese (not Chinese Korean) and Filipinos ordering the dry garlic fried black pepper crab on the tables behind me, which looked delicious.  Perhaps SW's forte is in Chinese Chinese food is the genre here, rather than hwagyo after my experience here.
author: JC K.

description:
A solid Chinese restaurant in Japantown. Inexpensive and really good jajangmyun.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
BIG portions for a great price! That's always a winning combination with my family. 

Although my entire family of 6 + 3 significant others = 9 was not here that night, the 4 of us that were there sure ate like a large party! My dad frequents this place often with his co-workers for lunch, so he knew the good stuff. We ordered the following: Dry fried chicken, clams, chili shrimp, gai laan (chinese broccoli) and their special handmade noodle dish/chow mein. Before we could even finish our first cup of tea or our first plate of complimentary kim chee, our dishes started flowing out of the kitchen and onto our table!

The noodles were first - a little oily, but still better than your average chow mein dish. The dry fried chicken is one of their specialties, and I can taste why. The chicken was very crispy and hardly dripping with oil, unlike some fried chicken I've had at other Chinese restaurants. And the sweet and spicy sauce with jalapenos that they served on top of this dish was a yummy compliment! 

Large pieces of fried shrimp covered in another sweet and spicy red sauce had just the right kick for my taste buds. The clams came out on a large dish and were covered with oyster sauce (?) They were OK - a little too much sauce for me. But that didn't stop me from eating about 15 of them! And the Chinese version of one of my favorite vegetables made me feel a little better about stuffing myself with carbs (we had steam rice, too) and fried food. 

This place is minimally decorated, and only has one dining area. But the staff is friendly and the food is quick. We spent about $56 bucks for a dinner for 4 (not including tip), and had tons of leftovers. 

Beware: parking is difficult. But maybe the huge flat screen t.v. showing a sports game (basketball that night) will ease your stress?
author: Kimberly S.

description: The food was horrible. Every dishes' taste was off. Never had such a bad experience eating Chinese food. Turns out this Chinese restaurant is owned by a Korean owner so they made the taste more similar to Korean food. If you are looking for a good Chinese/Taiwanese restaurant, look somewhere else!
author: Karen L.

description:
Been to this place a couple times before and keep forgetting to Yelp it! It looks like a hole in the wall place and has a 2nd floor for more seating. We got seated upstairs and I think the waitress forgot about us because it took them forever to come and take our order (but the food made up for it). 

We ordered: 

Steamed pot-stickers: these were okay but I would have preferred them fried! 
Mongolian Beef: very flavorful and I think they even added some mushrooms to it. 
Sweet and sour Shrimp: I like!!!! The shrimp was still crispy even with the sweet and sour sauce all over it. 
Deep fried chicken: it had a garlic kick to it =) 
Hot Spiced Bean Curd: Really good but not spicy enough for me. 
Black noodles (not the correct name for it): really fresh  

Would come back to try other stuff ... oh yeah the parking is hard to find but then again it's San Francisco!
author: Jenny M.

description: Great food, fast and thorough service, right by japantown if you want to walk around there! cool location. Good spicy foods!
author: trevor l.

description:
I'm trying really hard right now to start talking about San Wang's without mentioning its more popular, more Yelper-approved version.

Okay, I'm gonna stop trying now. 

It's hard not to put San Tung's and San Wang's together in a side-by-side comparison when you've dined at the two simply because there are so little restaurants in the Bay Area that specialize in Chinese cuisine from this particular region (ironically called the San Tung region). San Tung is a place of mountains and cold weather so of course warm foods that are starchy, soupy and spicy are more common in the diet than summery dishes like vegetables and meats.

With that said, San Wang's is definitely not bad if you're in the area and wanting a hearty bowl of hand-pulled noodle soup and tasty chicken wings. I disagree (respectfully, since I'm classy like that) with those who claim that San Wang's chicken wings can't hold a candle to San Tung's. I don't think the two are really comparable. San Tung's chicken wings are fried and then doused in a honey sweet glaze while San Wang's are batter fried and served way crunchier than San Tung's version with chopped up garlic and green onions in a soy sauce-y/garlicky sauce. Being more of a savory than sweets fan (well, maybe when it comes to meats), I actually prefer San Wang's.

The hand pulled noodles are ridiculous. In a good way. That's where it ends, though. If I could somehow just have, literally, the fresh, chewy noodles from San Wang's - yes, sans the broth, sans the garnishes, just the naked noodles, and have them served in San Tung's soups, I would seriously go to TOWN with that badass bowl of noodles right there. So it's probably made obvious now that San Wang's soups are lacking and a little more on a bland side, so my advice is to always order it spicy and not mild because the spices really lend to almost all the flavor of the soups.

The dumplings (jiao zhi) have a more homemade essence to them with the thicker skin, but are still tasty. Unless your Chinese mom can make those in her sleep . . . then you should pass.

So, in short - get the noodles (spicy version, always), get the wings if you aren't used to the San Tung's variety or prefer savory/garlicky over the sweet. Oh, and good luck with parking. But hey, know that there's hardly ever a wait at San Wang's and that's something that San Tung's definitely can't top. :)
author: Betty W.

description: I've read mixed reviews about this place and because it was very close to my Hotel I decided to give it a shot..  I've ordered 3 dishes: Sweet and Sour chicken, Schezuan chicken and some noodles. The food was fairly nice but the service was not... The service was slow and the waiter couldn't tell between the Schezuan chicken and the Sweet and Sour chicken.. He brought the Schezuan chicken and told us it was the Sweet and Sour chicken, after we waited 10 mins for the "Schezuan chicken " he brought the dish and told us the kitchen got him confused.... Really? How can you work in a resultant and have no idea how the dishes looks a like?   I was not impressed with the service at all...
author: Jerry J.

description:
Man has this place gone downhill!  San Wang used to be my family staple for gatherings and special occasions.  I realized this past week why we no longer come here.  We arrived about 45 minutes before closing time so my theory is that they were rushing to close up shop, but there is no excuse for the poor quality of food they served us:

1. We ordered the gampongki (dry chicken wings) and they were totally undercooked.  I took a bite and the meat was cold, pink, and raw on the inside.  Salmonella anyone? No thanks.  

2.  Have you ever tasted a salt lick?  I have. It's called GiaGiangMyun at San Wang (noodles with seafood & pork).  You'll need a few gallons of water to rehydrate after eating a bowl.

3. Jampong (spicy seafood noodle soup) was way underseasoned. i had to add almost an entire shaker of salt to make it edible. 

It was as if they took all the salt from one dish and added it to the other.  i was tempted to mix them together to balance it out.  It sounds nasty but it would have been better than eating them separately. It all ends up in the toilet anyway, right?
author: Ray K.

description:
This is one of the places my dad would take us when we were kids for jajang myun and jahm pohng.  I hadn't been here in about 15 years.  I haven't had jajang in a few years after an ill-fated trip to Zazang on Geary.  Was craving hand-pulled noodles so we got into the car and headed off to Japantown.  I ordered jajang and steamed dumplings to go.  Service was not great.  At home as I dumped the noodle block into a bowl with the dark sauce chock full of onions, I started having doubts.  I finished about half of the noodles and three of the lackluster, thick-skinned dumplings.  I put the leftovers in the fridge and am thinking now that they're going straight into the garbage.  

Alas, I can't think of a single remaining restaurant in SF where I can get decent jajang - fresh noodles in a tasty black bean-plum (salty sweet) sauce with the right proportion of good quality pork and zucchini (not full of onion filler) with crisp cucumber slices on top balanced by a nicely acidic side of kimchee.  Golden City was THE place but is now closed. San Tung puts seafood in their jajang, which I don't like.  Oh, well.  Maybe some place in the East Bay or South Bay will live up to my memories...  Or maybe, my palate has gotten too precious from living in SF for too long.
author: Esther R.

description:
Today my sister and I drove up and down Geary Blvd debating on whether we should eat at San Wang (today is the opening day after their remodel) or if we should  try out a new restaurant that was advertised in the Korean newspaper. After a small debate, we decided to try out their JaJiang Myun at the new restaurant since we figured that San Wang wouldn't have it. (Apparently, they do.)  So, that was a big mistake.  It tasted like chow mein with black sauce on top.  So, we decided to try out their Kang Poong Ki.  It was quite decent until my sister found 2 pieces of long human hair in the drumstick.  

San Wang has the best dried fried chicken, dried fried eggplant, dried fried fish and dried fried anything.  
We vow to never go to another Chinese-Korean Restaurant.  We'll stick to San Wang.  We'll go back soon to check out what they have done to the place.  2 thumbs up.  

Their Kimchi is also great.  Service is tolerable.  Korean and Chinese speaking employees.
author: Edward C.

description:
This is a place I come with with my family to EAT with a capital E.

This is a bad place for a diet.

This is a bad place to avoid fried, dry fried, deep fried...etc.

This is a great place for loads of meat dishes cooked in the aforementioned methods accompanied by as much steamed rice as you can take.

Been coming here or to the one on Clement in the 20's (now closed) for close to twenty years. I remember not my first time. 

I won't bother discussing the decor, etc. It's a Chinese restaurant. It's not a fancy one. It's not pristine, but I've never gotten sick there.

A side story if you will (since I just remembered it):

I once saw a waiter get tripped up and drop a bowl of soup all over a woman's fur coat. The woman freaked out and the manager had to come out and assure her they would pay for the cleaning. My thoughts...uh, furs are not PC and what the heck were you thinking bringing an expensive garment here? Stupid. The air alone is not unlike a Korean restaurant. Upon return home, clothes should go directly to the laundry. 

Anyways, they could spill soup on me and I'd still come back.

My fave (aka always order) dishes:

Hot & Sour Soup - hot, sour, loaded with meat, tofu, and veggies
Dry Fried Chicken - greasier, more spicy and more garlicky version of San Tung's Chicken
Sauteed Meatballs - Crispy fried on outside, tender on inside. Served with gravy and veggies.
San Wang clams - spicy sauce...so good...esp on rice...memories of fighting my dad for the biggest clams and trying to eat more clams (bigger stack of shells on plate) than him...I usually did not win...

San Wang has a dry fried version of almost every ingredient they serve. I've probably tried all of them at one point or another.

It's a wierd concept to go to Japantown for Chinese food but hey, whatever works.
author: Mike C.

description:
I'm a fan simply because the price is super affordable and taste is better than the usual Chinese restaurant. It is also impressively clean and the service is good. 

I love the fried chicken with garlic sauce, noodles with black plum, the seafoods with mushroom and the soup. Kimchi is complimentary :)..

Will definitely go back here if i'm craving for some good, affordable Chinese food.
author: ASIANDIVAH A.

description:
Very good Korean-influenced Chinese food. Milder and more flavorful than the food at the cursed Cantonese restaurants that plague the city. There is absolutely nothing wrong with good Cantonese food; unfortunately, the kind that prevails in the city is the wrong kind: oily, deep fried, poor ingredient quality, uncreative. The same can be said of most American food, I suppose - and maybe these Cantonese restaurants are simply cooking for that audience. But I digress.

San Wang is known for its dry-fried series of dishes (beef, shrimp, chicken, etc.) Dry fried beef is the best. They also have great soups - try the San Wang soup noodles or Ta Lo noodles. You can taste the clams in the broth, the ingredients are fresh, quantity is plentiful, and you don't feel thirsty or sleepy after eating. That's because they go easy on the MSG (or they don't use MSG at all - I did not detect any).

Service is decent as well, and so is the price. We have been going here for years and will keep coming back.
author: W. T.

description:
After eating somewhere else my friend brought us here to do more drinking.  I was confused since it was a pretty ordinary looking Chinese restaurant with bright florescent lights.  Then I learned it was run by Koreans and was a sorta hybrid Chinese/Korean restaurant.

So let me get to the interesting thing right off.  They have this weird spirit (hard liquor) that I've never heard of.  I think my friend pronounced it "coran joo" or something.  It came in this ceramic thing and it was warm.  At first I thought, "i dunno, Chinese moonshine - i'm scared...."  You know - it was actually pretty good.  Had a slight herbal taste to it, but also had a slight flavor that I find in a really good scotch.  So I definitely recommend trying it - I thought it was pretty well crafted and not weird at all.

The food was also pretty good.  Kinda' reminded me of this family-style Chinese place in the Sunset called "8 Immortals" which is also pretty good for that type of food.

Anyway - yeah - recommended if you're in that Chinese food mood or want to try that "coran joo."
author: Russel H.

description:
Yummy:

Jajang-min: black bean noodles.
Jam-pong: spicy noodle soup w seafood & pork.
Sweet & Sour chicken and/or pork.

Next time, I'm going to ask them if they have the Chinese chive dish.
author: HY L.

description:
20 years ago San Wang & Kams was the sh*t on this side of GG Park. Both places were generous and reasonably priced. Kams gave you lots more, but San Wangs had better quality, hand pulled noodles, and stayed open till after 10pm. (had our wedding rehearsal dinner here and the padre dug it!)

Now Kams is OUT, but San Wangs is still hangin' in there tough.
They're not as good as before, but I can say I've never had a bad meal here. Portions are still fairly generous. Their Hot & Sour Soup is awesome, and I don't particularly care for Hot Sour soup. I like their Chicken with Double Mushrooms and the Clams in Blk Bean Sauce. But you have to try their hand pulled noodles in Spicy Plum Sauce. Hand pulled means made from scratch, by hand! I can't explain it... you gotta watch reruns of Yan Can Cook to check it out. It's also pretty cool that they give you some free kim chee to get the appetite going.
OK, so it IS in Japantown, so prices are a bit high, but not outrageous. It's a little cramped in there, but the service is pretty good. The specials are posted on the handwritten wall posters in English, baby!

AND you got that public parking garage under the pagoda that is totally dirt cheap!

San Wangs is COOL... check it out!
author: Rick V.

description:
I freaking love this place!  Their portions are HUGE and everything I've ever had here has been tasty!  I'm especially fond of their black bean chicken, Schezuan beef, and anything that says dry fried.  Mmmmmmmm!

The only problem is that I eat so much here, I tend to feel sick and have a serious case of food coma afterward.  I can't hold that against the good people of San Wang though, I can only blame myself.
author: Cersei T.

description:
My first thoughts about this place, a Chinese restaurant in Japantown amongst all the Korean restaurants. Must be decent to survive there. 

The food was actually pretty good, big portions, fresh veggies and seafood. I liked that they added mushrooms to all the meat and veggie dishes (that's because I'm a big mushroom fan). The salted spicy spareribs were delicious! It wasn't a fried pork chip like it is at some places. It was fried just enough that it was still moist inside, tossed with some green onions and oil, yumm, good flavor. Clams and honey walnut prawns were a hit with the bf's fam. I'm allegrice to seafood, but if they said it was good, so it must be good :)
I would come back again. Saw on the other diners tables a bunch of Chinese/Korean dishes, will try next time
author: Flavia H.

description:
Something about winter weather makes me crave some serious carbs.  This afternoon, my friend and I went to San Wang to grab an early dinner.  I usually get one of the hand-pulled noodle dishes, so it's nice to bring a San Wang virgin along to see what else is on the menu.

My friend is a big fan of wonton soup, so she went with a small size.  It was large enough to feed one person as a main dish or two people as a side.  It was loaded with wontons, shrimp, chicken, broccoli, carrots and mushrooms ... quite healthy and fresh.  There was a bit of intrigue for a moment when we tried to figure out what sorts of meat were used in the wonton (we decided it was BBQ or roasted pork).  Overall, it was acceptable.

We ordered steamed and pan-fried pot-stickers.  If you order steamed, they give you eight (8) pieces.  If you order fried, they punish you for choosing something unhealthy by giving you only six (6) pieces.    Don't really know if that is why, but those are the real amounts that come out for each order.  Dumplings were okay, but nothing to write home about.  If you're trying to talk yourself out of getting an appetizer, please know that these are absolutely missable.  Get something else.

My noodles with black bean sauce was pretty good, but definitely not as great as the stuff I grew up with or had during my visits to Korea.  The noodles had a nice firm and chewy texture with an appropriate thickness to accommodate the type of sauce I ordered.  

The bean sauce itself was pretty decent, taste-wise, but sort of a let-down as far and quality and variety of ingredients.  The actual "ingredients" of the sauce consisted of 3 shrimp, loads of onion, and a smattering of chewy, dry pork nuggets.  Not too impressive.

A prior reviewer did make a very true point about how one gets what one pays for.  I think overall (except for the dumplings) ... this place is a pretty good deal.

I'll go back again with yet another San Wang virgin...
author: Jenny K.

description:
No, they don't take reservations.

Yes, the lady on the phone hung up on me when I asked her.

me = wtf


After having someone talk to me on the phone like that.....no thank you. 

Sam Wang, it's time for us to part ways. 

Good riddance.
author: Kay T.

description:
My co-worker had a thing with the Chan-pong noodle here, and I enjoyed lunch items most of the time when visited with him.
I liked something like seafood over rice or beef dish.

Never had fried dish until today... yet most people here recommended this place as a grease shop, so I ordered the dried fried chicken for the good reviews

Yes, the chicken is all right. 
Crispy and tasty with veg toppings.

Yet, my expectation for  'baby Shrimp with Hot Pepper Sauce ' was unfulfilled. First, the shrimp isn't baby shrimp! Second, the shrimp is fried!  it should say so if you gonna fry!!
Then coming from Japan, I imagined 
red chili pepper sauce covering the shrimps. However, here fried shrimp was mingled with sliced jalapeno..Third, it is with frozen carrots and peas....Fourth, it's not even spicy regardless the number of jalapeno slices.


Well, I will stick to something non-fried next time like I used to. I still haven't tried the chan-pong or jyajya-meng.

Looking forward to them!
author: Chacha M.

description: I had to edit this review and add another star after I dined in and tried other items which was actually pretty good. The place was packed and service was horrible....one of the waiters literally rolled his eyes when we asked for something. OMG!! Anyway, this time i tried the salt & pepper calamari, sizzling rice soup, clams, mongolian beef and some other items i can't remember at the moment. I still prefer SanTung but this place is descent but I will NEVER order to go.
author: Deb C.

description:
Very rude service from the guy behind the counter. He was wearing glasses had very ugly hair and an ugly face. Asked him to change the channel to a basketball game and he gave me attitude and slam
med the remote on the counter. That dbag needs to learn some manners.
author: Tony L.

description:
Disclaimer: I realize that I may be way too partial towards San Tung to give San Wang a fair shake.  

The dry fried chicken wings are good but they are closer to regular fried chicken than to the dry fried wings at San Tung.  ST's are sweet and glazed while SW's are drier and not-sweet at all.  SW's shrimp & leek/chive dumplings can't t hold a candle to ST's (sorry! I feel bad about this but it's true).  The hand-pulled noodles were pretty good, but I still like San Tung's better.

On the other hand, parking is easier for San Wang and the wait is not ridiculously long.  However, I dare to say there could be a reason for that ...
author: Melinda C.

description:
Popped in here for a quick nibble - had the steamed pot stickers.  Shortly after I was done, the all to familiar after taste of "dirty old wok" came through loud and clear - major turn off.  

That's why I test out a new Chinese place with something steamed rather than completely stir fried.  So if that gaggy taste came though with steamed pot stickers - yikes - then I know that everything else will taste like that.
author: Cinnamon Z.

description: Sang Wang is known for their special noodle dishes. Their "black bean" noodle is probably the best in san francisco, and N.California. Noodles are hand-made at the restaurant, reason why noodles are so good :)   Atmosphere is ok, simple. Service is good, and price is pretty cheap.
author: ji k.

description:
Did I mention hand-pulled noodles?  Can't live without 'em.
(Thanks! ji k for posting that pic of the thing I always get when I go there)
author: Bruce L.

description: This restaurant was highly recommended by the concierge at our hotel. We weren't sure about a Chinese restaurant in Japantown at first. Then we walked in and ordered the food. Everything we ordered was delicious. It may be cliche but this was the best pork fried rice I've ever had next to my childhood friends mother who is Chinese and always cooked for me. The service was great although we weren't looking for a lot of attention or interaction. It was the best $30 meal we've had and topped the list against some very big restaurants we have eaten at in many big cities in the US and abroad. Highly recommend this one.
author: Emily J.

description: Best Chinese restaurant in the San Francisco.  shrimp w/black bean sauce, shrimp w.hot pepper sauce, etc.  Everything tastes great, and very nice, quick, friendly service.  I love this place.
author: Charlie W.

description: oh boy..time to eat..time to enjoy a new place. After finding a parking spott in Japan Town, we bolted into San Wang. My Asian friend had eaten here the year before and said it was really good. She was right, it was over the top fantastic. Big (as in BIG) portions.They have a very large menu and plenty of Veggie dishes to choose from. Nothing really fancy about the place as far as decor goes, but it is clean and simple. Wonderful food. This is where the locals eat. We made friends with the Asian couple seated next to us and shared some of our food with them. Our server was busy, but gave us plenty of attention and was prompt. I love San Wang !
author: Donna S.

description: San Wang is a korean chinese restaurant with huge portions of food so go with at least 3 and order family style.  The dry fried chicken was delish (crisy and savory), the jajangmyun had the right texture and taste, the mongolian beef yummy.  The soup dishes I had on both my visits were really bland so I am writing them off my order repetoire. we'll be back!
author: Teresa T.

description: Friends took us here last week for dinner, and all I can say is this place is a BIG hit with us!  Their fried chicken, spicy shrimp and scallops totally rocked!!  And they are super reasonable - $47 for entrees for 5 people.  Can't beat that!
author: Maile N.

description:
The food is cheap.  I mean CHEAP.

Ever hear the term: "You get what you pay for?"

Well, cliches aren't just invented for no reason.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Alright boys and girls ... San Tung too crowded for you? This place may be a very good second fiddle.

The Ja Jang Mein here is great (the black bean noodle dish), I think so far this place has the best bowl (maybe even better than the just closed 2 Sisters).

The water dumplings are good as well, but not as good as San Tungs.

And yes, this place is cheap and I didn't have to wait an hour for a table ... *Try it out!*
author: Alex C.

description:
Super yummy - and didn't cost a ton either!

I'm normally not a big chinese foodie, because I've been to a lot of *BAD* restaurants, but all the dishes were delicious.  The dry fried chicken was great, and I'd get the pot stickers again too (they were big enough to be an entree!).

Just be sure to enunciate when you tell your friends the restaurant's name, so they're not looking for "San Juan"!  :)
author: Kristel S.

description: They make the best Dry Fried Green Beans on the entire planet.
author: Wan T.

description:
Ok I remember that there used to be a San Wang in cupertino.. anyone remember this? but my dad told me the owner had brain cancer and passed away, God rest her soul. its sad because it closed down. i used to go there quite frequently (corner of prospect and sunnyale-saratoga)

ever since then, ive always had the nostalgic taste for their cashew nut chicken. i dunno, no one else ever makes it the same. theres something about that tenderness of the chicken. maybe its the korean influence? i dunno.

so heres the breakdown. the food is pretty good. the cashew nut brought back some good memories. portions of lunch specials was ok. i remember it used to be 6 bucks, but i guess w/ the crappy economy and me being gone for 4 years i guess prices go up. but the happy family... well it wasn't very happy at all. that rubbery, old squid... not much seafood.. and didn't clean out the shrimp. u can still see the nasty black intestine. ugh.

the chow mein (san wang chow mein), substituting the hand pulled noodles tho, i have to admit, was good, because the noodles were very chewy. i haven't had it a long time. but there was a LOT of like.. juice/sauce... not typical for a chow mein. that was my gripe for that.

and the spicy noodle soup... too much spicy kim chee taste.

the kimchee? dood it was regular cabbage.. very gross, very nasty. 

so anyway the food was good. the service was horrible. the waiter was korean and didnt' even speak chinese. the other guy was very rude. owner was pretty rude. but i guess its in san francisco what can i say.

well i should really give this place two and a half stars, but as always, i round up. minus 50 for crappy service though.
author: Rick L.

description: My family and I have been coming here for years. One dish we always seem to get is the dry fried chicken wings! I usually ask for the sauce on the side. Go hit this place up, the prices are not bad too!
author: Raphael S.

description: I took my friend there today since he never been here before.  The place was empty with only a few tables occupied.  We ordered dry chicken and beef with green onions with rice.  The entrees were tasty and we enjoyed them.  However the rice tasted old definitely not good.  When you dine here do not expect any service.  While we were dining, no one has came up to checked on us nor refill our water.  The Service really sucks here.
author: donald c.

description:
It's alright.
they remodeled the restaurant... but the food is still lacking flavor.
the only thing is if you care about quantity over quality.. then i guess this is the place for you.
author: Selina L.

description:
Like many of the other reviewers, I have been coming to San Wang for jiajiangmyun and jampong since I was a little girl. I love the princess prawns (mae-oon-sae-woo in korean) and have been ordering it for so long that the owners bring it out regardless of whether I order it.  As far as I know, there is no other place in SF to get handpulled noodles and it is really a unique spot.
Don't come here looking for fancy food, this is a great spot for a quick lunch or casual group dinner.
author: Marie K.

description:
If you're in Japantown, but craving something Asian, not quite Korean, but quite Japanese, and definitely not Chinese come to San Wang. I wouldn't make a special trip here on a weekday, but weekends sure!

Food is good, price is decent. Parking is questionable!
author: Michael C.

description:
By far my favorite Chinese restaurant in the city!

Came with 3 friends last night and ordered:

1. Noodles in Black Bean Sauce
2. Spicy, glazed shrimp
3. Sweet Pork
4. Half Peking Duck
5. Spicy Garlic Chicken Wings

The waiters were SO NICE and FRIENDLY and the food was awesome! My friend got a little too tipsy so the waitress kept on looking out for her, gave her tea, made sure she felt ok and liked the food etc. Great food and great service - hard to beat!
author: Brian H.

description: If you're Korean (like me) and craving Chinese-Korean (aka Shandong) food, then you'd better just get in line and wait at San Tung. The ja jang myun was just not quite right and while the portions were HUGE, the food itself wasn't worth taking home and reheating.
author: Anonymouse C.

description: Let me start off with the one and only plus, it was fast.  I do have a theory on that though.  Fast due to the fact that the didn't bother adding flavor to my meal.  I had the dried fried shrimp lunch (not so) special.  The shrimp were heavily coated and had NO flavor.  Spicy? Um, no.   The waiter forgot my soup, the one thing that might have had some flavor, and the rice was disgusting.  It was lumped together, crisp in the outside and gluey on the inside.  Anyone who claims to like anything dried fried here obviously hasn't been to San Tung.  Bleck, zero stars.
author: Brye L.

description: I've been coming for dine-in and takeout for years and this has been some if the best in the City. Anything dry fried on the menu is a signature piece for this restaurant, but the dry fried squid is the one to get if none of the others. Was just in the other day and there's something new with color plates and new bowls . . . not a good idea. I know of very few places that try to plate a dish on a color other than white and there's a reason why: Let the food do the talking. Let the colors and the food's own appearance speak for itself. You eat first with your eyes and it's a total distraction to see a sauce turn greenish black against the mauve color of a Pottery Barn close out plate - not serving platter. It's funny I rag on presentation, but this place does food so well that it doesn't need to try to take it up a notch with something that's a waste of money for the restaurant - unless the good everyday stuff is in the washer. I rate this place high for the food, so lemme get back to that. Get the hot braised fish and you'll want some extra rice just for all the awesome flavored sauce that it's swimming in. There are misses too here, far in between all the hits. Come, eat.
author: Tristan C.

description:
Their San Wang special soup noodles are the best!!!!!!!  The noodles are hand-pulled and fresh, not like those frozen kinds served at some asian restaurants.  The soup is very tasty, just a hit of spicy.  And the bowl is huge....full of clams, squid, beef, shrimp, lettuce, and much much more!  One bowl is enough for 2, 3, 4, or even 6 friends to share!

Their kung pao shrimp is sooo sweet and tasty.  You will want to dip that sauce all over your rice...and anything else.  Finally, their fried battered green beans makes ANYONE a veggie lover! 

The portion is generous to the price.  Our bill came out to be $16 per person.  That was for 6 plates for 6 people!!!  Really good deal!  Take you friends, family and foes....because this is definitely a place for everyone to enjoy a big tasty meal!
author: Alice T.

description:
Everything that's tasty at San Tung is bland and one-dimensional here -- the dry fried chicken, the noodles in plum sauce, everything. Even the hot and sour soup is bland. We have tons of leftovers right now, and we're kind of dreading eating them. 

I only wish the service were bland instead of wretchedly horrible.
author: Midori S.

description: You won't be disappointed.  I've gone here about 5 times so far and every time it has been a hit.  Tonight we ordered the dinner for two and it was so good and only $30.  They give you tea and Kim Chee while you wait.  First came the Won Ton Soup which was very fresh and was not loaded with salt, even the broccoli was crisp.  Later came Cashew Chicken then Sweet and Sour Pork.  I don't know what kind, but the rice was very good too.  This was enough food for 3 and maybe 4.  Will enjoy the left overs at lunch.  Recommended!!!  PS, it was very busy on a Saturday night and the staff was very attentive and sat us right away.
author: Don J.

description:
I've been eating here with my family on and off for over 10 years. Their San Wang clams are nice and spicy, though they could be spicier.  My family loves the dried fried chicken. All their noodle dishes are great. Their jajjangmyun is excellent.  They make their own noodles and you can taste the difference.

This is NOT your typical chinese restaurant. The food is good, though after the remodel I think everything jumped up a dollar or two. Plus, when we came back right after the remodel we were very disappointed, luckily we gave it another shot and everything was good again.

The owners are brothers who take turns cooking throughout the day. They're friendly and come out and say hi if they recognize you. Unfortunately my favorite waiter here left, so I can't really say anything definitively negative or positive about the service, only the food.
author: Tiff L.

description:
My Family and I have been coming here for more than 15 years.
The owners have changed throughout the years and so the food has sometimes become inconsistent, but when they're on point, the food is delicious and very good portions.
