I love the dry fried chicken (crisp skin, juicy meat, lots of garlic and spice off set by a sour/sweet/saly sauce), dry fried scallops, good kim chee, black been sauce noodles, clams with san wang sauce and mongolian beef.

Yes, it's a little dingy looking, mainly because of the carpet, but the place itself is fine.  Try it out!
author: Kat T.

description:
It was ok. I always rave about San Tung to my mother. My mother always says "San Tung is good, but San Wang is better." We set out to settle the question. 

I was pretty excited when we sat in the Chinese restaurant and it was filled with Korean people. I thought this may be some pretty good Cam-pong-gi (dry fried chicken :) Everything was just ok. The chicken lacked the flavor I am used to. It just did not have any "kick." The green bean tasted exactly like the chicken. Our potstickers fell apart. The salt and pepper pork was a little tough. Overall, I was not impressed. 

The only exception was the Ja-Ja mein. I've been eating noodles for over 30 years and this place tastes pretty close to grandma's. 

I would eat here if I happen to be in the area, but I wouldn't make a special trip....unless I was feining for some hella good Ja-Ja Mein. 

PS: I brought the left overs home to mom. Her reaction: "hey, this food tastes no good. what happen? tastes bad. maybe they change the cook"
author: Karen B.

description:
THE PROBLEM WITH (nearly) EVERY REVIEW OF THIS RESTAURANT...is that this is Korean-chinese, not Chinese, not Tourist-from-Kansas Chinese-American food....The difference is significant. The reason the place is packed is because Koreans come here to get the three or four stellar Korean-Chinese dishes the place is known for. This is comfort food Koreans crave: Tangsuyook, Ja-Jyang Myun, Champong....These are stellar here. 

The Korean President came here when he was in town for the handthrown noodles they make here! Its all about the noodles. Look around when the place is busy!
author: Ross J.

description: This place has thee worst jjang ppong and jajamyung! Their spicy clams are aiite but I rather get my korean/chinese noodles at San Tung, they never disappoint.
author: Anna S.

description:
San Wang is so awesome - we had the Jam Bong (sp?), Noodles in Black Bean sauce, the Sweet and Sour Pork, Clams in Black Bean Sauce and the Sweet/Spicy Shrimp and ALL WERE TO DIE FOR. 

The owner is such a nice guy too - had a nice chat with him about his family. All in all, great place and definitely coming back.

Make sure to get the Sweet/Spicy Shrimp!
author: Brian H.

description: When my old High School and SFSU college buddy comes to town. We always go to San Wang's. He introduced me to this place back in 1983. Absolutley love their spicy fried shrimp, the fried scallops, hot and sour soup and how can you not go wrong with beef broccoli. It is some good stuff. I think they changed the way they prepare their KimChee. This time it had a heavy sauce and really drowned out the cabbage. It was still good but had alot of sauce on it. Overall a good time and good food. Excellent.
author: Timothy M.

description: dried fried chicken and calamari were not crispy.  plum noodles were okay but it does look quite unappealing when presented.  biggest hits were the broccoli/beef and fried rice.  the waiter did an outstanding job; bringing cold water and checking on our teapot.  he checked on us several times during the meal.  i would give him five stars.
author: el h.

description: I have a vested interest in liking this place, as it's the closest chinese take-out to my apartment, but I've not been impressed. I enjoyed the General Tso's chicken, but most other dishes have been either too greasy or too salty, with little flavor other than salt. I doubt I'll go back again.
author: D V.

description:
I have revised my rating c/ the service like the food can really bite depending the day you come.  Most of the staff are cool, but some are "#@!*$ holes,"
e.g., this 1 waiter will screw up your order, argue that it was your fault, refuse to correct the order, & expect you to pay for the dish that you did NOT order due to the cotton in HIS ears ! ! !

The owner is cool c/ if he was there on that day I know he would have made it right w/o a hassle, but that waiter needs to have his "#!*$%" canned, ASAP ! ! !

I HAVE BEEN COMING HERE SINCE I was a KID.

I KEEP COMING BACK c/ NOTHING TASTEs LIKE the FOOD at SAN WANG & the HAND-PULLED NOODLEs ! ! !

I HAVE LIVED FROM 1 END of the BAY AREA to the OTHER; THEREFORE, I HAVE GOTTEN a CHANCE to EAT in a TON of CHINESE RESTAURANTs THROUGHOUT the BAY AREA & I SWEAR this is TRUE.
ALTHOUGH THERE are SOME REALLY GREAT CHINESE RESTAURANTs NONE STAND OUT the WAY SAN WANG does.
THERE is a COMMON THREAD of FLAVOR that RUNs THROUGH EVERY OTHER CHINESE RESTAURANT that I HAVE COME ACROSS, & I WISH I COULD do a BETTER JOB of DESCRIBING this "FLAVOR", but for GOOD or BAD, there is no MISTAKING the DIFFERENCE in TASTE at SAN WANG.
SAN WANG's BOLD & UNIQUE FLAVOR MAY NOT be for EVERYONE & their FOOD can be OCCATIONALLY INCONSISTENT, but I GIVE SAN WANG 5 out of 5 STARs c/ NO ONE CAN DENY that NOTHING TASTEs LIKE SAN WANG.

HERE are their SIGNATURE DISHEs:

1. DRY FRIED CHICKEN WINGs

2. BABY SHRIMP in HOT PEPPER SAUCE 

3. CHAM PONG:  The BEST, if you go on the RIGHT DAY.

4. CHA JANG MYUN:  The ABSOLUTE BEST, if you go on the RIGHT DAY
author: AHAB D.

description:
my family and i used to come here when i was waaaayyyy younger for their dry-fried chicken wings and noodles and dumplings. 

even though the food has gone a little downhill since the golden days, these chinese-korean folks still make the best dry-fried chicken wings in town. you heard me right. THE BEST. san tung is a far second to these wings and here are the reasons why: 

the wings are not sticky sweet, they're fried CRISP, with lots of scallions and garlic and a soy-garlic flavor marinated into the meat and bones, not coated like they do at san tung. you don't feel like you have to visit the dentist after dining here. there is little sugar in these wings, if at all.

the jajangmyun is decent (i still prefer the chinese version more with ground pork and braised tofu pieces), and most of the noodle dishes use hand-pulled noodles.

i'm so lucky i live only 3 blocks away from these folks. it's very good eats for a j-town chinese/korean establishment.
author: May T.

description: For the record, I give this place 3.5 stars. When I was younger, family outings to Japantown almost always inevitably ended up here, most notably for the Jajangmyun. Came back a few weekends ago with extended family from out of town, and was unimpressed with the lackluster service.. but had a change of heart, all thanks to the FOOD. Arrived cranky and hungry after walking around all morning, and left feeling content and full. Opted to order family style entree dishes instead of taking advantage of their lunch menu. Jajangmyun, Happy Family, Sweet&Sour Beef, and Mapo Tofu. OMG. The flavorful, generous portions totally made up for the atmosphere. Although we had to summon the ill dispositioned server(s) for rice bowls, for more tea, for the check... it was a-okay. This is one of those places where you come for the food. Just the food.
author: Mina S.

description:
omg omg omg! i found a fly in the white vinegar dispenser!!!! gross!!!! 

but you know what?!?! i'm still not going to deduct a star from san wang, because this is still my favorite 3 star restaurant!
author: Brian P.

description: Dumplings are legit, but yu xiang rou si (fish flavored pork) and hui guo rou (twice cooked porK) were shit. Great white people Chinese food, but too washed out for Chinese people. BUT!!! Dumplings are LEGIT
author: Troll F.

description:
This place offers extremely large portions of Korean-Chinese food for super cheap prices.  I never thought that I'd ever come to Japantown for Chinese food, but my parents and I stumbled upon this place one Sunday, and I have been a fan ever since.

My favorites:

- Dried fried chicken: These are so bad for you, but so sinfully good, especially with all the minced garlic and scallions found in the dish.
- Dumplings: These are filled with pork and tons of chives (beware of those after-meal burps!).  But the best thing about them is the handmade dumpling skins.  
- San Wang spicy noodle soup (popularly known in Korean as "jjampong"): It is so very comforting on a cold day.  Their spicy soup is filled with perfectly al dente hand-pulled noodles and tons of goodies like clams, shrimp, squid, sea cucumber (the only not-so-goody), pork, mushrooms, wood ear fungus, napa cabbage, and zucchini.  
- Noodles with plum sauce (popularly known in Chinese as "zhajiang mian" and in Korean as "jajangmyeon"): I'm not sure why they call it plum sauce because it's really a black soybean sauce.  They use their awesome hand-pulled noodles in this dish, and the sauce is not too overpowering.
- San Wang Chow Mein: This is exactly like the jjampong (ingredients-wise), except without the spicy soup, and the flavor is full of the heat of the wok. 

This place can be packed at the oddest hours when you would not think it would be (e.g. 3pm on a Sunday afternoon and 9:30pm on a Friday night).  I know this because I've been here at those exact hours!
author: Diane L.

description: I am typically not a fan of Chinese food, but I have to say I did like San Wang. It wasn't too salty or over sauced and they were able to accommodate a group of seven easily. We also ordered quite a bit of food and the bill only came out to be around $20 per person. Crazy, right?
author: J F.

description: So my friends and I came here for dinner during a reallly cold and rainy day... Since it was sooo cold, i decided to get Wonton soup and they had a variety of meat/seafood dishes with steamed rice... WELL, the WONTON SOUP SUCKS..... the wontons themselves had a weird tasting stuffing that had unrecognizable parts of vegetables perhaps? and indistinguishable tastes...like pork perhaps? but it also had broccoli, weird seafood things?, mushrooms, other fillers and shrimp that tasted that its definitely been NOT FRESH... it  had a really fishy taste to it and was the worst part of the soup... I couldn't finish my small portion.. so I decided to eat some of my friend's food.. I tried the dried fried chicken and it was decent and then i tried their walnut prawns.. which were not very good also (dude, even the walnuts tasted bad)...... my friends also did not enjoy the food that much either... and we had to ask the waiter twice to refill our water... SORRY but when its cold and warm soup is not edible... thats some bad ish going on..
author: Jenny N.

description: I wish I tried this place when I use to leave 3 blocks away.  When I was in the area I lived off of La Salsa and Hunan China on Divisadero.  Both places are pieces of crap.  The fried chicken is good here.  The next time I come back I need to try the black bean noodles.  I like this Korean-Chinese place better than that place on 14th called San Tung.  I don't know why people like that crap so much.  It bewilders my fatty tissues.
author: Fatty A.

description:
i really LOVE, love the spicy seafood noodles at san wang.  the noodles are fresh, you can taste it!  plus, ive seen them throw the fresh noodles into a pot!  the broth is really nice and not super thick where you can't can't really enjoy it, like it is at other places.  there's shrimp, clams, squid, sea cucumbers, chives, onions, some napa cabbage, and some dry chilies as well.  i usually take the dry red chilies out, because they are usually too spicy to eat.  this dish is WAY better than the spicy seafood noodles at san tung.  

i haven't really had anything else, besides the spicy seafood noodles and the dry fried chicken.  i actually prefer the chicken a bit more spicy, next time ill ask for extra hot and crispy and see how that goes.
author: Wendy S.

description: I've eaten asian food my whole fuckin life so i have to say, this place is the shit.  I work a few stores down from this place and ive eaten here for weeks straight at times.  I've had their entire lunch special (ends at 2pm) multiple times.  Infact im eating lunch there right now. Prices are decent priced and service is good. They also have this big ass tv screen in there for you to watch.
author: Kenny C.

description:
best jjajangmyun ever.. PERIOD
theres only been one time that it was BLAH.. offday i guess..
but every other time.. its has been good GOOD GOOD!!!
the mehwoon saewoo is excellent.. and the beef noodle soup thing reminds me of pho.. but instead of the vermicelli theres big noodles..

you gotta be careful though.. there are several things i realllllly dont like.. (learned the hard way thru trial and error).. i think one of the things i really didnt like was the garlic chicken.. 

maybe im a bit biased since ive been coming here since i was little.. and my family knows the owner and get along with the staff..
but the service is always A+++ and the food is (for the most part) good.. 
just be wary when its busy.. u gotta work hard to grab a server's attention..
author: monica c.

description: My aunt is supposedly a huge fan of this place and knows all the good stuff, so when she said she would take me to get some awesome chinese food, I really expected something better. The food was mediocre, unless sweet and sour everything is all thats needed to satisfy your taste bud. Nevertheless, you can tell their noodles were freshly made, so if your not feeling too hungry and picky, I would recommend this place, only for noodles though!.
author: Katherine C.

description:
i got the kkang pong gee (dried fried chicken wings in spicy green onion goodness), jjajangmyun, spicy pork sautee, and chinese greens.

everything was perfectly cooked, exceptionally not greasy, and the wings were fricken amazeballs.
author: chise c.

description: I just did not like it.  Just sub-par.  We had to wait forever to get water and tea, refills, the hot ans sour soup was good, but that was about it.  Sweet and sour fish did nothing for me, and i thought the beef chow mein was lacking in flavor.  I would not go back.
author: Nicole F.

description:
mmmmmmmmmm. probably one of the best bang for your buck joints in the bay. portions are huge! and yummy!

go for the zajiang mien, walnut prawns, and fried chicken!

oh and the staff is great too
author: Justin T.

description: The first time I ate here, I was about 6 years old, with the rest of my family.  This is a great place to go for large parties.  It's a bit diferent from your typical Chinese restaurant because this is more of San Tung cuisine.  My favorites here are the kung pao shrimp (it's got a tangy taste to it) and their San Wang clams.  I was sad when they closed down the other locations, but I still come here after 25 years!!!
author: Selene K.

description: Good Chinese food. The zajiang mien is very good here. My favorite noodle dish. Also good are the dumplings, sweet and sour soup, and fried chicken. Good food at good prices. Service is friendly.
author: Leon C.

description: I agree with most of the yelpers... the jja jjiang myun was really good, but everything else was just eh... the chicken wings weren't even wings, they were like drumstick heads?  the seafood medley thing was missing the bamboo shoots it usually would have, the hot n sour soup wasn't even hot... and everything had too much msg.
author: Kymberli C.

description:
ok not a bad place for jja-jang myun BUT................this place has the best soo-go-gee tang-su-yuek in town ever.  litely in mean ever so litely battered and i think the meet is deep fried.  wow.........so yummmmmmmmmmmmmmmm!!!!!!!!!!!

it was so good i had to go back within the same week to try it again.  

the second time i was there i tried their jjam-ppong.  ew...it was ok.  i do however like there noodle consistancy.  jjolgi- jjolgi but not too much.  

i'm sure there are better places but for being close by this is decent place.  for korean/chinese food.
author: junie k.

description: You should come here just to get the San Wong clams.  For around $10, you get a huge portion of huge, tasty clams!   Looking around, most parties order the same dishes- clams, dry fried chicken, and eggplant with garlic sauce...  The other dishes are ok, but the clams are the yummy and cheap!
author: Sheryl L.

description:
FAMILY FAVORITE! There is no better place for szechuan than here! I know it's silly to go to Japan Town for Chinese, but I will drive the 30 or so miles to eat here and then go back home. Huge servings, great price and great people. I know exactly what I am getting when I go. Order the Princess Prawns, Szechuan Beef, and Mushu Pork!!! 

It's clean too! Not like the normal dirtiness experienced at most places in Chinatown.
author: suki y.

description: My family and I have been eating here for years and we always come back. Ive ate at many Chinese restaurants and this place is great. Definitely try out the dried fried chicken and calamari. Service is ok, not the best.
author: M L.

description: Excellent!!! Simply excellent!!! Had the black bean sauce noodles and San Wang chow mein.... The kimchee, tea, main courses, the large tv, and the fortune cookies were perfect! YUM!
author: Alex H.

description: Third stop in my epic, Bay Area jia-jian mien adventure.  It ranks toward the top because there are whole shrimps in the sauce.  I got four pieces.  My partner in crime got three.  Miscalculations are never bad when they are in your favor.
author: Andrew P.

description:
I really adore San Wang, there used to be one in San Jose but alas one day it was gone and in its place was sort of Taiwanese political bastion.

My favorites here are their steamed dumplings (nice and plump) as well as their seafood spicy noodle soup, as other reviewers have mentioned. I LOVE noodles and theirs are among the best I've tried...they are pulled and you can tell that they are not always consistent in width....fresh dough.....mmmmmmmmmmmmm.....
author: Veronica F.

description: Who cares about service in Chinese restaurant...  I never expect it.  It's all about food in Chinese restaurant!  Awesome portion of Mongolian Beef ( by the way, does Mongolians eat beef??? :)  nobody does Mongolian beef like these guys.
author: J Y.

description: This used to be my favorite Chinese food in the city, but that was many years ago...... loved the clams with black bean sauce, and dried fried squid.  The food quality is sometimes questionable, also the Hot and Sour soup is sometimes excellent and other times has no taste..I guess it depends on who's cooking.  The prices are high compared to other Chinese restaurants in the city but average for Japantown.  Don't go here for the service, as it is horrible!  I eat here about once a month, due to working in the area and needing a break from Japanese food.
author: Ed D.

description: Our go-to for Chinese in the hood. You gotta get the clams, the jia jiang mien (YUM! heart attack in a bowl!) and the chinese spinach greens. Service is lackluster as is the decor but what's new?  It is a chinese restaurant after all.
author: Cindy F.

description:
i followed the advice of other yelpers and tried the jajang myun and dried fried chicken. the jajang myun was ok. not bad. not great. tasted more chinese than other korean run establishment. could have used some more meat and veg.

the dried fried chicken was plentiful, meaning i think one order gives you like a dozen or more wings. i just know we had a LOT to spare. it was very garlicky, crispy skin when fresh. the next day is not as good. but i think i might still prefer san tung chicken more.

also tried the san wang seafood noodle soup. that was ok but it was too bland when we asked for less spicy, not knowing spiciness factor was correlated to flavor.

so sadly, wasn't over thrilled with the experience.
author: Cindy W.

description: This place has some bomb add food. Their dishes are also greatly presented. The braided fish is a dish I would highly recommend.
author: Cedric F.

description: I came here long time ago but forgot to write a review for it :P this place was my grandma's favorite and I thought the food was pretty good.   My favorite was the Jia-Jian Mien :)
author: JenJen W.

description:
I've eaten at San Wang since I was a little kid. At least 15 years. It used to be my family and many other family's after church lunch stop. 
I have memories of this place from sneakin around in the stair well adjacent to the entrance tryin to grab some ass from girls from my church to stealing Japanese candy from the markets on Post St. Most of all, the scrumptious noodles... mmmmmm=
They make their noodle the old skool way. Stretched and spun by hand. Their black bean sauce noodle and their seafood combo noodle soup are what I compare all others to. 
There are a couple of traditional things that us Koreans will eat with these noodles.  
1) Dry fried chicken wings are smothered in chunks of garlic and green onions. 
2) Spicy shrimp are lightly battered and deep fried then drenched in a sweet and spicy sauce.  
This is my favorite place to get these items.  The other stuff on the menu I can't really comment on cuz I've never had much of it. in the decade and a half that I've eaten here the noodles, chicken wings, shrimp have been fantastic enough not to even try the other stuff.
It may look smell and feel like an ordinary Chinese joint, but it is far from it.
author: Michael S.

description: I give this place 4 stars because the Sino-Korean items are worth the visit. It's all about the homemade noodles: black bean noodles (jja jjang mien) and spicy seafood noodle soup (jjam pong). The dry fried chicken (gamponggi) is pretty good too. The food is affordable and the service decent.
author: Jenny K.

description: I love this place for their ja jang mien and jang pong.  They are the best in Northern California that I know of other than this place in Sacramento, North China, that changed ownership years ago and moved to the South Bay.  If anyone knows the name of their restaurant tell me!
author: Jessica C.

description: Meh. Their dried chicken wings don't even come close to San Tung's awesome chicken wings.
author: Allie C.

description: This is the closest Chinese restaurant to my house, and they've got some pretty good food for reasonable prices. Their service is always prompt and you never have to wait too long for your food. I love their eggplant dishes especially. Since San Wang is Chinese cuisine done by mainly Koreans, they serve your table a small serving of Kim-Chee as a starter (complimentary). Highly reccomended for groups, as they have big enough tables to accomodate up to ten people at once. I enjoy coming here for dinner when I don't feel like scrounging through my pantry or freezer, and don't mind spending a little on a good meal.
author: Sean R.

description: I agree with Alice T., the food was scrumptious. Paticularly the kung pao shrimp and salt & pepper green beans - which surprised me. It's a different take on a classic chinese dish...  with the beans ever so lightly battered and tossed with sliced mushrooms, garlic and vegetables. Definitely my standout dish of the night. Apparently speaking in Mandarin scores you points here... as ordering in a different language could alter what your dish will be like. The service could stand for some improvement, hence the loss of one star. I thought it was colder than one would usually expect at a typical asian joint...  Decent prices tho.
author: Ikeb I.

description: first, san wang is also san wong. so if you look at the sign on the outside, it will say san wAng but then at the door, maybe just to confuse you, you'll see something that says san wOng. well, what you won't be confused about is the fact that they serve delicious handmade noodles in their dishes. my pal and I both ordered a bowl of the san wang soup noodles - spicy style. it was like a treasure trove of yumminess teeming with veggies, squid, clams, slices of pork (deeeelectable!), mushrooms and eternal happiness. yes, i vow to return to san wang to try all the other noodles i spied gracing the tables of other patrons.
author: ray e.

description: My in-laws have been coming here for decades. The jajang myun is very good. Their Nanjawansu (fried meat patties in spicy-tangy sauce) is well seasoned and delicious. But what really shines here is the whole fried fish with bean sauce. The fish is huge, and the bean sauce is very surprising. It is a generous amount of lovely, garlicky, brown bean gravy that has a pleasant sweetness to it. Very umami. It is such a large dish, we can never finish the entire thing, and we are a piggy, piggy little family. So we take home the leftover sauce, fish, fins, skin, bones... and eat it over rice the next day for luncheon. Mmmm!
author: Christine I.

description: meh. I specially didn't like the fried chicken. It had no taste, just raw garlic power over deeeeeeep fried chicken. Horrible.
author: Mohit K.

description:
everything deep fried is good here...dry fried shrimp, dry fried chicken, dry fried squid...yum.  all deep fried with garlic chili sauce.
lunch specials will fill you up.  almost enough for two.  we had 3 lunch specials for 4 people and still had leftovers.  couple of favorites are the cashew chicken and sizzling rice soup.
who cares if it is "korean chinese" and not just "chinese"?  Good eats is good eats!!!
author: Dustin S.

description:
You know when you walk by a restaurant time and time again and see it packed, it means something! Well, even better: You know when you walk past a Chinese restaurant in Japan Town time and time again and it is always PACKED with Chinese people that the food is gonna be really really good, or at the least a killer value....
So, on our way with mouth watering cravings for a Japanese curry walking down Post street into Japantown Center we took a turn into San Wang because the packed interior just screamed to us "this has to be good!!!".
The price, as we expected is super affordable and the food selection and quality was great, always accompanied by complimentary kimchee. The noodles were OK (I expected a bigger selection after the write-up taped on to the window highlights their in-house made noodles), but the stars were their stir fries and uhm, uhm... the deep fried dishes...
The fried chicken wings are obviously popular but we ordered something on a whim and I must say, their rendition of FRIED CALAMARI is pretty insane!!!!!! Huge portion of beautiful plump crispness garnished by an amazing flavorful garnish sprinkled over it that consisted of fried garlic chips and little dried red fried chillies and scallions, pretty killer.
author: Emily J.

description: I was here with family, hungry family, and we all enjoyed our meal here. My Korean sis-in-law ordered food family style which ended up being *way* too much food for 3 adults and 2 kids, but it was so good we ate it all. I am also a huge fan of the plum sauce noodles. Usually when I come here with Chinese friends we get the clams with black bean sauce, which totally rocks. We started with some OB beer and crispy beef. The noodles with bean sauce for the kids and spicy seafood noodle soup for the adults. It was great and I would come again. The style of food is different but since I don't live in Oakland anymore this is where I am coming for my Korean Chinese food. Next time I'm getting the whole fried fish since it looked and smelled so good on the tables near us.
author: Stephanie R.

description: we went to san tung on a wednesday night and they were closed, so we looked to find another place to get dry fried chicken wings.  this place had good reviews so we went.  it wasnt even close to san tung.  it lacked the flavor and texture that the san tung wings have.  i only ate like 6 wings when i was in the mood for a mega feast.  we also ordered pot stickers which basically tasted like kimchee was the only ingredient.  huge disappointment.
author: Brian K.

description: For those that say this compares to San Tung, I dont agree. I had high hopes for this place but was sadly disappointed. The dishes like the chicken wings look like it would be so tasty with all the colors and spices, but for some reason, was not. The noodle was just alright. I felt really greasy afterwards too. The service was fast and nice though.
author: Ravenous T.

description: I've read a slew of reviews so far, and every one of them (good or bad) omits the crown jewel of San Wang, THE BRAISED FISH!!!! The garlicky, brown-sugary, damned deliciously fantastic dish is one of the best in SF. If you don't need a flashy setting to enjoy your quality meal, this is the place for you. The noodles are made in-house, and are hard to beat. The Szechuan beef and dry-fried everything (especially green beans) are equally great. If you don't already have your heart set on a restaurant in Japantown, go here! You're still reading this? Go already!!!
author: Nick W.

description: I had a blast there with great food and especially the service!  One down side of this place, are the kitchen staff, they smoke and while I was waiting for the restroom you could actually smell the cigarette burning!!!  Did anyone else notice the kitchen staff?  I thought aprons were white but not here, they need to bleach them!!
author: Gavy J.

description: I live near the San Wang, it was a place that I wanted to give it a try. I really didn't care if a place had a good service or no service, because I go for the food. However, no amount of good food will get me back to rude wait staff. There is a difference between no service and rude/bad service.  My friend and I had ordered 3 entrees for lunch, we were never asked if everything was alright. When I requested for a side dish of radish, the wait staff in a very unprofessional toned told me to "wait a minute", of course it was never brought to me.  I guess the place thinks that big portion will bring people in.  For good food and service, I would still go to the Hong Kong Lounge on Geary.
author: bill w.

description: Having heard so much about their dry fried chicken, dumplings, and hand pulled noodles being the stars of the show, especially for a Shandong restaurant like there is, I was itching like crazy to try it.  Finally, a few nights ago, I did just that.  Our eyes were bigger than our stomachs with another night's worth of food; the service is very friendly, prices very reasonable, and atmosphere clean though no frills.  The water dumplings (boiled dumplings filled with shrimp and chives) topped with a little soy sauce are excellent; just the right amount of gossamerness with succulent shrimp and subtle chives.  The dry fried chicken is excellent with a light glaze of a sauce of black pepper, chili, and garlic.  The shrimp with black bean sauce are succulent with one of the most flavorful black bean sauces ever and fresh green onions and bell peppers.  The steamed rice is firm not soggy.  The plum sauce noodles are to die for; hand pulled fresh goodness of just the right amount of gossamerness and chewiness you would expect in northern style noodles.  The complimentary kim chi is an excellent spicy, salty, crunchy number.  So, for excellent Shandong cuisine at reasonable prices with friendly service in a clean yet no frills atmosphere, Sam Wang's cannot be beat.  keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: Went back to this place last week after a few years. We ordered the dry fried chicken, dry fried scallops, mongolian beef and curry chicken. Service was quick , food was really good, prices very decent and place looks great...only gripe is that the table for 4 is small, we had to stack plates' edges!--or we were all pigs for ordering so damn much! Oh yeah, hot and sour soup is off the hook!
author: Steve K.

description: Pretty good food. Went here with all my girl cousins for lunch time after Church. But, then again it was the same chinese food we'd always order. So, it was okay.
author: Rachel P.

description: I don't come here for the noodles like everyone else does .  I come here specifically for 2 dishes.  The mongolian beef and dry fried squid.  both are great dishes and I leave here with garlicky breath.
author: kenny l.

description: I have been going to San Wang for over 15 years. It has been consistently good over the entire period. I love the baby shrimp with pepper sauce and their green mussels. I am currently going into withdrawal since they have been closed for so long for remodeling. Their phone message says they are reopening the end of June, but here it is the end of July and still no  opening. I can't wait any longer :(
author: Frisco F.

description: Not bad.  JJa Jang Myun is probably the best in the City, far better than Zazang and more authentic than San Tung.
author: DJ K.
